Of itself with Chian wine (it is good) for ye griefs of the eyes. But ye juyce of it, doth take away the dimnesse that is in the eyes, and drie up the rhumes. But the seed being dranck is good for such as breed melancholy, & for ye Dysureticall and for the Flatulent. It causeth also many sneesings, being drawn up by the smell, & the herb doth the like. But they eyes must be shut whilst ye sneesing holds. Somme also doe avoyd it and doe not eate it, because that being chewed, and set in the Sunne, it breeds little wormes. But the Africans have entertained it, because they which eate it & are smitten of a Scoprion, yet remaine without paine.

Orobanche, [somme call it Cynomorion, somme Leonom, but the Cyprians call it Thyrsine, It is commonly call Lycos, [as we should say, A wolf] is a little stalke sommewhat red, as it were of twoe spans [high] & somme tymes greater, fattish in leaves, rough, tender, endowed with whitish flowers, or sommewhat enclining to yellow. The roote lyes under, of the thicknesse of a finger, eaten through with holes at ye drying of the stalke. It seems that growing among somme pulse, it doth choke them, whence also it had its name. It is used as a Pothearb, either raw, or sod, being eaten out of a platter as Asparagus. And being sod together with Legumina, it is thought to make them seeth ye sooner.

Tragopogon, or Tetrapogon, somme call it Come, is a short stalke, the leaves like unto saffron. The roote long, sweet. A great Cup upon the stalke, & a black fruit out of the top, from which also it tooke its name; it is an edible Herbe.

Ornithogalon is a tender stalke, thinne, whitish, as it were of two spans, having three or 4 tender slips, growing together on the top, from which comme the flowers, which outwardly looke of the colour of Herbes, but being opened they are like milke, and between them a little head cut in as Canchrys, which is baked together with bread, as Melanthium. The roote is bulbose, which is eaten both raw, & sod.
Tuber is a round roote, without leaves and without stalke, of a pale yellow, being digged up in ye spring it is edible, eaten either raw, or sod.

Garden Smilax, whose fruit Lobia (as we should say Siliquae) is called Asparagus of somme, hath leaves like unto Ivie, but softer, but thinne stalkes, and claspers wrapped about the neighbouring shrubs, which grow soe much, that they serve to be made into bowers. It beares a fruit like unto Foenigreek, but longer, and more renowned, within which are seeds like unto kidnies, not alike of colour, but partly sommewhat reddish. The fruit (or rather the Siliqua) is eaten pot-herb-like together with ye seeds, being boyled as Asparagus. But it moves urine, & is a causer of troublesomme dreames.

Medica being but just sprung up, is like unto Trifolium that growes in meadowes, but being more growne it becommes to be narrower-leaved, sending out stalks like unto Trifolium, upon the which growes the seed of the bignesse of a lentill wreathed about as a little horne; which being dryed, is mixed for its sweet savour’s sake to salt sauces. But being layd on whilst it is green, it is good for whatsoever hath need of cooling. But they which breed beasts use the whole herbe instead of grasse.

Aphace is a little shrub growing in the fields, higher than the Lentiae, small leaved. But the Siliquae that grow upon it are greater than those of the Lentill, containing three or four little seeds, great & lesse than the Lentill. The little seeds of it have a binding facultie, whence they stop both the flux of ye belly and ye stomach, being fryed, or bruised and sod, as ye Lentill is.

The headed Leek [the Latins call it Porrum] is inflative, of bad juice, causing troublesomme dreams, ureticall, good for the belly, extenuating, causing dullnesse of sight, expelling of ye menstrua, hurting of the exulcerated baldder, & of ye kidnies. But being sod with Ptissana or otherwise eaten, it brings out the thinges that stop ye breast. But ye blades of it beeing sod in sea-water & vinegar, is excellent good by way of Insession for the suffocation & hardnesse of the wombe. But it growes sweet & becommes lesse flatulent if it be sod in two waters, & macerated in cold water. But the seed is the sharper, having also sommething of binding. Whence the juice of it with vinegar and Manna or Franckincense mixed, doth stop the bloud, & especially that which commes from the Nosthrills, and it doth provoke Venerie, and it is good to be used as a Lohoc with Hony for all the griefs in the Thorax, and being eaten (it is also good) against ye tabes. It doth also cleanse Spiritalem canaliculam. But being eaten with a continuance, it is a duller of the sight, & is also naught for ye stomach. The juice also being dranck with Melicrate is a remedie for such as are bitten by venemous beasts, & the leek itself too, being applyed doth doe good. The juice also being dropped in with Acetum, & Franckincense, and milke, or Rosaceum, doth help the paines of ye eares and the noyses of them. The leaves also being applyed with Rhoe obsoniorum, doe take away the varos, & heale ye Epinyctidae. And being layd on with salt, it doth emarginate the crusts of ulcers. But twoe dragms of the seeds being dranck with the like quantity of Myrtle-berries doe stop the veteres superne rejectiones sanguinis.
Ampeloprasum is worse for ye stomach than the leeke, but it is warmer & more ureticall, expelling of the Menstrua; it is good also being eaten for such as are bitten of poysonous beasts.

The oynion [which somme call Polyides, ye Magi Calabotis, the Latins Caepa] which is long is sharper than that which is round, and the redd than the white, and the drie than the green, and the raw than the roasted, or kept in salt. But they are all of them of a biting qualitie and inflative, inviting of an appetite, extenuating, breeding thirst, causing nauseousnes, purging, good for the belly, opening ye passages of other excrements, soe also of ye Haemorrhoids. They are given for a suppositorie, beeing first peeled, and cast into oyle. But the juice being anointed on with Hony, doth help such as are dull of sight, the Argemae, the Nubeculae, & such as beginne to be troubled with suffusions, and the Anginosi also, being anointed on. It doth both moove & expell ye menstrua, & being infusus it is a purger of the head, by the Nosthrill. It is a Cataplasme with salt, and Rue, and Hony for such as are bitten of doggs. And being thorougly anointed in ye sun with Acetum it doth cure the Vitiligines, and with the like quantitie of Spodium, it doth assuage the scabras lippitudines. And with salt it doth represse the Varos. With pultries grease it is good for shooe galls, and for the flux of the belly, & for hardnesse of hearing, and for noyse in ye eares, and for purulent eares: it is good also for the dropping down of water in ye eares, & for the Alopeciae being rubd on, for it doth sooner call out ye haire than Alcyonium. But oinion being much eaten causeth the head-ach, but being sod it becommes the more diureticall. But being much eaten of in tyme of sicknesse it makes men lethargicall. But this being sod and applyed as a Cataplasme with raisins of the Sunne or figges it ripens and breakes swelling soares.

Garluk [somme call it Geboscum, some againe Elaphoboscum, the Latins Allium] somme of it is Sative & growes in gardens, & this in Egypt, being only but of one head as the leeke, sweet, inclining to a purple colour. But elsewhere, it is compacted of many white cloves, the cloves that therein (the Greeks) call Aglithai. But there is another wilde kinde, called Ophioscorodon, (that is Serpent’s Garlick). It hath a sharp, warming biting qualitie, expelling of flatulencies, and distrubing of the belly, and drying of the stomach causing of thirst, & of puffing up, breeding of boyles in ye outsyde of the body, dulling the sight of the eyes. And the same thinges doth Ophioscorodon doe being eaten, which is called Elaphoscorodon also, (as we should say, Hart’s garlick), Being eaten, it drives out the broade wormes, and drawes away the urine. It is good, as none other thing, for such as are bitten of vipers, or of the Haemorrhous, wine being taken presently after, or else that being beaten small in wine, & soe dranck. It is applyed also by ye way of Cataplasme both for the same purposes profitably, as also layd on upon such as are bitten of a mad dogge. Being eaten, it is good against the chaunge of waters [fauces expediende, easdeings asperas leniendo]. It doth cleare the arteries, & being eaten either raw or sod, it doth assuage old coughes. Being dranck with decoction of Origanum, it doth kill lice and nitts. But being burnt, and tempered with hony it doth cure the sugillationes oculorum, and Alopeciae being anointed on, but for the Alopeciae (it must be applyed) with unguentum Nardinum. And with salt & oyle it doth heale ye eruptiones papularum. It doth take away also the Vitiligines, & the Lichenes, & the Lentigenes, and the running ulcers of the head, and the Furfures, & ye Lepras, with hony. Being sod with Taeda and franckincense, & kept in the mouth it doth assuage the paine of ye teeth. And with figge leaves & Cummin it is a Cataplasme for such as are bitten of the Mygale. But the leafes decoction is an insession that brings downe the Menstrua & the Secundas. It is also taken by way of suffumigation for ye same purpose. But the stamping that is made of it and ye black olive together, called Myrton, doth move the urine & open ye mouths of ye veines & it is good also for the Hydropicall.

Scordoprasum growes of the bignesse of a leek partaking of the qualities both of the garlick and the Leek, wherefore also it hath a mixt kinde of strength, performing that which ye garlick & ye leeke doe, but with lesse efficacie. It is ordered as a pot hearb to be eaten, as ye leeke is, being sod, & soe made to grow sweet.
Sinepi, or Napy, [the Romans call it Sinapi]

Choose that which is not very drie, & very red, full, but which being broken lookes green within, & as it were juicie and galucum. For that which is new & in its prime is such. It is of a facultie to warme, to attenuate, and to draw, and being chewed to purge the Pituita of ye head. But ye juice of it being mixed with Hydromel & gargarized, is good for the hard swellings of the Tonsillae, and for the old & callosas Scabritias of the Arterie. Being beaten small, and put unto ye nosthrills it causeth snevlings, it doth also help the Epilepticall, and revive such as are troubled with the strangling of the Vulva. It is also anointed on the Lethargicall, ye head being first shorne. Being mixed with figgs and layd on the place till it comme to rednesse it is good for Sciaticaes & Spleens, and in generall for any paine of long continuance when wee would draw out any thing from the deep within to the outsyde of the body (to cure it) by diverting the grief somme other way. And being anointed on also it doth cure the Alopeciae and doth cleanse the face, and takes away the sugillata Oculorum with Hony, or fatt, or Cerat. With Acetum it is anointed round about for Leprosies and the wilde Impetigines. It is dranck also drie against ye circuits of fevers, being sprinckled on the drincke like as Polenta. It is also profitably mixed with drawing plaisters & such as are made for the Psora. It is good also for the hardnesse of hearing & ye noyse in the eares, being beaten with figgs and soe applyed. But the juice of it with Hony is good both for the dullnesse of ye sight and for the Scabritias genarum being anointed on. The juice is prest out of it whilst ye seed is green, and that which is prest dryed in the Sunne.

Cresses [Somme call it Cynocardamom, somme Iberis, others Cardamina, or Cardamantica, ye Aegyptians Semeth, the Latins Nasturtium], that seems to be best which is in Babylon. The seed of any sort of it is warming, sharpe, bad for ye stomach, troubling the belly, & expelling wormes, lessening ye spleen, killing the Embrya, moving ye menstrua, inciting to copulation: it is like of nature to mustard seed, & rocket seed. It doth cleanse away Lepras, & impetigines. With Hony it keeps low the spleen being anointed on, & it takes away the Favos, & it brings up the things sticking in the Thorax, being sod in Sorbitionibus. And being dranck it is an Antidot against the poyson of Serpents, and with the suffitus of it, it drives away serpents. It staies falling haire. And bringing Carbuncles to suppuration it breakes them round about. Being anointed on with Acetum & Polenta, it is good for the Sciaticall. And it doth dissolve Oedemata and inflammations, and brings Furunculi to suppuration being anointed on with brine. And the herb doth performe the same thinges, yet it is somewhat lesse effectuall.

Thlaspi [somme call it Thlaspidium, somme Sinapi Persicum, somme Sinapi sylvestre, somme Myiten, somme Myopteron, somme Dasmophon, some Bitrum, the Aegyptians Suitempsum, ye Romans Scandulaceum, somme call it Capsella, somme pes Gallinaceum] is a little herb, narrow in the leaves, the height as it were of a finger, bending to the ground, divided at the toppe, somewhat fatt. It sends out a little stalke of twoe spans heighth, having a few little branches, & about the whole of it there is a fruit from the toppe sommewhat broade wherein there is a little seed enclosed like to Nasturtium, of the fashion of a dish, as it were broken or bruised, whence also it tooke its name; but the flower of it is sommewhat white, growing in waies, and upon walls, & in hedges. The seed is sharpe, warming, purging choler upward and downeward, being dranck to ye quantitie of an Acetabulum. It is made also into a Glister for the Sciaticall. Being dranck it brings out blood, and breakes the internos abscessus. It moves ye Menstrua also, and destroies the Embrya.
Crateuas reckons up another kinde of Thlaspi which somme call Persicum Sinapi, broad leaved & bigge rooted, & this also is mixed in Glisters for the Sciatica.

Draba is an herbe having the height of a Cubit, and slender Spriggs, with leaves on both sydes as of Lepidium yet more tender and whiter, with a tuft on the top of it like Elder, having white flowers. The herb of this is sod with Ptisana especially in Cappadocia, but the drye seed of it is mixed with sauces instead of Pepper.

Erysimum [somme call it Chamaeplion, the Magi Herculis Alphita (hoc est Polenta), the Aegyptians Erethmu, the Romans call it Irio] growes about townes and yards of howses and gardens, but it hath leaves like unto Eruca Sylvestris. It hath little stalks plyable & flexible like a reine flowers of an yellowish colour, on the top are little Cods like hornes, slender as those of Foenigraec, in which are little seeds like those of Nasturtium, burning according to the tast, which being licked in with Hony are good for the flux of the Thorax, spitting up of rotten stuff, coughes, the Icterus, and Sciaticaes. And it is dranck also against deadly drenches. Being anointed on with water or Hony, it is good for the hidden Carcinomata, for hardnesses, the Parotides, the inflammations of the stones, and the duggs, and in generall it doth attenuate and warme, but it is made the milder for Eclegmaes, being macerated in water, and parched, or bound into a linnen cloth and wrapt about with kneaded flour, & soe roasted. [Let Erysimum being beaten small with wine be dranck for ye paine of ye belly, & if you cast 7 graines into an house, there shall be contention].

Pepper is sayd to be a short tree growing in India, it sends out a fruit, at first long, like Cods, which is the long Pepper, having sommething within it like Milium which will be perfect Pepper, which at its tyme opening itself, it sends out clusters bearing graines such as wee know, of which somme are unripe, which are the white Pepper, which is especially fitting for eye medicines & for Antidots and for Theriacall faculties, but the long is endved with an extraordinarie biting qualitie, and sommewhat bitter because of its unripenesse and is fitting for Antidots and Thericall faculties. But the Black is sweeter and sharper than the white, and more pleasant to the mouth, and more aromaticall because it is ripe, & more fitt to be used for sawces, but the white and unripe is weaker than the aforesayd. Chuse that which is heavist, and full, black, not to much wrinkled, new, and not branny. There is sommme found amongst this black, without nourishment, lanck and light, which is called Brasma. All pepper in generall hath a warming, ureticall, concocting, attracting, dissolving power, & of cleansing away of those thinges which darken the Pupillae. It is good also being either dranck, or anointed on, for periodicall rigors (of feavers), & it doth help such as are bitten of poysnous beasts, & it drives out ye Embrya. And being applyed as a Pessum is seems to be an hinderer of conception after conjunction. And it is good for all ye passions about the Thorax, and for coughs, being taken either in Lohocs or potions. And it is good for ye Squinancie, being anointed on with hony, and it dissolves the Tormina being dranck with the tender leaves of Lawrell. Being chewed with Uvae passae, it drawes the Pituita out of the head. And it is both an easer of paine and healing, & provokes appetite being mixed in sawces. Being taken with Pitch it doth dissolve the Strumae, & with Nitre it doth cleanse away the Vitiligines. It is roasted in a new earthen vessell over coales, being shaked about like as Lens. But the roote of it is not Ginger, as somme have supposed, as wee will shew a little after. Yet the roote of Pepper is like unto Costus, warming the tast, and causing spittle. It being anointed on with Acetum doth humble the spleen, but being chewed with Staveacre it draws out the Pituita.

Ginger is a private plant growing plentifully in Troglodyticall Arabia, the green herb of which they use for many purposes, as we doe Rue, seething & mixing it in oyle for drinkinge, & sod meates. It hath small little roots, as those of Cyperus whitish, resembling pepper in tast, and of a sweet smell. Chuse those which are most without rottennesse. But of somme, because of their soone rotting, they are preserved and are carryed into Italie in earthen vessells fitt for meate, but they are taken together with their pickle. But they have a warming concocting power, mollifying of the belly gently, & good for ye stomach. And it is effectuall against those thinges that darken the Pupillae. It is also mixed with Antidots, & in generall in a manner it doth resemble pepper in its strength.

Hydropiper growes chiefly by standing waters, or such as flow gently. It sends out a stalke that is knottie, strong, about which are the Concavitates alarum, and leaves like unto minte, but greater, and delicater, and whiter, sharpe in tast like Pepper but not having any sweet smell. It hath a fruit growing upon the little branches growing neere the leaves, hanging close together, & like clusters of grapes, & that also is sharp. The leaves beeing applyed with the seeds have power to dissolve Oedemata and old hardnesses, and to take away the sugillata. But being dryed & beaten they are mixed with salt, & sawces instead of Pepper. But it hath a little roote that is for noe use.

Ptarmica is a little shurb, having small branches, many, round, like unto Sothernwood, about which are many leaves sommewhat long, like to those of the Olive tree; on the top a little head, as of Anthemis, small, round, sharpe according to the smell, provoking of sneesing, from whence also it is named. The leaves being smeared on with the flowers are of force to take away the sugillata sub oculis. But the flowers move sneesings most effectually. It growes in mountainous & rocky places.

Struthium [of somme it is called Cerdon, of others Catharsis, of others Struthiocamelus, of somme Chamaerrhytos, the Magi call it Chalyriton, the Latins Radix or Herba Lanaria, the Aegyptians Oeno, the Africans call it Syris] is commonly knowne, which Fullers use for making cleane their wool. The root of which is sharp & ureticall. It helps those which are Liver-sick, and coughes, & ye Orthopnoeae, the quantitie of a spoonefull thereof being taken with hony, and it doth subducere alvum. And being taken with Panaces and the roote of Capparis, it breakes the stones, & makes them to be voyded by urine, and it melts the spleen hardned into a Schirrhus, & being subditum, it draws downe menstrua & doth effectually kill the Embrya. Being smeared on with Polenta and Acetum, it takes away the leprosie. & It doth dissolve the Panos, being sod with barly meale & wine. It is mixed also with Collyries made for sharpening the sight, and with mollifying medicines. And it moves sneesing. And being beaten small, & put up into ye nosthrills with Hony it purgeth through ye mouth.

Cyclaminus [somme call it Cissanthemon, others call it Cissophyllon, somme Chelonion, others Ichthyotheron, somme call it Chuline, somme call it Zoroastris, or Trimphalites, Osthenes calls it Aspho, the Magi Miaspho, the Aegyptians Theske, the Romans Rapum terrae, (aut Umbilicus terrae, aut Orbicularis) and somme call it Arcar] hath leaves like unto Ivie, of a purple colour, divers, with whitish spots beneath and above, a stalke of four fingers high, bare & naked, on which are flowers like Roses, enclining to a purple colour, the roote black, much like the Rape roote, and sommewhat broader. Which being dranck with Hydromel, doth drive the flegme & water downeward, and doth move the Menstrua, being either pota or subdita. They say that if a woman great with childe doe goe over ye roote, that shee doth make abortion, and being tyed about her it doth hasten the birth. It is dranck with wine against deadly poysons, and especially against the Sea-Hare. And being applyed, it is a remedie against ye bitings of serpents and being mixed with wine it causeth drunckennesse. It doth also drive away the yellow Jaundice being dranck the quantitie of three drammes with Passum or diluted melicrate. But hee who drinckes it, must lye downe upon his bed in a warme howse, not open to the winde, and be covered with many cloaths that hee may sweate (the more easily). But the sweat that commes out, is found of a Gaully colour. The juice of it is put into the Nosthrills with Hony for to purge the head. And it is put up in wool into ye seate, for to bring downe the excrements of the belly. And the same being anointed on ye Navill, & ye lower part of the belly & ye hipp, doth mollify the belly, and doth work abortions. And the juyce anointed on with Hony is good for ye Oculi suffusi and hebetiores. It is mixed also with medicines that cause abortion. The juice being anointed on with Acetum doth restore the seate againe, when it is fallen downe. The roote being beaten is juiced, & squeesed out, the juice being sod to the consistence of Hony. The roote also doth cleanse ye skinne, & stayes the breaking out of pustles, & cures wounds with vinegar either of itself, or with hony. Being applyed it doth mollify the spleene (and abates it). It doth also take away the sunne-burning & ye Alopeciae. And the decoction thereof being fomented on is fitting for luxations, & the goute, and for little ulcers in the head, & for ye perniones. And it being sod in old oyle, it brings wounds to a cicatrix, the oyle being smeared on. The roote also being made hollow, is filled with oyle, & set over warme ashes, & sommetymes there is added unto it a little of Tyrrhenian wax, that it may be glewy, an excellent oyntment for such as are troubled with the Perniones. The roote of it also is layd up in store, beeing cut in pieces as that of ye Squill. It is sayd also that it is taken amongst love-procuring medicines being beaten, & soe made into Trochiscks. But it growes in shadie places, & especially under trees.

The other Cyclamen, which somme call Cissanthemon or Cissophyllon, hath leaves like unto Ivie but lesser, thick stalkes, knottie, rolling about ye trees that grow next to them, like the tendrells of vines. The flowers are white and odoriferous, but the fruit as the Acini uvae, like unto ivie, soft, single, sharpe in the tast, and viscous. The roote is unprofitable. It growes in rough places. The fruit of this being dranck as much as ye quantitie of one dragme with twoe Cyathi of white wine for fourtie daies doth melt ye spleene, & is a bringer downe of the belly by urine. It is also dranck for the Orthopnoea. And being dranck it doth purge away the rellicks after childe-bearing.

[Dracontium maius, somme call it Aron, somme Isaron, somme Iaron, somme Hieracicus, somme Biaron, somme Aron agreste, somme Cyperis, the Romanes call it Colubrina, others Mauriaria, others call it Sigingialios. It growes in shadie places about hedges. It hath a smooth stalke, upright, of the height as it were of twoe cubits, & about the thicknesse of a staffe, divers coloured according to ye tyme, soe that it doth resemble a Dragon, and it doth abound in purple spotts. It hath leaves of the fashion of Lapathum folded one within another. It bringes forth a fruit on the top of ye stalke in clusters, at first of an ashie colour, but when it is ripe enclining to a saffron, and purple, colour. It hath a very great roote, round, white, having a thinne barck. It is gathered & juiced when it is thoroughly ripe & dryed in the shade. But ye roote is digged up in the harvest, and being washed is cut in small pieces, & thrust through with a thong, but is dryed in ye shade. It is of a warming facultie being dranck with diluted wine. Being either sod or roasted, it is good being taken as a Lohoc with hony, for the Orthopnoici, for ruptures, convulsions, coughs, distillation. But being dranck with wine, it stirrs up the vehement desires to conjunction. But being beaten small with hony, and applyed, it takes away the malignancie of ulcers, & eating ulcers, & especially with the white vine. And Collyries also are formed of it with Hony for Fistulas, & for ye drawing out of the Embrya. It is good also for ye vitiligines, being smeared on with Hony. It doth also take away the Polypi & the Carcinomata. The juice also of it is good for eye medicines, for ye nubeculae, the albugines, & ye Caligo. But the smell of ye roote, or of the herbe, is destructive of late conceptions, as also thirtie graines of the seed being dranck with Posca (are of ye like effect.) But somme have poured in ye juice of this with oyle into the eares of such as have been pained in them & have layd on the leaves, as binding, on new wounds & have applyed them, being sod in wine, to such as have ye Perniones. And they say, that such as rub the leaves in their hands, or beare ye roote digged up about them, shall not be bitten of a viper.]

Dracontium, or Dracunculus, hath leaves like Ivie, great, having white spots, but an upright stalke of twoe cubits high, divers coloured, after the fashion of a serpent, spotted with purple spots, of the thicknesse of a stalke. The fruit on the top of it, like clusters of grapes, in ye colour at first indeed like grasse, but when it is ripe like saffron, biting the tast. The roote in a manner round, bulbosa, like unto Aron having a thinne barck. It growes in shadie places about hedges and moundes. But the juice of the seed being prest out, & put with oyle into the eare, doth cease the paine of the eares. But being put with wool into the nosthrills, (it is of force) to destroy the Polypus. Being anointed on also to stop the Carcinomata. But as much as thirtie graines thereof being dranck with Posca cause abortion. And they say that the smell thereof, after ye withering of the flowers, is destructive of Embrya newly conceaved. But the roote being of a warming qualitie, doth help the Orthopnoeae, the rupturae, convulsions, coughs, ye distillation. And it makes the moisture sticking in the thorax to be easily expectorated, (if it be given) either sod, or roasted with hony, or else eaten of itself. But being drye, & small beaten it is taken as a lohoc with Hony. It is ureticall also, and stirrs up affections to conjunction being dranck with wine. And it doth cleanse malignant ulcers, and phagedoenica, & brings them to a cicatrix, being beaten small with white Brionie with Hony. And Collyria are made thereof for Fistuals & for the bringing out of ye Embrya. And they say that if any one doe rubbe his hands with ye roote, he remaines unbiteable of the viper. It doth also cleanse away ye vitiligines being anointed on with Acetum. But the leaves being beaten small are profitable being layd on ye newly wounded instead of Linnet, & for the Perniones, being sod in wine, & applyed. And cheese also wrapped in the leaves, is kept from putrifaction. And the juice of the roote, is good for ye nubeculae and the Albugines, & ye Caligines oculorum. The roote is ordered for use in health, being eaten either sod or raw. But they which dwell in the Gymnesian Isles called Baleares, mixing the sodden roote with much Hony, doe set it in their banquetts instead of Placentae. But ye roote must be set up by them who digged it in the harvest, having washt it, & cut it in small pieces, & made a thread goe through them, and dryed them in the shade.

Aron, which is called Lupha amongst ye Syrians [somme call it Alimon, somme Thymon, somme Dracontium, which the Cyprians also call Colocassion] doth send out leaves like to those of Dracontium, yet lesser, & lesse spotted, a stalke of a span long, of a faint purple, & of the forme of a Pestle, wherein is a fruit enclining to a saffron colour. The roote is white neere unto that of Dracontium, which is also eaten when it is sod, being sommewhat lesse sharpe. The leaves are preserved in salt for to be eaten, & when they have been dryed, they are sodden, and soe eaten alone of themselves. But the roote, and the seed, and the leaves have the same force as Dracontium. Particularly, the roote being applyed with bullocks dunge unto such as are troubled with the gowte, it doth doe them good. The roote is to be layd up after the same manner as that of Dracunculum. And in brief, it is edible because it is not oversharpe.

Arisarum is a little small herbe, having a roote of the bignesse of an olive, but it is sharper then Aron, whence, being anointed on, it staies the Nomas. And Collyries are made of it effectuall for Fistulas, but being either put in, or applyed thereunto, it doth destroy the Genitall of any living creature.

Asphodelus [somme call it Anthericum, ye Romans call it Albucium] is a plant knowne unto most, having leaves like unto the great Leek, but a smooth stalke, having on the top a flower called Anthericon, the roots are under, sommewhat long, round, like Suppositories, sharpe to ye tast, and for their facultie warming. These being dranck doe move the Urine, and the Menstrua; they doe also cure the paines of the syde, and coughes, & convulsions, & ruptures, being dranck the quantity of a dragme in wine. It causeth easy vomiting, as much as a knuckle bone being eaten in meate, & it is profitably given to such as are bitten of serpents as much as ye quantity of three dragms, and you must lay to the bitings ye Cataplasme made of the leaves & ye roote and ye flowers with wine. It doth also cure filthy, & feeding ulcers, & the inflammations of ye duggs & of the stones, & the Tubercula, & ye Furunculi, the lees of wine being sod together with the roote, but for new inflammations, (it is to be applyed) with Polenta. But the juice of the roote, taking therewith of old sweet wine & myrrh and saffron, sod together, is an (excellent) medicine to be anointed on the eyes. And either of itself, or warmed together with Franckincense, & hony, and wine, and myrrhe, it is good to be put into purulent eares. And the juice of itself being poured into the contrary eare doth assuage the toothach. But the roote being burnt, and the ashes anointed on, doth thicken ye Alopeciae, (or fill it with haire). But Oyle that is sod in the hollowed roots over the fire doth help exulcerated Perniones and ambusta, being anointed on, and it doth help the paine of the eare, being poured into the eare. And the roote smeared on doth take away ye Vitiligo alba being first rubbed with a napkin in the Sunne. But the seed, and the flowers being dranck in wine are an extraordinary remedie against ye stroakes of the Scolopendrae, and of Scorpions. But they doe mightily purge the belly. [It beares flowers in the tyme of Harvest. But the white Asphodelus, must be cut downe about the vernall Aequinoctiall before the seed encrease. They say that ye roote being dranck, makes men to have noe appetite to Venery. And Crateuas the Herbalist sayth ye same, and that the roote being dranck with wine one dragme, doth cure the paines of the gowte].

The edible Bulbus, & that which wee eate, is knowne to all, being good for the stomach & ye belly, red, & brought from Africa, but that which is bitter & like ye squill, is better for ye stomach, & helps concoction, but they are all sharpe, and warming, & provoking to conjunction, exasperating the tongue & the Tonsillas, being of much nourishment & replenishing with flesh, but they breed winde. Being anointed on they are good for luxations, bruises, splinters, & for the griefs of the jointes, & for gangraenes & gowtes, being applyed either with Hony, or of themselves. As also for the Oedemata of the Hydropicall, and for ye bitings of doggs, being applyed likewise with hony & pepper beaten small. They doe also represse swetts, and mitigate the paines of the stomachs.

With nitre roasted they doe cleanse away the Furfures & the running sores of ye head. And they doe also cleanse the sugillata sub oculis being applyed either alone, or with ye yolke of an egge, & ye Varos, as also the Lentigines with hony, or Acetum. And with Polenta they are good for ye fractiones avrium, & for ye contusiones unguium. And they take away the Piles also, being roasted in hott embers, & with ye burnt heads of ye fishes called Maenae, & soe applyed. But being burnt, & mixt with Alcyonium, & anointed on in the sunne, they take away sunne-burnings & black skarrs. Being sod, with vinegar eaten they are good for ruptures. But heed must be taken of feeding too much on them, because they are offensive to the sinewie parts. [But being sod with Polenta, & applyed with swines grease, it doth quickly bring the oedemata & tubercula to suppuration, & breakes them.]

Bulbus called vomitorius, hath leaves more flexible, like a bridle, & farre greater than ye edible, a roote like the Bulbus, about which is a black barck, which roote being eaten of itself, as also ye decoction thereof being dranck, doth cure the griefs about ye bladder, & provokes vomiting.

Scilla hath a sharpe & burning facultie, but being roasted, it is made usefull for many purposes. But it is wrapt about with dough or clay, & put into an oven, or hidd under hott coales, till the dough that doth enfold it, be sufficiently baked, which being off, if ye squill within it be not tender, we shall take ye like course with it againe, putting other dough or clay about it, for that which is not thus roasted, is hurtfull to be given, especially if it be (taken inwardly) carryed to ye bowells. It is likewise baked in an earthen vessell close stopped, & put into an oven, & of that the very middlemost is taken, that round about the outsyde of it being taken away. And being cut in pieces it is sod, the first water being cast away, & an other water powred upon it, till ye water becomme neither bitter, nor sharpe. And being cut in pieces, it is dryed in the shade, the pieces being thrust through with a little linnen thread, soe that ye parcells may not touch one another. And those pieces wee use for making of oyle, and wine, & vinegar of Squills. But for ye chaps which are in the feet, the inward part of the raw squill is applyed, being sod in oyle, or else dissolved with Rosin. Being sod with Acetum, it is a Cataplasme for such as are bitten of vipers. But mixing eight parts of roasted salt, beaten small to one part of roasted squill, wee give one spoonfull or twoe hereof to ye fasting for the softning of the belly; & being put into potions & aromaticall medicines, it is good for such in whom wee would move the urine, & for the Hydropicall, & for ye stomachicall in whome theire meate swimms above, and for ye Icterus, the Torminosi, for such as have been troubled with ye cough a long tyme, for the Asthmaticall, and such as cast up (bloud). The quantitie of three Oboli, taken as a Lohoc with Hony, is sufficient. It is sod also together with Hony, & is eaten for the same purposes, very much cooperating with concoction. It drives out also the slymie stuff that sticks in the belly. But being sod, & taken after ye like manner, it doth doe the like, yet the giving thereof must be forborne to such in whom there is any inward exulceration. And ye roasted squill being anointed on, is good for hanging warts, & the Perniones. But the seed [of it being beaten small, and taken in a drie figge, or Hony, & soe eaten] doth mollify the belly. It is also an Alexipharmacon, being hanged up whole before the doores.
203. PANKRATION. Scilla Pancratium or Pancratium maritimum

Pancratium, which somme also call (the little) Squill, is in ye roote like unto a great Bulbus, of a pale red or pale purple, of a bitter, and burning tast, the leaves like the lillies, but longer. It hath the like force & preparation as the squill hath, and the same dose (is to be taken thereof), being good for ye same griefs, but this is of a milder nature than the Squill. Whence also the roote of it being juiced, & mixed with flour of Ervum, & formed into Pastillos, is profitably given with Hydromel to ye Spleneticall & Hydropicall.

Capparis [somme call it Cynosbatos (as we would say, Dogges bush), some call it Capria, some call it the Apple of a Crow (μηλον κοορακος), some Ophioscorodon, some Ophiostaphylen (i.e. Serpents grape), some Thallian, some Petraea, some Holophyton, some Ioniten, some Oligocloron, some call it Aconitum, some Hippomanes, some Trichomanes. The Magi call it Potera, some Peuteron, some call it the heart of an Wolf, some Haloscorodon, some the Lilly, some Thlaspi. The Romans call it Sinapi Persicum, some Inturis, the Africans Herbiaeathum] is a prickly shrub, spred in a round compasse on ye ground, having prickles as ye Bush crooked like an hooke, the leaves round like those of the Malicottoon tree, a fruit like as of the Olive which opening doth first send forth a white flower, which falling off, there is found somme thing of ye fashion of a long suppositorie, which being opened hath little red graines, like those of the Pommegranat. It hath rootes, woodie, & great, & many, It doth grow alltogether in rough and barren places, & in Islandes, and in courts belonging to howses. Both stalke & fruit of it are preserved in salt to be eaten. But it doth disturbe the belly, and is naught for ye stomach, & causeth thirst, but being eaten sod, it is better for the stomach than the raw. The fruit thereof doth abate the spleen, the weight of twoe dragms of it being dranck with wine for fortie daies; it doth also exspell urine & the bloudy excrement. The same being dranck doth help the Sciatica, and the Palsie, and is good for ruptures and convulsions. It doth also drive out the Menstrua, & drawes away the Pituita from the head, & it doth assuage ye paine of the teeth, being sod in Acetum, and the mouth washed therewith. But the drie rinde of the roote, is good for the thinges before spoken, and doth also cleanse away everie old and filthie and hard ulcer. It is also layed with Barly meale upon such as are troubled with the spleen, & ye roote being bitten doth help a pained tooth, & being beaten small with vinegar it takes away the vitiligines albas. But ye leaves and the roote being beaten together doe dissolve hardnesses and strumas, and the juice being poured in doth kill ye wormes in the eares. But ye Affrick Caper, especially that which growes with ye people called Marmaridae, doth mightily cause inflations; that in Apulia, provokes to vomiting, but that from the Red Sea, and Arabia, is extreame sharpe, raysing pustles in the mouth, & eating up ye gummes to the bare bone, wherefore it is unprofitable to be eaten.

Lepidium, which somme call Gingidium, is a little herb well knowne, preserved in Brine with milke. But the facultie of the leaves is sharpe, exulcerating, wherefore it is a most singular plaister for the Sciatica, being beaten small with ye roote of Elycampane, & layed on for a quarter of an hower, & it is good also after ye same manner for ye splenicall & it doth take away Leprosies. But ye roote is thought to take way the paines of ye teeth, it being hanged about ye neck.

Ranunculus, which somme call Apium agreste, of this there are many kindes, but ye facultie is one, sharpe, & too much exulcerating. And one of them hath leaves like those of Coriander, yet broader, & sommewhat white, & fatt. The flower of an yellowish colour, & sommetymes of a purple; the stalk not thick, but the height, as it were of a Cubitt. It hath a little roote, bitter, having little fibrous stringes growing out, as that of Hellebore. It growes neere rivers or running waters. But the other kinde is more lanuginous & longer stalked, having more in-cuttings of the leaves, growing much in Sardinia, extreme sharp, which they also call Apium agreste. And there is a third, very small, of an hard savour, the flower like unto Gold, & a fowrth like unto this, the flower of the colour of milke. The leaves and the tender stalkes, being anointed on, have an exulcerating & incrusting power with paine. Whence they take away scabrous nayles, & Psoras, & deface marcks, as also they take away ye formicationes and the hanging warts, & ye Alopecias, being layed on but for a little tyme. But being sod, the decoction thereof luke warme, is a fomentation for those troubled with ye Perniones. And the roote being dryed & beaten small, & put to ye nosthrills, causeth sneezing. Being hanged to them, it easeth the paine of ye teeth, but it breaks them.

Anemone [somme call it wilde, somme black, somme purple, somme call it Anemion, somme Meconium, somme Tragoceros, somme Ges parine, somme Barbyle. Osthanes Berylius, in like sore Ornios Ceranios, Pythagoras calls it Atractylis, the Magi Cnicus agrestis, the Romas Orci tunica, ye Africans Chuffis] is twofold, one wilde, the other sative; & of ye sative somme beare flowers of a Phoenician colour, others of a pale, or milky, or purple colour. The leaves like to Coriander, but lesse jagged next ye ground. The little stalkes downie, thinne, upon the which are flowers as of Poppie, & ye heads between, black or azure, the roote according to the bignesse of ye Olive, or greater. But the wilde is alltogether greater then the Sative, & broader & harder in ye leaves, & it hath a longer head. The flower of a Phoenician colour, the little rootes small, & many, & there is one kinde which hath black leaves beeing ye sharper. But they have both of them a sharpe facultie, wherefore the juice of ye roote, being poured into the nosthrills doth avayle for ye purging of the head. But the roote being chewed, drawes out ye pituita. And being sod in Passum, & soe applyed, it cures the inflammations of the eyes, & it doth amend their cicatrices, & their hebetudines, & it doth cleanse the filthinesse of ulcers. The leaves & ye stalkes sod together with ptissana, & eaten, doth draw out milke. In a Pessum it provokes the menstrua. Being anointed on it takes away the Leprosies. But somme being not able to distinguish that which is called Argemone, & ye Papaver rhoeas, of which wee will speake when wee comme to discourse of Poppies, from the wilde Anenome, because of the likenesse of the colour of the flowers being of a Phaenician dye, they are deceaved calling Argemone Eupatorium. Yet the Phoenician colour of ye Argemone is sommewhat lesse deep, as also of the Rhoeas, and both it & Argemone doe flower later. And the Argemone doth yield a juice of a Saffron colour, & extreme sharpe to the tast, but ye Rhoeas a whiter juice, & sharpe. But both of them have little heads between, like the wilde Poppie, but that of Argemone is sommewhat broader at the toppe, & that of Rhoeas sommewhat narrower. But the Anemones doe neither give out any juice, neither have they an head or cup, but as it were the top of Asparagus, & they grow for ye most part in fields.

Argemone [somme call it Oenone, somme Anthemis, somme Homonoia, as we should say Concord, somme Flos campestris, the Romans call it Liburnia or Concordialis, somme call it Pergalia, the French call it Corna] is wholly like unto wilde Poppie, but it hath a leafe divided like to Anemone, a flower on ye stalk of the Phoenician colour, but an head like to Papauer Rhoeas, but sommewhat longer, & broade towards ye upper parts, a round roote, but it yields a juice of a saffron colour, sharpe. The leaves being applyed as a cataplasme, doe take away the Argema & the Nubeculas, & doe assuage inflammations; [Crateuas the Herballist sayth to ye same purpose, that this Herbe Argemone, being beaten together with swines grease doth dissolve the Strumae. It is good also for ye Vitiligines, it being drie & beaten with nitre, & brimstone that hath not felt ye fire, and sifted, but it doth cure those which use it in a Bath, being drie rubbed first. It is also effectuall against the Scab.

The other Argemone somme call Artemone, somme Arselam, somme Sarcocolla, the Romanes call it Artemonia, & it is like to wilde Poppie in the leaves. But it being beaten small when it is green, and soe applyed, hath power to cure cuts, and to assuage the inflammations of the eyes. It is good also for the Dysentericall, being dranck with water. It is also conglutinative of wounds, & good to be layd to inflammations. In like sort being applyed, it is curative of convulsiones & vellications. It is good also for such as are bitten of poysonous beasts being dranck with wine.

Of Anagallis [somme call it Punicea, somme Aeritis, somme Aigitis, somme Sauritis, the Magi call it Oculi Sanguis, others Chelidonion, the Romans Macia, the Hetruscans Masitipos, the French Sapana, the Dacians Cerceraphron. But ye common Anagallis, somme call Corchoros, somme Halicacabus, somme Zeliauros, the Magi Nycteritis, ye Aegyptians call it Micii, the Romans Meciato, the Aphricans Asirrhizi] there are twoe kindes, differing in the flower, for that which hath an azure flower is called the femall, but that of a Phoenician colour, is called the Male. They are little shrubs spreading upon the ground, having small leaves upon their four-cornered little stalks, somewhat round, comming neer to those of Helxine, & a round fruit. They both are of a mitigating power, & driving away of inflammations, and extracting of splinters or thornes (that were run into ye body), and of repressing the Nomas. But the juice of them being gargarized doth purge ye head of Pituita, and being powred into the Nosthrills it doth cease the paine of the teeth, if it be put in the contrary nosthrill to the grieved tooth. And with Attick Hony it doth mend the Argema & helpeth the dullnesse of the eyes. It is good also for such as are bitten of vipers, being dranck with wine, as also for ye Nephriticall, and Hepaticall, & (for ye Hydropicall), but somme say, that if that which hath the azure flower by applyed it doth stop the procidentia sedis, and that which hath the Phoenician flower doth provoke it.

Hedera [somme call it Cittaros, somme Cissaros, somme Chrysocarpos, somme Peotica, somme Corymbias, somme Cussion, (as we would say, Hederula), somme call it Dionysia, (quasi Bacchicei), somme Ithutherion, somme Persis, somme Cemos, somme Asplenos, the Romans Siluae mater, somme Hedera, the French Subites] hath many differences, according to the sort, but, of the chiefest kindes, three, for somme is white, somme black, & this Helix. The white therefore beares a white fruite, the black a black one, or anewst a saffron colour, which the vulgar sort also call Dionysium, but the Helix is both without fruit & hath white branches & thinne leaves, is full of corners, and red. But all Ivie is sharpe & binding, and touching of the sinewie part. But the flowers thereof being taken as much as one can take up of them with three fingers, & dranke in wine, are good for ye dysentericall, but it must be dranck twise a day. The same being beaten small, with Ceratum are good for Ambusta. The tender leaves being sod with Acetum, or the raw ones beaten together with bread heale the spleen. But the juice of the leaves & of the berries, with Irinum or hony or nitre, is powred into the nosthrills & soe is good for the old griefs of ye head. And ye head is moystened therewith with Acetum and Rosaceum: & with oyle it doth cure grieved & purulent eares. But the juice, and the clusters being dranck doe cause sterilitie, & being taken in too great a quantitie doe trouble the minde. But five Acini of the Corymbi being small beaten, & warmed with Rosaceum in a pommegranat coate, & dropt into ye contrarie eare in ye tooth ache, doe assuage ye paine. And the Corymbi doe make ye haire black. But the leaves are layed as a cataplasme to any sort of ulcers, & layd on as Cataplasmes doe also cure ambusta maligna, & sun burnings, being sod as is afore sayd. And the Corymbi being small beaten, & given as a Pessum doe move the menstrua, & being dranck ye weight of a dragme after womens cleansing, it hinders conception. And the Pediculus foliorum, being moystened with hony, & put into ye vulva, doth expell the menstrua, & the embrya. And the juice being dropt in, doth purge away the stincking smell in ye nosthrills, and their rotten ulcers. But the lachryma of Ivie doth take off haire, & being anointed on doth kill lice. And ye juice of the rootes being dranck with acetum doth helpe such as are bitten of ye Phalangium.

Chelidonia the greater [somme call it Paeonia, somme Crataea, somme Aoubios, somme Galucios, somme Pandionis radix, somme Philomedion, somme Othonion, ye Romanes Fabium, ye French Thona, the Aegyptians Mothoth, the Dacians Crustane] doth send out a stalke of the height of a cubit or more, slender, having branches full of leaves. The leaves are like those of Ranunculum, yet they of Chelidonia are tenderer, & sommewhat of a cerulean colour, and by everie leafe a flower, as ye Leucoion. But the juice is of a saffron colour, sharpe, biting, a little bitter, & of a strong smell. The roote at ye upper end is but one, but at ye lower syde manie, of a saffron colour. The fruit as of horned Poppie, slender, long, like a Conus, wherein are little seeds, greater yet than those of Poppie. The juice of this being mixed with Hony, and sod in a brasen vessell upon coales, is good for ye sharpening of the sight. But the leaves, and ye roote, & the fruit, are juiced at ye beginning of summer, which is dryed in ye shade, and is made into little balls. The roote being dranck with Anisum and white wine doth cure ye Ictericall, & ye Herpetas, being layd on with wine; and it doth assuage ye paine of ye teeth being chewed. It seems to be called Chelidonia because it springs out of the ground together with ye swallowes appearing, & doth wither with them departing. Somme have related that if any of ye swallows’ young ones be blinde, the dammes bringing this herbe, doe heale ye blindnesse of it.

Chelidonia minor, which somme have called sylvestre Triticum, is a little herb, full of little feet, without stalke (compast) with leaves like Ivie, yet much rounder, & smaller, and tender, and sommewhat fatt. It hath many small rootes out of the same, growing close together like wheat-cornes, but there are three or fowre of them that grow out long. It growes about waters & marishie places. It hath a sharpe faculties like unto Anemone, exulcerating the outmost part of the skinne. It takes away both the Psoras, and scabrous nayles. But ye rootes being juiced are good with hony to be put into the nosthrills for the purging of the head [as likewise the decoction thereof with Hony, being gargarized, doth powerfully purge ye head, & all thinges out of the Thorax.

Othonna, somme say, is the juice of ye Chelidonia major, somme of Galucium, somme say that it is the juice of the flowers of horned Poppie, somme that it is the mixture of the juices of Anagallis coerulea, and of Hyoscyamus, & of Poppie, & somme say that it is the juice of a certaine Troglodyticall herbe, which is called Othonna, & that it doth grow in that part of Arabia that lyes towards Egypt. It hath leaves like to Eruca, full of holes, as though they were worm-eaten, ill-favoured or mouldie, & but few leaves. It beares a saffron-coloured flower, broad leaved, whereupon somme did thinke it to be a kinde of Anemone. It is juiced to be put into eye medicines when there is need of cleansing; it is of a biting nature, & doing away all thinges whatsoever that darken the Pupillae. And somme say that there is a certaine kinde of humor that doth flow from the herbe, which washing, & severing the stones from it, they make into Trochiscks for ye same use. But somme say that it is an Aegyptian stone, growing in Thebais, of ye colour of brasse, of a small bignesse, biting the tast, with a certaine kinde of burning & binding.

Muris auriculae [Somme call it Myoton, somme Anthyllion, somme Myortochon, somme Myrtosplenon, the Romans Muris auricula, the Africans Labatholabat] which somme call Myosotis, sends out many stalkes out of one roote, being of sommewhat a reddish colour toward ye lower end, and hollow. The leaves sommewhat long & narrow, having ye back-bone of them standing out, of a blackish colour, by distances, growing up twoe and twoe, ending in a sharp point. There grow thinner little stalkes out of the winges, whereon are little flowers of a coerulean colour, small, as those of Anagallis. The roote is the thicknesse of a finger, having many hairie strings. Finally, the herbe is like to Scolopendrium, yet smoother & lesser. The roote of this being applyed doth heale the Aegilopas. Somme also call Alsine Myosotis.

Isatis sativa [some call it Augion, some Egne, the Magi Arusium, ye Romans Ruta] which ye Dyers use, hath a leafe like to Plantain, but fatter & blacker, & a stalke above twoe cubits high. The leaves being layed on are of force to dissolve any Oedema & tumors, and to conglutinate bloudy wounds, & to stop bleeding, & to cure Phagadaenas, and ye Herpetas and rotten ulcers.

Isatis sylvestris [somme call it Egne parva, the Romans Ruta minor] being like to ye above mentioned, but it hath greater leaves neere ye bignesse of those of lettuce, but more slender stalkes, having many slitts, sommewhat reddish, having upon the toppe many little pods hanging like tongues, in which is the seed, a flower of an yellowish colour, & thinne. It is of the like efficacie, to that spoken of before, & is also good for the spleneticall, being dranck, and also applyed. [It is to be understood that these descriptions of Isatis containe that which is erroneous, for the Sative beares both a yellowish flower, & slenderer, & much divided branches, & little Cods on the toppe, of ye fashion of tongues in which are the seeds, but there is contained in these a black seed like to Melanthium, & it beares a stalke above twoe cubits high, & not only above one cubit high. But the wilde sort beares blacker leaves than this, & a lower & thicker stalke, & a flower of a purple or azure colour, and the fruit in fashion of a crosse, sharpe, in which are ye seed, severed or distinguished in a manner by five little leaves apiece, & those equall.]

Telephium [somme call it Sempervivum sylvestre, and somme call this Portulaca sylvestris, the Romans call it Illecebra, ye Aegyptians Anoth, the Africans Atirtopuris]. This is like to Purcelane both in ye leaves, and ye stalke having twoe winges sticking upon everie knot of the leaves, from which six or seven small branches from ye root full of azure-coloured leaves, both thick, & tough, & fleshie, the flowers of an yellowish or whitish colour. It growes in the Spring tyme in vineyards & tillowed places. The leaves being layd on for six hours doe cure the alba vitiligo, but after this you must use barly meale, & being anointed on with vinegar in the sunne, they take away the Vitiligines, but after they are dryed, they must be wiped away.

In ye previous books, most loving Areius, we have discoursed of Spices, & of Ointments, & of Oyles, and of Trees & the of Fruits from them, of the Lacrymae, as also of Living Creatures & of Frumentacea, & of Potherbs, & of the sharpness-possessing Herbs, but in this being ye third book, we will set upon an account of Roots, and of Juices, & of Herbs, & of Seeds apt both for common use & for medicament.

Agaricum is said to be a root like unto Silphium, not thick on the outside, like as Silphium, but all is thin. But of it some is male, & other foemall, of which ye foemall doth excell having straight vaines within, but ye male is round and on all sides growing alike. But in taste both are alike, tasting sweet indeed at first, after by dissolving it grows bitter. But it grows in Agaria of the Sarmatian (Country). Some say it to be ye root of a tree, but some, that it grows in the stocks of trees of rottennesse, as the mushrumps. It grows also in Galatia in Asia, and Cilicia upon the Cedars, but brittle and weake. As for ye virtue of it, it is binding, warming, being good both for ye tormina, and crudities, & ruptures, and falls from on high. Ye quantity of two oboli is given with honeyed wine to ye unfeverish, but to ye feverish in melicrate & to ye Hepaticall, & Asthmatical, and ictericall & dysentericall, & nepriticall, & ye dysureticall, & womb stranglings, and sickly looks it is given ye weight of a dragm, but to ye phthysicall with Passum, and to ye Spleneticall with Oxymel, & to ye stomachicall as it is, being chewed and swallowed down, no moisture being poured upon it. In like sort also it is given acidum eructantibus. It stops also ye rejectiones sanguinis, ye weight of 3 oboli being taken with water. It is good also for ye griefs of ye hipps, & of ye joints, & of ye Epilepsy, an even quantity being taken with oxymel. It provokes also ye menstrua; & to women suffocated in ye womb, a like weight is profitably given. It dissolves also the shivering being given before ye ague fit. It purgeth also the belly, a dragm or 2 being drank with melicrate. It is also an Antidot of poysons being taken with ye weight of one dragm of diluted wine, & it doth help for ye stroakes, & bitings of serpents being drank to ye quantity of 3 oboli with wine; & finally it is good for all inward griefs, being given according to strength & age, to some with water, to others with wine, to others with Oxymel or Melicrate.

Rha [some call it Ria, the Romans Rha Ponticum], but some call it Reon, grows in the places beyond Bosphorus from whence also it is brought. Ye root is outwardly black like unto Centaurie the greater, yet lesse and redder within, without smell, loose, somewhat light, but that of it is ye best which is not worme-eaten & is slamie according to ye taste with a remiss binding, and being chewed (is) of a pale and somewhat like saffron in the colour. It is good being dranck for inflations, ye weakness of ye stomach, all manner of grief, convulsions, spleneticall, Hepaticall, Nephriticall, torminaticall, & ye griefs about ye bladder & ye Thorax, & ye extensions of ye hypochondria, & the affections about ye matrix, Sciaticas, Spittings of blood, Ashtmas, the Rickets, dysenteries, coeliacall affections, and courses of fevers, & ye bitings of poysnous beasts. But you shall give it like unto Agarick, for every grief the selfsame quantity & liquors, using with honeyed wine indeed to ye unfeverish but to ye feverish with melicrate, to ye phthysical with Passum, to ye Splenetical with oxymel, to ye stomachicall being chewed as it is, and swallowed down no moisture being supt with it. It takes away also blacks & blues, & ye Lichenas being anointed on with Acetum, and it dissipates all inveterate inflammations being applied with water, but the chiefest force of it is binding with some heating.

Gentiana [some call it Centaurea radix, some Aloe Gallica, some Narce, some Chironium, ye Trojans Aloitis, ye Romans Gentiana others Cicendia, and Cyminalis] seems indeed at first to be found by Gentius the king of ye Illyrians of whom also it took its surname; of which ye leaves indeed at the roote are like ye wallnut or plantain somewhat reddish, but those on ye middle stalke & especially those about ye top are a little jagged: ye stalk is empty smooth, ye thicknes of a finger, but the heighth two cubits, divided by joints, compast about with leaves at greater distances, but having a broade fruit in cups, light, chaffy, near to that of Sphondylium; a long root like to Aristolochia ye longer, thick, bitter. But it grows in the highest tops of mountains, & in shady & watry places. But ye roote hath a warming, binding faculty, & doth help those bitten by venemous beasts, being drank ye quantity of 2 dragms with pepper, and Rice and wine; but as much as a dragm of ye extracted juice is good for ye griefs of ye sides, & falls from on high, & ruptures, and convulsions; it doth also help ye Hepaticall & Stomachicall being dranck with water. But ye root being layed to as a Collyrie doth cast out ye Embrya. It is also a wound-herb being layed on as Lycium, & a medicine for undermining ulcers, & especially ye juice, & is an ointment of inflamed eyes. But the juice also is mixed instead of Meconium into ye sharper sort of collyries. The root is also cleansing of the vitiligines. But it is juiced, being bruised, & steeped in water for 5 days, afterward being sodden in the water until the roots appear above; and when ye water is cold, it is strained through a linen cloth, and is sod until it becomes honey-like in consistence, and it is layed up in an earthen vessell.

Aristolochia is so called because it is thought to help passing well women in child-bed. This sort is round and called ye femall, but it hath leaves like ivy, sweet smelling, with sharpness, somewhat round, tender, with many shoots on one root, but the branches are very long, ye flowers white, like unto little hats, but the red (part) in them is of a bad scent.
5. ARISTOLOCHIA MAKRA. Aristolochia parvifolia, A. sempervirens (Singer)

But the long Aristolochia is called ye male and Dactylitis [but some call it Melocarpum, some Teuxinon, ye Romans Herba Aristolochia] having leaves somewhat longer than the round, slender branches, ye bigness as it were of a span, a purple flower of a bad scent, which withering becomes like a pear: ye root indeed of the round (Aristolochia), is round like a turnip, but ye root of ye long kind hath ye thickness of a finger, being a span high, or more. But both of them are much a boxen colour, bitter according to taste, and poisonous.

But there is also a third long sort, which also is called Clematitis, having slender branches full with leaves somewhat long like unto Sempervivum ye lesser, ye flowers like to rue, ye roots longer, slender, having a thick bark, & of an aromaticall smell, being useful properly to ye unguentarians for the thickening of ointments. The round indeed is good for ye poisons, but the long for that of serpents & deadly poisons, being dranck ye quantity of one dragm with wine, and also applied, and being drank with pepper and myrrh it doth cast out all the remaining purgaments, & the menstrua and Embrya, and being applied also in a Pessum, it works ye same; and the round is effectual indeed for ye same things as before spoken of. And moreover also it helps ye Asthma, ye Ricket, ye rigor, ye Spleen, ruptures, convulsions, ye pains of ye side being drank with water: it draws out also Splinters, pricks, it takes off ye scales of ye bones, being applied; & with Iris and honey it doth emarginate the rotten, and cleanse foul ulcers and fills up the hollow. It cleanseth also ye gums, & ye teeth.

It is thought that Clematitis is good for ye same things. Yet it is less in strength than those formerly spoken of. [It is called by some Arariza, & Melecaprum, & Ephesia, and Lestitis, and Pyxionyx, & Dardanus, & Iontitis. The French call it Theximon, ye Aegyptians Sophoeth, ye Sicilians Chamaemelum, ye Italians terrae malum, ye Dacians Absinthium rusticum. It grows in mountainous, and warme, & level places or else in rough and rocky places. It is good for a grievous fever, but let him which hath ye fever take in ye smoke over ye coals, & the fever shall cease. It heals wounds being applied, and with ye seed of Dracunculus & honey it helps the Carcinomata in ye nosthrill, but being sodden with oil, or swines grease & anointed on, it cures ye rigors. And Crateuas the Herbalist, and Gallus have said ye same, & that it is good for ye goutie.]

Glycyrrhiza. [Some call it Pontica, some Glyceraton, some Symphyton, some Leontica, some Glycyphyton, some Scythion, some Adipson, some Sylithra, some Libyestaso, some Homoenomoea, some Peenthaomoeos, ye Latins Dulcis radix.] Grows much in Cappadocia, and Pontus. But it is a little shrub having branches two cubits high, about which ye leaves are thick, like Lentiscum, gross and clammy to him that touch them, but the flower is like to Hyacinth, but ye fruit of ye bigness of ye berries of ye plane tree, sharper, having cods as of ye lentel, red, small; ye roots long, of ye colour of box, like those of Gentian somewhat bitter, sweetish, which are juiced like as Lycium is. But ye juice is good for ye shapenesses of ye Arterie, but they must put it under ye tongue to let it melt. It is good likewise for ye burning of ye stomach & for ye griefs in ye thorax, & ye liver, & for ye scabies vesicae, and kidney griefs. Being dranck with Passum, & melted in ye mouth it is a quencher of thirst, & healer of wounds being anointed about, & being chewed it is good for ye stomach, & ye decoction of new roots is good for the same. But the dry root being beaten small is a fit sprinkling for ye Pterygia.

Centaurie the great, but some call it Narce [some Limnesion, some Marone some Pelethronion, Chironias, some Limnestis, ye Magi blood of Hercules, ye Romans Ferum seu Uvifera, seu Fel terrae], hath leaves like the wallnut, somewhat long, greene in colour, as those of ye Brassica, but ye circumference of them is cut in, as a saw, but it hath a stalk of 2 or of 3 cubits high as that of Lapathum, having many shoots from the roote, upon which are heads like to poppie, somewhat long in ye circumference; ye flower azure, but ye seed like Cnicus, being layed as it were in lanuginous flowers; the root is thick, sound, heavy, about 2 cubits full of juice, sharpe with a certaine astriction & sweetness, inclining to red. But it loves a fat soil, open to ye sun, & woods, and hillocks. But it abounds in Lycia, and in Peloponesus, in Helis, & Arcadia, and Messenia, & Pholoe, and Lycia, and about Smyrna. But ye roote is good for ruptures, convulsions, ye Pleuriticall, ye Dyspnoea, the old cough, blood spitters, for those without fevers with wine, but for ye feverish with water, ye weight of 2 dragms of ye root beaten small being given. As likewise for ye Tormina, and the griefs of ye Vulva. It expells also ye menstura, & ye Embrya, being shaved into ye form of a Collyrie, & applied to ye Vulva, the juice also doth do ye same things. It is also good for wounds, being beaten whilst moist, but being dry it is first macerated, & so beaten; it draws together & conglutinates, & it conjoins also flesh that is sodden, if one having beaten it seeth it together. But they in Lycia juicing it, use it for Lycium. It was also called Panacea since that it assuageth all griefs of inflammations and force of blows. It assuageth also ye strangurie in glisters, & those which have ye stone. But this is gathered when the sun is about to rise, in a clear season, when all things are full.

Centaurie the little, some call it Limnesion [some Helleborites, some Amaranton, the Magi ye blood of Hercules, the Romans Febrifuga, some herba multiradix, ye Dacians Tulbela] Which some do call Limnaion because it loves moist places, is an herb like unto Hypericum, or Origanum, having a stalk above a spanne, with corners; ye flowers like those of Lychnis of a faint Phoenician purple; ye leaves are small, very long, as of Rue, ye seed like wheat, ye root small, unprofitable, smooth. It being beaten when it is green, & applied is conglutinative of wounds, purgative of old ulcers, & brings them to a cicatrix. But being sodden, and swallowed down, it expells chollerick & grosse humors through ye belly. But the decoction thereof is a fit glister for the Ischiaticall, drawing out blood, & easing ye pain. Ye juice also is good for eye medicines cleansing away with Honey such things as darken the Pupilla, & in a Pessum it is extractive of ye menstrua & ye Embrya. But being drank it is equally good for griefs about ye sinews. The herb is juiced being gathered when it is great with seed, & macerated in water five days, afterward it is sodden till it stand above the water, afterward all being cooled, the herb being prest is strained through a linen cloth, & sod again to the consistence of honey. But some beating it green, full of seed, press out the juice & casting it into an earthen unglassed vessell; they stirr it about in the sun moving it always with a stick, & always scraping away that which hangs about, & mising it with ye moist juice, & covering it carefully at night for dew is forbidding of ye thickening of moist juices. As many therefore of dry roots or of herbes as are juiced, are prepared as Gentian by being sod. But as juices prest out of moist barks or rootes or herbes, are stirred about in ye sun as is aforesaid, soe also Thapsia & Mandragora, & unripe grapes & ye like unto these are juiced. But Lycium & wormwood & Hypocisthis & ye like unto these when sodden are stirred about in ye manner as is aforesaid. [Centaurie is good for inflammations & ye bruises of strokes, it helps women troubled with ye mother, & it eases ye pain of ye strangurie & those that have ye stone. But gather the herb in ye spring, at sun rising.]

White Chamaeleon [but some call it Chrysisceptrum, some Ixia, ye Romans Carduus varius, the Aegyptians Epher, but some Epthosephim] is called Ixia, because in some places viscous matter is found at the roots of it which also women use instead of mastick. It hath leaves like Silybum, or Carduus, but rougher, sharper & stronger than the black Chamaeleon. It hath not a stalk but out of ye midst puts out a prickle like that of the sea Urchin, or Cinara; ye flowers are of a purple colour like hairs, flying away in downe, but a seed, like to Cnicus; but ye root in fruitful hills is gross, but in ye mountains slenderer, white at ye bottom, somewhat aromatical, of a strong sweet savour. This being drank ye quantity of an Acetabulum expells ye broad worm. But it is taken in hard wine with ye decoction of Origanum, & to ye hydropicall also a dragm is given with wine, for it extenuates them: and ye decoction thereof is drank for ye Dysourie & being drank with wine it is a Theriaca, and being kneaded with Polenta and diluted with water & oil it kills both doggs, and swine, and mice.

Black Chamaeleon [some call it Pancarpon, some Ulophonum some Ixia, some Cynomachon, some Ocimoides, some Cnidium coccum, some Cynoxylon, ye Latines Carduus niger, some Vernilago, ye Egyptians Sobel], and that also in ye leaves is like unto Scolymus, yet it hath these lesser, & thinner, and distinguished with red. It sends out a stalk ye thickness of a finger, a span high, somewhat red having a tuft, and prickly flowers, small like ye Hyacinth, divers coloured. The root gross, black compact, & some tyme eaten into, but being cut is of a pale yellow, and being chewed is biting. It grows in dry & rocky grounds, and in sea-bordering places. Ye root being beaten small, mixed with a little coblers ink & Cedar oil, & swines grease, is of force to take off ye Psoras. It cleanseth away also ye Lichenas taking thereto brimstone & bitumen, and being sodden with acetum & anointed on. But ye mouth colluted with the decoction of it, assuageth toothach. And being wrapt about with like quantity of pepper and wax, it helps the pained teeth, and the teeth are preserved by it, it being sodden with acetum and affused. And it being conveyed warm through a quill to ye grieved tooth, it breaks it. It cleanseth away also ye vitiligines and sun burning, it is mixed also with ripening medicines and it heals the Phagedaenicall, and ye wilde ulcers being applied, destroying them. It is called Chamaeleon because of ye divers colours of ye leaves. For these are found according to ye difference of the place, the same green, or pale, or azure-coloured or red.

Crocodilium is like to black Chamaeleon, but it growes in woody places having a long roote light, somewhat broad of a sharp smell like as Nasturtium. But the root warmed in water, & drank is of force to drive out much blood through the nostrils. It is given also to ye splenetical manifestly helping them. [And the seed of it being round and double as a buckler, is of a diuretical faculty.]

Dipsacus [some call it Crocodilium, some Chamaeleon, some Onocardium, some ye bath of Venus, ye Romans ye Lippe of Venus, some ye thistle of Venus, ye Egyptians Seseneor, some Chir, some Meleta, ye Dacians Sciare]. It also is of the prickly plants, but it hath an high stalke full of prickles, & leaves compassing ye stalk, like lettuce, two at everie knot, tall, and they prickly, having as it were some prickly bladders upon ye middle of ye back both within and without, & hollow places about ye 2 (joining) parts of ye leaves, so that it gathers waters from the dews & showers, whence also it drew the name. But on ye top of ye stalk at every shoot one head like an hedgehog somewhat long and prickly. But being dried it shows white, but ye head being divided hath also small worms about ye middle of the pith. But ye root of this being sod with wine, & beaten, taking ye thickness of a Cerat, being put in healeth ye chaps, & fistuals in the seat. But the medicine must be layed up in a brasen box: they say also that it is a cure of ye Myrmeciae & hanging warts. But ye worms of ye heads being bound up in a purse, & hanged about the neck or the arme, are sayd to cure such as have quartanes.

Spina Alba [some calle it wild Cinara, some Donacitis, some Erysisceptron, ye Romans some Spina regia, some Carduus ramptarius] grows on mountains & woody places having leaves like to white Chamaeleon, but narrower & whiter, somewhat rough, prickly, a stalk above two cubits (high) ye thickness of ye great finger, or rather more, of a pale white, empty within, but on ye top of it there is an head, prickly like to ye urchin of ye Sea, but lesser & somewhat long, ye flowers purple, in which the seed, as of Cnicus, but rounder. The root of this being dranck is good for blood-spitters, for ye stomachical, ye coeliacal, & it provokes urine. And it is laid upon Oedemata and the decoction of this by collution is good for ye teethach, but the seed being drank doth help convulsed children & such as are serpent-bitten. But they say that it being worn as an amulet, drives away poisonous creatures of itself.

Spina Arabica [some call Acanthis, ye Romans Spina]. Seems like in nature to ye white Acantha, binding both for ye flux of women, and for casting up of blood, & for the other fluxes, the roote is alike effectual. [It grows in rough places.]

Scolymus [Some call it Ferula, some Pyracantha, ye Romans Strobylus, ye Egyptians Chnus] hath ye leaves of Chamaeleon, & of ye thorn called white, but blacker, & thicker. It puts out a long stalk, full of leaves, upon which is a prickly head, but ye root lies under black, thick, ye force whereof is good for such as have the arme pits & the rest of ye body of a rank smell, it being applied, or being sod in wine and drank, for it drives out much urine & that stinking; but the herb new come up, being sod as Asparagus serves instead of a potherb.

Poterium [But some call it Phrynion, some Acidotum.] But ye Ionians call it Neurada, is a great shrub having long branches, soft, flexible like a bridle, thin, like Tragacanth, ye leaves little, round. But ye whole shrub is compast with a thin woolly down, and is prickly, ye flowers small, white, but ye seed to him that tastes it of a sweet scent, & sharpe, serving to no use. But it grows in sandy and hillocky countries. The roots are under, being two or three cubits high, strong, sinewy, which being cut close to ye ground send out a tear like unto Gum. The roots being cut & smeared on doe conglutinate ye cuttings asunder of ye sinews & wounds, and the decoction of it being drank is good for ye griefs about ye sinews.

Acanthium hath leaves like to ye white thorn, but on ye top prickly excrescencies on which there is a down like a spiders web, which being gathered & made into one (or spun) becomes like silk. But ye roots & ye leaves of this being drank do help such as are troubled with ye crick.

Acantha or Herpacantha [but some call it Melamphyllon, some Pæderota, some Acanthus topiaria, some Mamolaria, some Craepula] grows in gardens, & in rocky, and in moist places; but it hath farre broader & longer leaves than lettuce, divided as those of Eruca, somewhat black, gross, smooth. A smooth stalk, of 2 cubits, ye thickness of a finger towards ye top, compast about by distances with certain longish little leaves, like little hives, of an hyacinth colour, from which growes out ye white seed somewhat long, yellowish, but the head like a Thyrsus. But ye roots are under, viscous, mouldy, reddish, long. Which being applied are good for ye Ambusti, and Luxations. But being drank they provoke urine, and stop the belly. They are good also for ye phthisicall, and ruptures, and convulsions.

Acantha Sylvestris, which ye Romans call Spina agrestis. There is also a wilde Acantha like to Carduus, prickly, shorter than that in ye garden & the Sative, but the root of this effects as many things as that before it.

Anonis, but some call it Ononis, ye branches a span long, and longer, shrubbie, full of joints, having hollow wings many round little heads, small little leaves, thin as of ye Lentel, coming near to those of rue or of ye Lotus, growing in meadows, somewhat rough, sweet smelling not smelling unseemly, but it is preserved in brine before ye putting out of ye prickles, & it is very pleasant, but ye branches have sharp prickles, like arrow-heads, strong, but a white root, warming, extenuating, of which ye bark being drank with wine moves ye skin and breaks ye stone, & emarginates ye scurf of ulcers, but being sodden in Posca & taken as a collution it assuageth ye pain of ye teeth: [the decoction also of this being drank is thought to cure ye Haemorrhoides.]

Leucacantha [but some call it Polygonatum, some Phyllon, others call it Ischias, ye Romans Gniacardus, the Thuscans alba spina]. The roote of this is like to Cyperus, bitter, strong which being chewed doth assuage ye toothache. But ye decoction of it being drank, three Cyathi with wine, doth help ye pleuritical of long continuance & ye Ischiaticall, ruptures, ye convulsed, and ye juice also of ye root being drank performs ye same effects.

Tragacantha ye root is broad and woody appearing above ye earth from which low strong branches, spreading very much & upon them many small, thin leaves, having prickles between; hidden in the leaves, white, strong, upright. There is also a Tragacanth teare cleaving together ye root being cut. Of which that is best which is transparent & smooth, & slender & cleane & somewhat sweet.
