But it hath a power like gum of stopping ye pores. But the use of it is for ye eye medicines & for coughs & for roughness about ye arterie, & for distillations, in a Lohoc with Honey. And it melts also being put under ye tongue. It is drank also ye quantity of a dragm being macerated in Passum, for ye pain of ye kidnies, & ye erosion of ye bladder, there being mixed with it Harts horn burned & washed, or a little of Allom Scissile.

Eryngium [which some call Erynge, some Eryneris, some Caryon, some Gorginium, some Hermium, some Origanum Chlunium, some Myracanthum, some Moly, ye Egyptians Crobysus, The Magi Siserti, ye Romans Capitulum Cardui, some Carterae, ye Dacians Sicupnoex, ye Spaniards Ciotocapeta, ye Africans Cherdan, herba montana, some Chida], is of ye prickly plants. Of which ye leaves in ye begining being laid up in brine, are eaten as potherbs; but they are broad, rough in ye round about, to ye taste aromaticall; but growing bigger they become prickly at ye most shootings-out of ye stalks, on which at the tops are little round heads, compast with very sharp prickles like a star, hard round about. Of which ye colour is foung green, or pale, or white, or sometimes azure: the root long, broad, black on ye outside, within white, the thickness of ye great finger or thumb, & it is sweet smelling & aromaticall, but it grows in fields and rough places. It hath a power of warming, & it expells ye urine & ye menstrua & being drank, dissolves ye tormina and ye inflations. It is good also with wine for ye hepaticall & those bitten by venemous beasts, & for such as have taken a deadly drink. But it is drank for ye most part with ye seed of Pastinaca ye quantity of one dragm. It is said also, that it being hanged about one, or anointed on him, it doth dissolve tubercula, but ye root of it being drank with Hydromel doth cure ye Opisthotonicall, & ye Epilepticall.

Aloe [but some call it Amphibion, some Eryngium, some Herminum, some Tragoceros, ye Romans Aloa, by ye Barbarians Aloe] hath a leaf near like Squill, thick, gross, somewhat broad in ye compass, broken or bowbacked behind, but on either part it hath ye leaves prickly by ye sides, appearing thinly, short. But it sends out a stalk like to Anthericum, but a white flower, & a seed like unto Asphodelus. All of it, is of a strong scent, & very bitter to ye taster, but it is but of one root having a root as a stake. It grows in India very much, gross, from whence also ye extracted juice is brought. It grows also in Arabia and Asia, & in certain sea-bordering places and Islands, as in Andros, not good for extracting juice but fitting for ye conglutinating of wounds, being laid on when it is beaten small. But there is a double kind of the juice, this indeed sandie, which seemeth to be ye subsistence of the purest, ye other like a liver. But chuse thou the pure & undeceitful, & unstonie, glittering, yellowish, brittle, liver-like, easily melted, excelling in bitterness. But the black and hard to be broken, refuse. But they counterfeit it with gum, which is convinced by ye taste, & ye bitterness, & ye strongness of ye smell, and by not falling in pieces even to the smallest crumb when squeezed by the fingers. Some also mix Acacia with it. But it hath a power of binding, of procuring sleep, of drying, of thickening of bodies, & of loosening of ye belly, & of cleansing of ye stomach being drank ye quantity of 2 spoonfulls with water cold, or warm milk; & with 3 oboli of water or ye quantity of 1 dragm in drink, it stops ye spitting of blood; & it cleanseth ye Icterus. And it being swallowed also with Rosin, or taken either with water, or sod honey it looseth ye belly, but ye quantity of 3 dragms doth fully purge. But being mixed with other purging medicines it makes them less hurtful to ye stomach. By being sprinkled on drie it conglutinates wounds, & brings to a cicatrix boils, & represseth them; but it properly healeth exulcerated genitalls, and conglutinates ye broken preputia of boys. It cures also the Condylomata, & ye chaps of ye seate being mixed with sweet wine. And it stops ye fluxes of blood that come from Haemorrhoids, & it brings to a cicatrix ye Pterygia, takes away blacks & blues, & ye Hypopia with Honey. And it assuageth Scabritias and the itchings of ye eye corners, and ye headache being anointed with acetum & Rosaceum, on ye forehead & the temples, & with wine it stays ye hair falling off, & with honey and wine it is good for ye tonsillae, as also the gums and all griefs in ye mouth. But it is roasted also for eye medicines in a cleane and red hot earthen vessell, being kept turned with a splatter until that it is roasted equally. It is washed also, ye sandy part of it being severed as unprofitable, & the fattest and smooth being taken.

Absinthium [ye Egyptians call it Somi, ye Romans Absinthium rusticum,] called Bathypicron is a known herb, but ye best of it is that which growes in Pontus, & Cappadocia on ye mountain that is called Taurus. But it hath a warming, binding digestive facultie, & of taking away ye cholerick matter sticking to ye stomach, & ye belly. It is also ureticall & keeps from surfetting, being drank beforehand. It is good also for inflations and ye paines of the belly & of ye stomach being drank wit Seseli or Celtick Nardus, & the dilutum or ye decoction of it doth heale want of appetite & ye ictericall, being taken every day to ye quantity of 3 Cyathi. It doth also expell ye menstrua, being both drank, & applied with honey. And it is good for the strangulations that come from mushrumps, being with Acetum. But with wine for (ye poison) of Ixia, & hemlock & ye bitings of ye shrew mouse and the dragon of ye sea. And for ye Synanchicall it is an unction with honey & nitre, & for ye Epinyctidae with water. But for Sugillata with honey & for dullness of sight, and likewise for mattering ears, and the vapour thereby of ye decoction for ye ear’s-pain, & for ye toothache. And being sodden with passum it is a cataplasme of very much pained eyes. It is also applied to ye Hypochondria, & ye liver, & a pained stomach, & that have suffered long, being beaten together with Cyprian Cerat, but for ye stomach with Rosaceum. It is good also for ye hydropicall, & ye Splenicall, there being mixed therewith figs and nitre & ye meale of Lolium. There is made of it also wine which is called Absinthite, but especially about Propontis and Thracia which they use in ye absence of a fever for ye purposes aforesaid, & otherwise also they drink to each other of it in ye summer, thinking it to be a causer of health. It seems also that being layd about into ye chests, to keep ye garments uneaten, & being anointed on with oil to forbid ye Culices to touch ye body. But ye ink wherewith we write macerated with ye macerating thereof doth keep writings uneaten of mice. It seems also that the juice doth do ye same work. But we doe not allow of it in potions, it being bad for ye stomach, & causing headache. Some counterfeit ye juice with Amurca sod.

Absinthium marinum [but some call it Sandonion, some Seriphum, ye Romans Santonicum] which some call Seriphion, very much grows in the mount Taurus about Cappadocia, & in Taphosiris of Egypt which ye Isiaci doe use instead of an olive branch. But ye herb is with thin branches like ye small Abrotonum abounding with little seeds, somewhat bitter, bad for ye stomach, of a strong smell, binding with some heating, which being sodden by itself, or with Rice, & taken with honey doth kill ye Ascaridae and round worms, looseing ye belly gently. But is of force to doe ye same things with Sapa or being sod together with Lenticula. Cattle feeding on it, grow very fat.

But there is also a third kind of wormwood growing in ye Galatia (or rather Gallia) very much, near ye Alpes, which they call by ye place’s name Santonicum, giving it this surname from its growing in ye country of Sardonis. Like unto wormwood but yet not so seedy, but somewhat bitter, and able to doe ye same things as ye Seriphian.

Abrotonum [but some call it Abutonon, some Absinthium, some Heraclion, some Cholopoeon, some Thelyphthorion, some Absinthiomenon, some Procampylon, the Magi nervi palmae, some Cynanchites, ye Romans Absinthium Ponticum, but some call it femineus frutex & some dulcis cubitus]. But the female of it is a treeish shrub, somewhat white, with leaves with little incuts as that of Seriphium about ye branches, having on ye top a Corymbus of a golden colour full of flowers, putting out in ye summer, of a sweet smell, with some strongness, bitter in taste. This seems to be the Sicilian.

The other called male is full of spriggs, with slender seeds, as wormwood. It grows much in Cappadocia, and Galatia which is in Asia, & in Hierapolis which is in Syria. The seed of these being sodden and beaten raw, being drank with water doth help ye Orthopnea, ruptures, convulsions, sciaticas, dysuries, the stoppage of ye menstrua, & being drank with wine it is an Antidot of deadly poisons. And with oil it is an ointment for those which have ye rigor. It drives away also serpents being strewed under, or suffumigated. And being drank with wine helps them which are bitten. But particularly it is good for ye strokes of ye Phalangii & Scorpions. It doth also help ye inflammations of ye eyes being applied with sodden Quince, or with bread. And it dissolves ye Pani being beaten small & sodden with barly meal. It is also mixed in ye composition of Oleum Irinum.

Hyssopus, [ye Latin Hyssopum, somme calle it Later, some Cassiala, ye Egyptians Pesalem] a knowne herb is of 2 sorts, for the one is mountainous, but ye other grows in gardens, but ye best is that which grows in Cilicia. It hath a power of extenuating and warming. But being sod with figgs & water, with honey also & Rue & soe drank it helps ye peripneumonicall, Asthmaticall, ye internall cough, ye Catarrh, ye Orthopnaea, it doth kill also ye wormes, & being licked in with honey it doth do the same. And also ye decoction of it being drank with oxymel it expells gross humours through ye belly. It is eaten also with green figs beaten small for ye subduction of ye belly, but it purgeth more forcibly, there being mixed with it Cardamom, or Iris, or Irio. It causeth also a good colour. It is daubed on also with a figg & nitre, for ye Spleen, & ye dropsie, but with wine for inflammations. It dissolveth also sugillations being applied with warm water, & with ye decoction of figgs it is an excellent gargarisme for ye Synanchicall. It assuageth also ye paine of ye teeth being sod with acetum & used as a Lotion. It dissolves also ye windyness about ye ears, being suffumigated.

Stoechas [but some call it Syncliopa, some Alcibiades, some Pancration, some Styphonia, ye Egyptians Suphlo, the Magi Oculus Pythonis, ye Romans Schiolebina] grows in the Islands of Galatia over against Messalia, called ye Stoechades, from whence also it had its name, is an herb with slender twiggs, having ye haire like Tyme, but yet longer leaved, & sharp in ye tast, & somewhat bitterish, but ye decoction of it as the Hyssop is good for ye griefs in ye thorax. It is mingled also profitably with Antidots.
32. ORIGANOS ERAKLEOTIKE. Origanum vulgare var. megastachyum (A.J.W.)

Origanum Heracleoticum, but some call it Conila, hath a leaf like to Hyssop, but a tuft not of a round fashion, but as it were divided, and on ye tops of ye spriggs, ye seed, not thick. But it is of a warming facultie, whence ye decoction of it being drank with wine is good for such as are bitten by poisonous beasts, but with Passum for such as have drank Cicuta or Meconium. But with Oxymel for such as have drank Gypsum or Ephemerum, but for ye convulsions, & ruptures, & dropises, it is eaten with a figge; but being drank dried, ye quantity of an Acetabulum with melicrate it expells black (humors) throug ye belly, & it moves ye menstrua, & cures coughs being licked in with Honey, & ye decoction of it in a bath is good for ye prurigo and ye Psorae & ye Icterus, but ye juice of it being green doth cure ye Tonsillae, and ye Uvulae, & ye Apthae, and being dropped in with oleum Irinum it purgeth through the nostril. But with milke it also assuageth ye ear-paines. And a vomitory medicine is made of it & onions, & Rhoos (that which is for sauce) all of them being sunned in the burning heat under ye dogge in a brass copper vessell for 40 days. But ye herb being strewed under, expells serpents.

But that which is called Onitis is whiter in the leaves, & more resembling Hyssop, & it hath the seed like berries hanging together. And it can effect ye same things as ye Heracleoticall, yet it is not altogether so effectual.

But the Origanum sylvestre, which some call Panaces Heraclion, others call it Cunila, of whom is also Nicander Colophonius, hath ye leaves indeed like Origanum, but ye rods a span high, thin, on which are tufts like Dill. But ye flowers white ye root thin, unuseful. But the leaves, and ye flowers being drank with wine, doe properly help such as are bitten of serpents.

Tragoriganum is a little shrub, like Origanum, or wild Serpyllum in ye leaves & ye small branches. Some of this is found more prosperous & broader leaved, glewy enough according to places: some again with small shoots & thin leaves, which some also call Prasium. But ye best is ye Cilician, & that in Co, & in Chios, & in Smyrna, and Crete. But all are warming, & ureticall & good for ye belly, the decoction being drank for they drive down melanclohy matter. They are profitable also for ye Splenicall being drank with Acetum & with wine for such as have drank Ixia; they expell also ye menstrua: it is given also in a Lohoc with honey for coughs, & peripneumonies. The potion of it is milde, whence it is given to such are are squeamish & bad-stomached & unsavoury belchers, and upon whom sea-sickness & a Nausea & ye burning of ye precordia followeth. It dissolves also Oedemata being applied with Polenta.

Pulegium [some call it Blechron, some Arsenicanthon, ye Romans Polium, ye Africans Apoleium, ye French Albolon, some Gallisopsis] is an herb well known, extenuating, warming, digesting. But being drank it expelleth ye menstrua, & ye seconds, & ye Embrya. It brings up also ye stuff out of ye lungs being drank with salt & honey, and it helps ye convulsed. It assuageth also ye nauseousness & gnawings of ye stomach being drank with Posca. It drives out also melancholy matter through ye belly; being drank also with wine it helps ye bitten of serpents. It doth restore also such as faint being applied with acetum to ye nostrils. It strengthens ye gums being drie pounded & burnt. But being anointed on with Polenta, it assuageth all inflammation. But by istelf it is good for ye gouty (being laid on) till the appearance of redness. But with Ceratum it doth extinguish ye Varos. It is good also for ye Splenicall, being applied with salt. But ye deoction thereof assuageth itching being washed on, & by way of Insession it is good for inflations, & ye hardnesses & ye conversions of ye womb. But some call it Blechon, because being tasted of at the flowering tyme by cattle they are filled with bleating.

Dictamnus, which some call Pulegium Sylvestre [but some Embactron, some Beluacos, some Artemedion, some Creticus, some Ephemeron, some Eldian, some Belotocos, some Dorcidium, some Elbuniuim, ye Romans Ustilago rustica] is a Cretian herb, sharp, smooth, like to Pulegium. But it hath leaves greater, & downy, & a kind of woolly adherence, but it bears neither flower nor seed, but it doeth all things that the sative Pulegium, but more forcibly by a great deal, for not only being drank but also being applied and suffumigated it expells the dead Embrya. And they say also that ye goats in Crete being shot, & having fed on the herb do cast out ye arrows. But also ye juice of it hath a cleansing faculty being anointed on or rubbed on with Polenta. But the herb being applied doth cure the pricks which are under the feet, or the rest of ye body. It is effectual also for ye pain of ye spleen, for it lessens it. But they gather it in ye summer, and the fall. Ye root of it doth warm such as tast it: it is also a birth hastener, & likewise ye juice of it being drank with wine helpeth ye bitten of serpents. Yea such is ye force of this herb, that even being smelt it drives away, & being touched it kills ye poisonous beasts. But ye juice of it, being dropt into a wound of iron, or ye bite of a poisonous beast, & beside ye dropping it on, it be taken in drink, it forthwith cures. [Having dried Dictamnus rub it in thine hands, & having made it like meale, & casting in a drop of wine, touch thy body. For it is good against all serpents. And first cleansing ulcers, & the rotten Nomae it then fills them up, and if one be pricked, lay this to him & straight thou shalt help him. But for ye Spleen, and the griefs of inflammations in hidden places apply it, having made it as meale. But dig up the herb in ye Spring, & in hot seasons, and in the Autumn.]
But that which is called Pseudodictamnus growes in many places, is like to that before it, but less sharp; but it does ye same things as ye Dictamnus, being not alike effectual.

There is also brought out of Crete another kind of Dictamnus, like in leaves to Sisymbrium, but greater in ye branches, on which is a flower like to wilde Origanum, black, soft. But ye smell of ye leaves most pleasant, between Sisymbrium, & Sage. It is effectual for all things as that before it, being somewhat less biting. It is mixed also with plasters & theriacall medicines.

Sage, which some call Elaphoboscon, some Sphagnon, some Ciosmin, some Phagnon, some Becion, ye Egyptians Apusi, the Romans, Cosalon, others Salvia, is a shrub somewhat long, much branched, having stalks 4-square, & somewhat white, but leaves like to Malicottoon, but yet longer & sharper & thicker, hidden by hairs, like as of outworn garments, whitish, exceeding odoriferous, poisonous, but it hath ye seed on ye top of the stalks, as of wild Horminum. But it grows in rough places. But ye decoction of the leaves, & of ye branches hath the power being drank, to move ye urine & ye menstrua, & to draw out ye Embrya, & to help ye strokes of ye Pastinaca marina. It dyes ye hair black also, & it is a wound-herb, & a blood-stancher, & a cleanser of ye wild ulcers. But ye decoction of ye leaves, and of the branches of them with wine being fomented on, assuageth ye itchings about ye privities. [Elelisphacon dissolves chilliness, ye cough & it is good being taken with Rosaceum, and Cerat for all ye bad ulcers, & being drank with white wine it cures ye paine of ye spleen, and ye Dysenterie. In like sort being given to drink, it cures blood-spitters & is available for all cleansings of a woman, but ye most wicked women making a Pessum of it, do apply it, & cast out ye Embrya.]

Hedyosmus, some call it Mentha [ye Romans Menta, some Nepeta, ye Egyptians Tis, others Pherthumerthrumonthu, some Perxo, some Macetho], is a known little herb, having a warming binding, drying faculty, whence ye juice of it being drank wit Acetum stops blood, & kills round worms, & it provokes lust; & two or three little spriggs being drank with ye juice of a sower pomegranate assuageth ye hickets, & vomitings, & choler; & being applied with Polenta it dissolves suppurations, & being laid to ye forehead it pacifyeth headaches, & assuageth ye swelling & extension of ye duggs, but with salt it is a cataplasme for ye dog-bitten, but ye juice with melicrate helpeth ye ear paines, but being applied to women before conjunction doth work inconception, & being rubbed on it makes smooth a rough tongue, & it keeps milk from curdling, the leaves being steeped in it. And finally it is good for ye stomach, & fitt for sauce.
But ye wilde mint, whic ye Romans call Mentastrum, is rougher in the leaves & altogether greater than Sisymbrium, but more poisnous in smell, and lesse fitting for use in health.

Calamintha, some of it is more mountainous, and it hath leaves like unto Ocimum, whitish, but spriggs and stalks angular, a puple flower. But ye other sort is like Pulegium, yet greater, whence some have called it Pulegium agreste, because also it is like it in ye smell, this the Romans call Nepeta. But ye 3rd sort is like wilde mint, longer in ye leaves, greater than ye aforesaid in ye stalk & branch, & is less effectual. But ye leaves of them all are strongly warming and sharp to him that tastes them: ye roots are unuseful. But it grows in plain fields, & in rough, and watry places. But being drank, or applied, it helps ye serpent-bitten, and the decoction being drank moves ye urine, it helps also ruptures, convulsions, Orthopnaeas, ye tormina, choler, & ye rigor, & being drank before hand with wine it is good against poisons, & it cleanseth away ye Icterus. And being beaten small, either sodden, or raw, and being drank with salt & honey, it kills both ye round worms, & ye Ascaridas; & being eaten, & ye whey of milk drank after, it helpeth such as have ye Elephantiasis; and the leaves beaten small and given in a Pessum doth kill ye Embrya, and expell ye menstrua; being either suffumigated, or strewed under foot it drives away serpents, & being sodden in wine, and applied, it makes white ye black scars, & taketh away blacks & blues. It is applied to ye Schiaticall for a metasyncriticall medicine, burning the outward skin, and ye juice being dropt in doth kill ye wormes in ye ears.

Thyme [but some call it white Thyme, some Cephalotus, some Epithumis, some Thyrsium, ye Romanes Thymus, ye Egyptians Stephane, ye Dacians Mozula] is knowne of all, is a little shrub full of branches compast about with many, & narrow little leaves having upon ye top little heads of a flower resembling purple, but it grows chiefly in rocky, and barren places. But it hath a faculty being drank with salt & Acetum to drive out fleagmie matter through ye belly. But ye decoction of it with honey doth help ye Orthopnoeici & ye asthmaticall, & it expells ye worms and ye menstrua, & ye Embrya, & ye Secondines, & it is also ureticall, but being mixed with honey, & taken as a Lohoc it makes matter out of ye Thorax, easy to come up. Being applied with acetum, it dissolves also new-come oedematas, it dissovles clotts of blood & takes away ye Thymos & hanging warts, & being applied with wine & Polenta it is good for ye Ischiaticall; being eaten with meat it avails for ye dull sighted. It is good instead of sauce for the use in health.

Thymbra, & this also is knowne, growing in barren and rough places, like to Thyme, but less and tendered, bearing a stalk full of flowers of a greenish colour. It can perform ye things as Thyme, being taken after ye like manner, & it is fitting for ye use in health. There is also a sative Satureia, of less vertue in everything than ye wilde, yet more useful for meat because it does not partake so much of sharpness.

Serpyllum [which some call Zygis sylvestris, some Polion, the Egyptians Meruopyos, ye Romans Serpyllum, some Cicer erraticum] this indeed is ye garden kinde, Sampsuchum-like in ye smell, & used for making crowns. It is so-called from its creeping, & because if any part of it touch ye earth, there it roots. It has leaves & small branches like Origanum yet whiter, yet led down from unmortared walls it becomes more growthful. The other is wilde which is also called Zygis, not creeping, but upright, sending out thin branches, full of spriggs, environed with leaves like unto Rue, yet they are narrow, & longer, and harder. The flower sharp to the taster, sweet to ye smell, ye roote unuseful. It grows on rocks, being stronger and hotter than ye garden kind, and more fitting for the medicinal use. For being drank it expells ye menstrua, & moves ye urine. It helps ye Tormina, Ruptures, convulsions, inflammations of ye liver, & for serpents, being both drank, & applied. And being sod with Acetum it assuageth ye paine of ye head, Rosaceum being mixed thereto, & it be moistened therewith, but especially it is good for lethargy & frenzy. But ye juice of it being drank, ye quantity of 4 dragms, with acetum, doth cease ye vomiting of blood.

Sampsuchum [but some call it Trifolium, some Amaracum, some Agathides, some Cnecion, some Acapnon, Pythagoras Thrambes, ye Egyptians Sopho, ye Armenians Myurum, ye Magi ye ass of ye priest, other genitura Isidis, ye Romans Majorana] ye best is the Cyzicenian, & ye Cyprian, but the Egyptian is ye second of this. But it is called of Cyzicenians, & of those in Sicily Amaracum. But it is an herb of many branches, creeping upon the earth, having rough & round leaves, like the thin-leaved Calaminth, very odoriferous and heating, and plaited into crowns But ye decoction thereof, being drank is good for such as begin to have ye dropsy, & ye dysureticall, & ye Torminicall. But the dry leaves being smeared on with Honey take away ye sugillata, and in a Pessum drive out ye menstrua, and for ye stroke of a scorpion they are anointed on with salt and Acetum, but for luxations they are layd on, being take with a Cerat, & likewise for Oedemata being taken with a Cerat, & it is anointed on with ye flour of Polenta for ye inflammations but it is mixed with Acopicall, & mollifying medcines, for warmths sake.
°48. MELILOTOS. Trifolium officinale or T. italicum or Trigonella graeca

Melilot, [also called Zoodotion and Ortamon, the Magi Thermuthin, the Egyptians Haemith, the Romans Sertula or Trypatium] ye best is ye Attick, and that which growes in Chalcedon, like saffron, & of a sweet scent. It grows also in Campania about Nola, inclining to yellow, & remisse concerning ye sweet smell. It hath ye power of binding, & of mollifying all inflammation, especially of that about the eyes, the matrix, & ye fundament, and ye stones, being sodden with Passum, and applied. And sometimes ye roasted yoke of an egg being mingled, of ye meal of faenigraec or of hemp seed, or of wheat flour, or of ye heads of poppies, or of Intybus. It doth also cure ye meliceride new come, by itself in water; & ye Achores being anointed on with Chian earth, & wine, or Galls. And ye paine of ye stomach sodden with wine, or raw with some of ye things beforespoken, & being juiced raw, & droped in with Passum, it easeth ear pains, & being let fall on gently with acetum & Rosaceum it assuageth ye headache.

Marum, or Hysobrium [but some call it Origanis] is a known herb full of spriggs, like in ye flower to Origanum, but ye leaves of this, are by much whiter, & ye flower sweeter. It hath a force like to Sisymbrium, somewhat binding, & gently heating. Whence also being applied it stops ye Nomae, & it is mixed amongst hot ingredients of compound ointments. It grows in abundance, both by Magnesia and by Tralles.

Acinus, or Aconus [but some call it Basilicum sylvestre ye Romans Ocimastrum] is an herb of a small stalk, used in making crowns, like to Ocimum, but rougher, & of a sweet scent, but by some also it is sown in gardens, being drank it stops ye belly & ye menstrua, and being applied it heals both ye Pani & Erysipelata.
°51. BAKCHARIS. Conyza squarrosa or Gnaphalium sanguineum

Baccharis is an herb of many stalks of a sweet scent & of use to make crowns, of which ye leaves are sharp, having ye bigness between ye violet & Verbascum, ye stalk cornery, ye heighth of a cubit somewhat sharp, having suckers; but ye flowers of a purple colour, whitish, sweet-smelling, but ye roots like to those of black Veratrum like in smell to Cinnamon. But it loves rough, & dry places. The roote of this being sodden in water doth help convulsions, ruptures, falls from on high, hard breathing, ye cough inveterate, & ye Dysurie. It expells also ye menstrua, & is profitably given with wine to ye serpent-bitten. But one of ye tender roots being applied as a Pessum draws out ye Embryo, & ye decoction of it is good by way of Insession for women in child-bed. And it is good to be put into Diapasmata having a very fragrant smell. But ye leaves being binding, applied doe help headaches, ye inflammation of ye eyes, and the Aegilops beginning, & duggs inflamed upon child-bearing & ye Erysipelata. Ye smell is soporiferous.
52. PEGANON TO KEPAION. Ruta graveolens. Rue

Rue mountainous [some call it Rhyten montana, ye Romans Ruta montana, Ruta hortense, ye Egyptians Epnubu, ye Syrians Harmala, some Besasa, ye Africans Churma] and wild is sharper than tame or garden Rue, and unfit for eating. And of ye garden kinde, that is fittest for eating which grows near fig trees. Both of them are caustical, warming, exulcerating, ureticall, bringing out ye menstrua, & being eaten or drank do bind ye belly; & ye quantity of an Acetabulum of ye seed being drank in wine, is an Antidot of deadly medicines. And being eaten beforehand ye leaves by themselves, or with wallnuts, or with dry figs, it makes poisons ineffectuall, & in like sort being taken it is good against serpent-bitings, & either eaten, or drank it extinguisheth geniture. But being sodden with Dill dried, & drank, it ceaseth ye Tormina. It is good also for ye paine of ye sides of ye breast, hard breathing, coughs, ye lungs inflammation, ye griefs of ye hips, of ye joints, periodical rigors, being drank as is aforesaid; & for ye inflations of ye Colus, & of ye Vulva, & of ye rectum intestinum, being sodden with oil, & given as a glister. It cures also stranglings of ye womb, being laid on beaten small, with honey, from ye genital to ye seat. But being boiled in oil, & drank it expels ye worms: it is also applied with honey for ye griefs of ye joints, but with figs for under-skin dropsies, & being drank also it helps such as these, & being sodden in wine to halfs and rubbed on. It is also a sight-quickner being eaten raw or pickled, & being applied with Polenta it assuageth ye paines in the eyes. But with Rosaceum, and Acetum it helps ye headaches, & stops bloody fluxes, those out of ye nostrils, being beaten small, & applied. It helps also ye inflammations of ye stones, being applied with ye leaves of Bay, & the Exanthemata with Myrtle Cerat. Being rubbed on round about with wine, & pepper, & nitre, it heals ye white vitiligo, & being applied with ye same, it takes away ye Thymos & ye Myrmecias, & it is good for ye Lichenae being laid on with honey, & Allom. But ye juice is good for ear griefs, being warmed in a pomegranate rinde, & dropped in; & being anointed on with ye juice of fennel & honey it helps ye dullness of sight; & being anointed on with Acetum, & Cerussa, and Rosaceum, it cures both ye Erysipelata, & ye Herpetas & ye Achoras. And being chewed, it ceaseth ye rank smells which come of garlick & onions.

But ye hilly rue being much eaten of kills, but being gathered about flowering time for picklings it makes red, & puffs up ye skin with an itching & an extreme inflammation. But they ought having first anointed ye face & the hands, so to gather it. And they say ye juice being sprinkled on chicken, keeps off ye cats. But they say that which grows in Macedonia by the river Haliacmon, being eaten, doth kill, but that place is mountainous and full of vipers, but ye seed of it being drank is good for the griefs within; & it is mixed profitably with Antidots & having parched ye seed of it, give it to drink for 7 days to him that sheds his water, & it shall cease. Ye root of it is called mountain Moly.

The wild Rue therefore is like ye sative, & being drank it is good for ye Epilepticall, and ischiaticall. It moves also ye menstrua, but kills ye Embrya. But it is sharper than ye Sative & more effectual in operation. But you must not eat the wilde, because it is hurtfull [Ruta sylvestris, some call Hypericon, some Androsaemon, some Corion, some Chamepitys, ye Romans Hederalis, some Sentinalis, ye Africans Churma Semmaked].

But some call Ruta Sylvestris, both that which in Cappadocia, & that which in Galatia near Asia, is called Moly, but it is a shrub bringing out many shoots from one root having much longer, & tenderer leaves than ye other Rue, of a strong scent, a white flower, & on ye top little heads, a little greater than ye Sative Rue, consisting especially of three parts, in which is a three-cornered seed, of a faint yellow, extremely bitter to the taste, of which also there is use. But ye seed is ripe in ye Autumn being good for the dullness of the sight, being beaten small with honey, & wine & ye gall of Henns, & Saffron, & ye juice of Fennill. But some call it Harmala, ye Syrians Besasa [ye Egyptians Epnubu, Africans Churwa], ye Cappadocians Moly, because in some part it keeps the likeness to Moly, being black in ye root & white in ye flower, but it grows on hilly, & fertile places.

Moly [but some call it Leucoion sylvestre] hath leaves like unto grass, but broader being on ye ground, flowers like to white violets, of a milky colour, yet less in bigness than those of the violet, but a white stalk of four cubits, on ye top stands something like garlick. The root is small of ye shape of a skallion, this is passing good for ye openings of ye womb, being beaten with flour of Lolium, & put up as a Pessum. [The herb Moly being cut up by ye root, and borne about the body, is good against poisnings and bewitchings.]
The SPHAERITIS figure is described in similar terms in the Codex, but it represents a plant like a Centaurea.
°55. PANAKES HERAKLEION. Ferula Opopanax or Opopoanax hispidus

Panances Heracleum of which Opoponax is gathered, grows in abundance in Boeotia & in Psophis of Arcadia. Insomuch that it is carefully tillowed in gardens for ye profit that comes of ye juice: but it hath rough leaves lying on ye ground, green, coming very near to those of ye fig, being jagged five-fold in ye circumference; but a very high stalk, as of a ferula, having a white down & smaller leaves about it, but a tuft on the top long, as of Dill, but a yellowish flower; ye seed smelling sweet & burning; many white strong smelling roots from one beginning, having the bark thick, somewhat bitter in taste. It grows in Cyrene of Lybia, and in Macedonia. But the root is juiced, being cut, when ye stalks are but new putting out. It sends out a white juice, which being dried looks of a saffron colour on the outside. But they take the liquor in leaves, having laid them beforehand on ye ground digged hollow, & they take them being dried. They juice also ye stalk, cutting it at harvest time, taking the liquor in like sort. But of ye roots ye stretched-out and white & dry & uneaten, and hot in the taste & aromaticall, are the best. That seed is good, which comes from ye middle of ye stalk, for that which comes of ye Spriggs is less nourished. But of the juice that doth excell which is most bitter to ye taste, within indeed white & somewhat red, but without of a saffron colour, smooth, fat, brittle, fit for use, melting quickly, of a strong scent; but ye black & ye soft is naught, for it is adulterated with Amoniacum or wax: it is tried by being rubbed in water with ye fingers, for ye uncounterfeited dissolves and becomes like milk. But ye faculty of it is warming, mollifying, attenuating, whence it is good for ye periods of agues, & rigors, convulsions, ruptures, ye pains of ye side, coughs, ye tormina, stranguries, ye scabies in vesica, being drank with melicrate or wine: & it moves ye menstrua, & kills the Embryo, & it scatters ye inflations & ye hardness which are in ye womb being dissolved with honey; and it is also an ointment of ye Ischias, it is also mixed with acopa, and head-medicines, & it also breaks carbuncles round about & being anointed on with Uva passa it is good for ye goutie, and it assuageth also ye pains of ye teeth being put into the concavities of them, it is also a sight-quickener of ye eyes being anointed on. And mixed with pitch it is an excellent plaster for such as are bitten of mad dogs, and ye root being shaven & laid to ye Vulva draws out ye Embryo. And it is effectual for old ulcers, & it covers with flesh ye bared places of ye bones, being applied beaten small, & anointed on with honey. But the seed of it being taken with wormwood moves ye menstrua, and with Aristolochia it is good for ye bitings of poisonous beasts & being drank with wine for ye stranglings of ye womb.

Panaces Aesculapii sends out of ye earth a thin stalk of a cubits length, distinguished by knots, about which are ye leaves like unto Fennill, yet greater & rougher, odoriferous, & upon ye top a tuft on which are ye flowers of a golden colour, sharp, odoriferous: ye root is but small. The flower and the seed have a power fitting for ulcers, & Pani, & Phagedaena, being laid on, beaten small with honey, & for Serpents being drank with wine, and anointed on with oil. And some call Panaces wild Origanum, some again call it Cunila, of which it is spoken in ye things said of Origanum.

Panaces Chironion chiefly grows on ye mountain Pelius, it hath leaves like to Amaracus, flowers gold-like, a slender & not deep root but sharp to ye taster. But ye root being drank hath a force against serpents poison, & ye hairs being applied are effectual for ye same purposes.

Ligusticum [some call it Panacea, others Panaces,] grows most plentifully in Liguria, from whence also it had ye name, on that which is called Apennine, an hill that is bordering to ye Alps. But ye inhabitants call it Panaces not without reason, since that ye root & ye stalk is like to the Heracleoticall Panaces, & ye force of them is alike. It grows on the highest & roughest, and shadowy mountains, but especially by places digged in ye earth. And it bears a thin stalk like to Dill, knottie, about which are leaves like to those of Melilot, yet more tender & odoriferous, but those near ye top stalk are slenderer & more cut in, but on ye top is a tuft on which also is ye seed, black, sound, somewhat long, near to that of Fennill, but sharp & aromaticall to ye taster. The root is white like to ye Heracleoticall Panaces, odoriferous. But force of ye seed, & of ye roote is heating, digestive, being good for the within griefs, & digestions, and Oedemata, and inflations, & especially those about ye stomach, & for ye strokes of poisonous beasts: being drank it moves both ye urine, & ye menstrua, & ye root also being applied doth do the same, but the root & ye seed is profitably mixed with both Oxypora, & digestive medicines. But it is excellent good for ye Stomach, whence also ye Inhabitants use it instead of Pepper, mixing it with their sauces. It is counterfeited by a certain seed like it, which thou shalt discern by ye taste, for it is bitter. But some counterfeit it, mixing together with it ye seed of Fennill, or Seseli.

Pastinaca sylvestris [some call it Cerascomen, ye Romans Carota, some Patinaca rustica, ye Egyptians Babiburu, ye Africans Sicham] hath leaves like Gingidium, but broader, & somewhat bitter, but an upright stalk, rough, having a tuft, near like to Dill, on which are white flowers, & in ye midst something small of a purple colour, & as it were of a saffron, but ye root ye thickness of a finger, a span long, sweet-smelling, edible being sodden. Of this ye seed being drank or put up as a pessum doth move ye menstrua & it is good for ye dysureticall & hydropicall & pleuriticall in potions, & for ye bitings and strokes of venemous beasts; they say also, that they which take it before hand shall take no wrong of wilde beasts. It cooperates also to conception, but ye root, & it also being ureticall, both provoketh conjunction, and being applied; but the leaves being beaten small with honey, & laid on, doth cleanse ulcers Phagedanicall.
But ye garden Pastinaca being fitter to be eaten is good for ye same purposes working more weakly.

Seseli the Massiliense [but some call it Sphagnon] hath leaves like unto Fennill, yet thicker and it hath a stalk fuller of branches, it hath also a tuft like to Dill, in which is a seed somewhat long, cornery, soon sharp being eaten, ye root long, of a sweet scent; ye seed & the root also have a faculty of warming; being drank they cure ye strangurie, & ye Orthopnaea, they are good also for ureticall stranglings, & ye Epilepticall, & they move ye menstrua, & ye Embryo, & they are effectual for all griefs within, & cure old coughs; & ye seed being drank with wine is helping of digestion and dissolving of tormina. It is good also for ye febres Epiales, & it is drank with pepper and wine for the rigors in travailings. It is given also to goats and other cattle as a drink hastening delivery.

But ye Sesilis called Aethiopicall [ye Egyptians call Cyonophricen] hath leaves like to Ivie, yet less & somewhat long, answerable to those of Periclymenom,. It is a great shrub having sions of about 2 cubits, on which branches 18 inches long, but the little heads as of Dill, but ye seed black, thick as of wheat, yet sharper, & more odoriferous than ye Massaleoticall, very sweet. It performs ye like effects.
62. SESELI PELOPONNESIAKON. Angelica sylvestris or Myrrhis odorata

But that which grows in Peloponnesus, hath leaves like to Cicuta, but broader and thicker, a stalk greater than ye Massiliense, like a Ferula, on ye top of this a broad tuft, in this a broader seed, & of a sweet scent, & more fleshy. It hath the selfsame force, it grows in rough, & moist & hillocky places: it grows also in Ida.

Tordylium [some call it Tordylum] but some call it Creticum, grows on ye hill Amanus by Cilicia. It is a little herb full of shoots, having a round little seed, double, like little bucklers, somewhat sharp, and aromaticall, being drank for ye Dysurie, & the expelling of ye menstrua, but ye juice of ye stalk & of the seed yet being green, being drank in ten days with Passum as much as 3 oboli makes sound ye nephriticall. But ye root is of use drawing up also that which stops ye breast being licked in with honey.

Sison is a little seed growing in Syria, like unto Apium, somewhat long, black, of a burning taste, being drank for ye spleen, & ye dysurie, & ye retention of the menstrua, but ye inhabitants use it for a sauce taking it with Cucurbita sodden with vinegar. It hath as it were many little grains on ye tops.

Anisum [some call it Sion, ye Romans Anisum] hath generally a warming, drying, sweet breath-making, paine easing, dissolving, ureticall, discussing faculty. Being drank it takes away thirst from ye hydropicall. It is good also both for outcasting ye poison of venemous beasts & for inflations, & it stops ye belly & ye white flux & draws down milk & incites conjunctions & being suffited to ye nostrils, it quieteth ye headach, & being beaten small, & droped in with Rosaceum it heals the chaps of ye ears. But ye best of it is ye new and fuller, & not branny, strong in ye scent. But ye Creticall claims ye first place, & the next ye Egyptian.

Carum is a little seed well-known, ureticall, warming, good for ye stomach, pleasant to ye mouth, digestive mixed profitably in the Antidots & Oxypota, being much alike in nature to Anisum, ye root also being sodden, is edible as Pastinaca.

Of Anethum [which is eaten, some call Polgidos, some Anicetum, ye Magi genitura Cynocephali, likewise crines Cynocephali, some genitura Mercurii, ye Egyptians Arachu, ye Roman Anethum, ye Africans Sicciria, ye Dacians Poltum] ye decoction of ye dried haire & of ye seed being drank, draws down milk & assuageth the tormina and inflations, & stops both ye belly & ye vomitings that float on ye top of ye stomach; it moves urine, it stayeth ye hickets, & being drank too long together it both dulls the sight & extinguisheth geniture, but ye decoction thereof is good by way of Insession for women troubled with womb-griefs, but the seed being burnt, & sprinkled on takes away ye Condylomata.

Cumin, ye Sative is of a good tast, & of this especially ye Aethiopicall which Hippocrates called ye Kingly, next ye Egyptian, & then the rest. It grows in Galatia, & in Asia, Cilicia, & ye region of Tarentum, & in many other places. It is hot, binding, drying, being good for ye tormina and inflations being given as a glister, sodden with oil, or applied with barley meal. It is given also to ye Orthopnoicall with Posca, & to ye bitten of venemous beasts with wine. And it helps ye inflammations of ye stones being applied with uva passa, & bean flour, or Ceratum. It stops also ye womanish flux & bleedings of ye nostrils, being laid on beaten small with Acetum. It changeth also ye skin into a paler colour being either drank, or smeared on.

Cuminum sylvestre [ye Romans call it Cuminum agreste some Cuminum silvaticum]. Grows ye most, & ye effectualest in Lycia, & Galatia of Asia, & in Carthago of Spain. It is a little shrub having a stalk of a span long, thin, on which are 4 or 5 little leaves as it were sawn about, of ye incutting as Gingidium. It hath on ye top 5 or 6 little round, soft heads, in which is ye huskie seed, to ye taster sharper than ye Sative. It grows in hillocky places. But ye seed is drank with water for ye tormina & inflations. And with vinegar it assuageth ye hicketts. And with wine for ye poison of venemous beasts and ye moisture of ye stomach. It takes away also blacks & blues, being chewed, & applied with honey and Uva passa. And it cures ye inflammations of ye stones, being applied with ye same.

There is also another kind of wild Cumin like to the Sative, but out of every flower it sends out little horns lifted up, in which is ye seed like to Melanthium. This being drank is an excellent remedy for such as are bitten of serpents. It helps also ye troubled with ye strangury, & ye stone & such as piss dropps of blood. But let them drink upon it ye seed of Apium boiled.

Ammi [ye Romans call it Ammium Alexandrinum] some also call this Aethiopicum, some Regium Cuminum. But some have said that ye Aethiopicall Cumin is of one nature & ye Ammi of another. is a known little seed, by much less than Cumin, & like Origanum to ye taste. But choose that which is pure & not branny. And this also hath a warming, burning, & drying faculty, being good for ye tormina, dysuries, & ye bitten of venemous beasts being drank with wine; it doth also move ye menstrua. It is mixed also with corroding medicines made of Cantharides to resist the dysuries ensuing, & being applied with Honey it takes away ye sugillata. Being either drank or smeared on, it changeth ye colour into a paler, & being suffited with uva passa or Rosin it cleanseth ye Vulva.

Corion or Coriannum [ye Egyptians call Ochion, ye Africans Goid], is well known, having a faculty of cooling, whence being applied with bread of Polenta it heals ye Erysipelata & creeping ulcers, but with honey & uva passa it cures ye Epinyctidae. ye inflammations of ye stones & Carbuncles, & with bruised beans dissolves ye Strumas & ye Panos. But ye seed being drank a little with Passum expells wormes, and it is engendring of seed. But being taken too much it distrubs ye understanding dangerously, whence men ought to avoid the overmuch, & too often use of it. But ye juice being anointed on with Cerussa, or Lithargyrum, & Acetum and Rosaceum doth mend the fierie inflammations on the outside of ye skin.

Hieracium ye great [some call Sonchiten, ye Romans Lampuca, ye Africans Sithileas] produceth a rough stalk, somewhat red, prickly, hollow. It hath leaves thinly jagged by distances like in ye circumference to Sonchus, yellowish flowers in somewhat long, little heads. It hath a cooling & indifferent gently binding faculty, whence it is good for a burning stomach being applied, and inflammations. But ye juice being supt in assuageth ye gnawing of ye stomach, but ye herb with ye root being applied doth help ye scorpion-bitten.

Hieracium ye little [some call this also Sonchiten, some Entimon agrion, ye Romans Intubus agrestis, the Africans Sithilesade] & this also hath leaves jagged round about by distances. It sends out little tender, and green stalks, on which are yellow flowers describing a circle, & this also hath the same force to ye afore spoken.

Garden Apium, ye herb of it is good for ye things also that Coriander is, & for ye inflammations of ye eyes being applied with bread or ye flour of Polenta, & it assuageth ye burning of ye stomach; & it slacks breasts swollen with clotted milk, & it moves urine being eaten sodden, or raw; and the decoction of it & of ye roots, being drank resisteth poisonous medicines, moving vomitings, & it stops ye belly, but the seed is more ureticall, helping also ye bitten by poisonous beasts & those who have drunk Lithargyrum, & it is also a breaker of wind. It is mixed also profitably with pain-easing, & theriacall, & cough medicines.
Heleioselinum [some call it campestre, some water smallage, ye Romans Apium rusticum] growing in the watery places is greater than ye sative smallage & it effects as many things as ye garden kind.

Oreoselinon [some call Petroselinum sylvestre, ye Romans Apium montanum, ye Egyptians Anonim] is a stalk of a span high, one from a slender root but about it are little branches, & little heads like unto Cicuta, yet a great deal slenderer, on which is ye seed somewhat long, sharp thin, of a sweet smell like unto Cumin. But it grows in rockie, & mountainous places. Both ye seed & ye root hath an ureticall faculty being drank in wine it also expells ye menstrua. And it is mixed with Antidots and diureticall & heating medicines. But we must not be deceived thinking that Oreoselinon is that which grows on rocks, for Petroselinum is another thing.

Apium, that which also is called Petroselinum, this grows in Macedonia, on steep places, having a seed like to Ammi, but of a sweeter, sharpe and aromaticall scent, ureticall & expelling ye menstrua. It is good also for ye inflations, and ye tormina of ye stomach, & of ye Colus, as also for ye griefs of ye side, & of ye kidnies, & of ye bladder being taken in drink. It is also mixed with ureticall Antidots.

Hipposelinon some call Grielon, some Agrioselinon, or Smyrnium [ye Romans Olusatrum], being of another kind from that which is properly called Smyrnium, as forthwith we will declare: but it is greater, and whiter than ye garden Selinum, ye stalk hollow, high tender as it were having lines, ye leaves broader, enclining to a purple, over which is ye hair as of Libanotis, full of flowers, standing together in clusters before it have done blowing; ye seed black, somewhat long, solid, sharpe, aromaticall. The root sweet of scent, white, pleasing ye taste, not thick. It grows in shady place, & near marshes. It is used for a potherb as Selinon, & ye root is eaten sodden, or raw, & the leaves & the stalks are eaten sodden. They are drest either by themselves or with fish, and raw they are preserved in brine. But ye seed being drank in honeyed wine hath ye power of expelling ye menstrua, and it doth heat such as are taken with Rigors, being drank or anointed on, & it helpeth stranguries, & ye root doth do ye same.

Smyrnium which they call Petroselinum in Cilicia, growing plentifully on the hill which is called Amanus: this hath a stalk like unto Selinum having many spriggs, but ye leaves broader towards ye ground, & they winde about beneath somewhat gross strong & smelling sweet, with sharpness & of a medicinal scent, & inclining to a faint yellow in colour, but a tuft on ye stalk, like that of Dill; the seed round like that of ye Colewort, black, sharp, like Myrrh to ye taster, making one for one; but ye root sharp, odoriferous, tender full of juice, biting ye top of ye throat, having a bark, in ye outside black, but within pale, or of a faint white. It grows in rocky & hillocky & dry places, & corners untilled, the root & ye herb & ye seed hath a faculty of warming, and the leaves are eaten like potherbs being preserved in brine, & stop ye belly; but ye roote being drank doth help ye serpent-bitten, it assuageth also coughs, and orthopnoeas, & healeth dysuries, but being applied it dissolveth ye late-come Oedemata, & inflammations & hardnesses & it brings wounds to a cicatrix. Being sodden and applied as a Pessum it causeth abortion, & the seed of it is good for ye kidnies & ye spleen & ye bladder. And it expells ye menstrua, & ye secondines, & it is good for Sciaticas being drank with wine, & it assuageth inflations of ye stomach, & it is also a causer of sweat & of belching; being drank especially for dropsies, & ye circular courses of agues.

Elaphoboscum [some call Elaphicum some Nephrium some Ophigenium, some Ophioctonon, some Herpyxe, some Lyme, ye Romans Cervi ocellum ye Egyptians Chemis, ye Africans Ascacau] is a stalk like to Libanotis, or to Fennill, knotty, ye leaves of 2 fingers breadth, very long, as of Terebinth, broken about in a sharp manner, but the stalk hath very many little spriggs having tufts like unto Dill flowers, of a pale yellow, & ye seed like unto Dill. Ye root about ye length of three fingers ye thickness of a finger, white sweet, edible: ye stalk being newly come up, is eaten as other herbs. They say that ye Hindes having fed on this very herb do hereby resist ye bitings of serpents, whence also ye seed is given with wine to ye serpent-bitten.

Fennill, ye herb itself if eaten is of force to draw down milk, as doth the seed being drank, or sodden together with Ptissana. But ye decoction of the hair being drank is good for ye nephriticall, & for ye griefs about ye bladder being diureticall. It is fitting also for ye serpent-bitten when drank with wine, & it expells ye menstrua, & in fevers doth assuage ye burning heat & nauseousness of ye stomach, being drank with cold water. Ye roots being beaten small & applied with honey do heal dogs-bitings, but the juice of the bruised stalks, & ye leaves being dried in ye sun, is prepared commodiously for eye medicines such as are for ye sight-quickening, & ye seed also being green together with the leaves & the branches is juiced for the same purposes, & the root at ye first putting out. But in Iberia towards ye West it sends out a liquor like unto gum, ye inhabitants in ye flowering time, cutting it down about ye middle of ye stalk, lay it by the fire, that being as it were in a sweat by the warmth, it may cast out ye gum: and this is more effectuall than ye juice for ye eye medicines.

Hippomarathrum [some call Marathrum sylvestre, ye Egyptians Sampsos, ye Magi Thymarnolion, Romans Faeniculum erraticum, some Faeniculos, some Cuinos, some Meum, ye Galls Sistrameor] is ye tall Wild Fennill, it bears a seed like unto Cachryi, ye roote under is of a sweet scent, and being drank cureth stranguries, & expells ye menstrua when applied. But ye seed & ye root being drank stop ye belly, & help ye bitten by poisonous beasts, & break ye stones & cleanse ye Icterus; & the decoction of ye leaves being drank brings out milk, & cleanseth ye women after childbirth.

And there is another called Hippomarathrum having slender small, somewhat long leaves, but ye seed round like that of Coriander, sharp, of a sweet scent, heating; but ye virtue of it is answerable to ye aforespoken working more weakly.
83. DAUKOS. (1) Athamanta Cretensis? or Daucus Carota

Daucus, some call it Dircaeum, that which is of Crete, having leaves like unto Fennill, yet lesser, & slenderer, a stalk a span long, a tuft like to Coriander, ye flowers white, & in these the seed sharp white, rough, sweet smelling in the chewing, ye root ye thickness of a finger, but the length of a span. It grows in rocky & sunny places.

But there is another kind of them like unto wild Selinum, sharp, & smelling sweet, & hott to him that tasteth it, but that of Crete is ye best. But the third kind is like in leaves to Coriander, with white flowers, but it hath an head, & seed like to Dill, on which head a tuft like to Pastinaca full of long seed, as of Cumin, sharp. But ye seed of them all hath a warming faculty, being drank, expelling of ye menstrua, ye embryo & ye urine, & freeing from ye tormina, assuaging of old coughs, it helps those bitten by ye Phalangium being drank with wine, & being applied it dissolves also ye Oedemata. But ye seed only of all the others is of use, but of ye Cretick kind ye root also, which is drank especially with wine against hurts by poisonous beasts.

Delphinium [some call it Diachysis, some Diachytos, some Paralysis, some Camaros, some Hyacinthus, some Delphinias, some Nerion, some Nereadium, some Sosandros, some Cronios, ye Romanes Buccinus minor] sends out shoots two spans long or rather greater from one root, about which are little leaves cut-in, thin, somewhat long, like Dolphins whence also they are named, but ye flower like ye white violet, bearing upon a purple colour, ye seed in the cods resembling Milium, which drank in wine helpeth ye scorpion-bitten, as nothing else. They say also that Scoprions grow faint, & become unactive & benumbed, the herb being put to them which being taken away, they are restored to their former state. It grows in rough, & sunny places.

The other Delphinium [some call Hyacinthum, ye Romans Bucinus,] & this also is like to that before it, yet much slenderer in ye leaves & ye branches, & this also has ye same virtue with the afore spoken of, but not altogether so effectual.

Pyrethrum [some call Dorycnion, some Pyrinon, some Pyroton, some Pyrothron, some Arnopurites, the Magi Purites, ye Romans Salivaris] is an herb sending out a stalk, & leaves as wild Daucus, & Fennill, & a tuft as that of Dill. Ye root long, ye thickness of ye great finger, like hair curled round, extreme burning hot to him that tastes it, it is a drawer-out of phlegm, whence also it helps ye toothache being sodden with vinegar, & ye mouth washed with it; it also expells phlegm being chewed, but being anointed on together with oil it procureth sweats, being efficacious for Rigors of long continuance, & it is excellent good for ye chilled or paralyticall parts of ye body.

Libanotis is of 2 sorts, one of which bears fruit, which by some is called Zea, or Campsanema, of which ye seed is called Cachris, but it hath leaves like to fennill, but thicker and broader, lying like a wheel on ye ground, smelling sweet, but the stalk is of a cubit & more, having many wings, & on ye top a tuft in which is much seed, white, like to a vertebra, round, having corners, sharp, smelling like rosin, & in the chewing burning ye taste, but ye roote white, very great, smelling of franckincense. But ye other kind being like in everything to that before it, beares a broad seed, black, as Sphondylium, sweet-smelling, not burning, a root as for ye out part, black, but being broken white. But that called unfruitful, being like to ye aforesaid spoken-of sends out neither stalk, nor flower, nor seed. It grows in rockie & rough places. But the herb of all of them in general being applied beaten doth stop ye Haemorrhoids, & assuage ye inflammations such as are in ye seat, & ye Condylomata, & do concoct ye hard to be concocted of suppurations, but the dry roots with honey doe cleanse ulcers & cure ye tormina, & are good for ye bitten by venemous beasts: being drank with wine, & they expell ye menstrua, & ye urine, & dissolve also old Oedemata being applied, but ye juice of ye root & of ye herb is a sight-quickener being mixed with honey & anointed on, and ye seed being drank doth do ye same feats: it helps also ye Epilepsie, the old griefs in the Thorax, & ye Ictericall, being given with pepper, & wine: it is also a causer of sweat, being anointed on with oil. It is good also for ruptures, & convulsions, & feet goutes being laid on beaten small with Lolium meale & acetum; & it cleanseth ye vitiligines being mixed with ye sharpest acetum & for abscessus we ought to use that kind which bears no Cachrys, for that is sharp & exasperating of ye Artery. Theophrastus speaks of Libanotis growing with Erica, having leaves like wild Lettuce, which is bitter, has a short root but ye leaves are whiter, and sharper than those of ye Lettuce. & that this being drank doth purge upward, & downward,
Cachry hath a warming & extraordinary drying faculty, whence it is good being mixed with Smegmata, & for rhumatick eyes being sprinkled on the head, & wiped off after three days.

Libanotis which ye Romans call Rosmarinus, & they which plait crowns use it: the shoots are slender, about which are leaves small, thick somewhat long, thin, on ye inside white, but on ye outside green, of a strong scent. It hath a warming facultie, curing of ye Icterus, if any having sod it in water give it to drink before exercises, & then he who exerciseth doe bath and be drenched with wine: it is also mixed with Acopa, & ye Gleucinum unguentum.

Sphondylium [some call Arangem, some Phalangium, or Asterium, some Nisyris, some Sphondulis, some Choradanon or Oenanthe, ye Romans Herba rotularis, ye Egyptians Apsapher, ye Magi Osiris] hath leaves somewhat like to ye Platanus, according to those of Panax, but stalks of a cubit high or rather more, like unto Fennill, but ye seed on ye top like Seselis, double, but broader, and whiter, & more husky, of a strong scent, ye flowers white, ye root white like to Raphanus. But it grows in marshy, & moist countries. The seed thereof being drank, purgeth through ye belly phlegmy stuff. It cures being drank ye Hepaticall, Ictericall Orthopnoeicall, Epilepticall, & ye strangulation of ye matrix. Being suffited it calls back again such as sink in a swoon: the head being moistened herewith with oil it is good for ye phreneticall, lethargicall, & headaches. And it restrains ye Herpetas being applied with Rue. But ye root is given to ye Ictericall, & Hepaticall which being shaved about also & put in doth consume ye hardness which are in Fistulas. But ye juice of ye flower being new is good for exulcerated & purulent ears. It is laid up in store also, being sunned as the other juices.

Narthex [ye Romans call Ferula] the pith of this being drank whilst it is green, doth profit ye Haemoptoicall & Coeliacall, & with wine it is given to ye viper-bitten, & it stops ye fluxes of blood out of ye nostrils being put in as a tent. But ye seed being drank helps ye troubled with ye tormina, & being anointed on with oil it provokes sweats; but ye stalks being eaten are causes of headache, they are also preserved in brine. The Ferula therefore brings forth a stalk oftentimes 3 cubits long. But it hath leaves like to Fennill, yet much thicker & greater, from which when cut in near to ye root, comes ye Sagapenum.

Peucedanum [some call it Agrion, some Agriophyllon, ye Magi bonus Daemon, some Pinasgelum ye Romans Stataria] sends out a thin slender stalk like to Fennill, but it hath hair about ye root in abundance, & thick; ye flower yellow, ye root black, of a strong scent, plum full of liquor: it grows on shady hills. Ye liquor is taken thus: the root yet tender being cut with a knife & that which issues from it presently is set in ye shade, for under ye sun it is coloured forthwith, but in ye gathering of it, it causeth the headache & brings the Vertigines, if one does not anoint before his nostrils with Rosaceum, and wet his head beforehand with it. Ye root becomes unuseful having lost her liquor. Ye stalks and ye root, like Mandrake have their liquor taken & are juiced, but ye juice of ye liquor workes less, & quickly expires. Sometimes there is found a tear already congealed, like to frankincense sticking to ye stalks and to ye roots. But of ye juice, that which is made in Sardinia & Samothracia is ye best, of a strong scent, yellowish, warming the taste. It is good being anointed on with Acetum & Rosaceum for ye Lethargicall, Phreneticall, vertiginous, epilepticall, for ye long troubled with headaches, ye paralyticall, Ischiaticall, for ye convulsed, & in general for ye griefs about the sinews being anointed on with oil & acetum, & it is a scent to be smelled to for ye wombish strangling, & a raiser up again of such as sink in a swoon, & it drives away serpents being suffited, it is good also for ye ear-pain, being dropped in with rosaceum, & for ye toothach being put into their concavities. It is good also for coughs being taken with an egg. And it is effectual for hard breathings & ye tormina, and windy affections, & it gently mollifies ye belly, & lessens ye spleen, & wonderfully helps hard labours in childbirths, & being drank it is prevalent for ye griefs & extensions of ye bladder, & ye reynes, & also it unstops ye matrix. Ye root also is profitable for ye same purposes, working less effectually, but the decoction of this is drank, being beaten small; also when it is dry, it cleanseth the foul ulcers, & takes off scales from ye bones, & heals ye old ulcers. It is mixed also with Cerats, & with warming Malagmatas. But choose ye root which is new, uneaten, sound, full of scent. But ye liquor dissolved into potions with bitter almonds, or Rue, or warme bread, or Dill.

Melanthium [some also call this Mecon agria melana, the Romans Papauer niger,] is a little shrub with slender shoots of 2 spans length, or more, having small leaves like as of Senecio, but much slenderer, and having a small head on ye top, little, as of Poppy. Somewhat long having in ye side partitions in which also is ye seed, black, sharp, sweet-smelling, used to be sprinkled on loaves. It is good also for ye troubled with headache being applied to ye forehead, & for such as begin to have suffusion of ye eyes, being poured into ye nostrils after it is beaten small with Irinum. It takes away also ye Lentigines, & leprosies, & old Oedemata, and hardnesses being applied with Acetum; & with old wine being laid on, it takes away corns, being first scarified about. And it is good for ye toothaches, being sodden with Acetum & taeda & ye mouth washed therewith. It expells also round worms, the nail being smeared thereby with water. But being beaten small, & bound up in a loin cloth, and smelled-to, it helps ye troubled with Catarrs. But being drank for many days together, it drives out the menstrua & ye urine & ye milk, & being drank with wine it easeth ye hardness of breathing, it helps also ye bitten of ye Phalangium as much as a dragm being drank with water. It drives away also serpents being suffited: they say also that it kills when much is drank.

Silphium grows in the places about Syria, & Armenia, & Media, & Libya, of which ye stalk is called Maspetum, like unto Ferula, but it hath leaves like unto Apium, a broad seed, but ye root is warming, hard of digestion, inflative, & hurtful of ye bladder. It cures ye Strumae & Tubercula being taken in a Cerat, or also Sugillata being smeared on with oil. But with a Cerat of Irinum & Cyprinum it is of fit use for ye Ischiaticall. And it takes away ye excrescencies about ye seat being sodden in a pomegranat coat with Acetum & so applied. And being drank it is an Antipharmacum of deadly medicines. And it rellisheth ye mouth well, being mixed with sauces & salt. But ye liquor is gathered, the root & ye stalk being cut in. But of this, that is ye best, which is somewhat red & transparent, emulating myrrh, & prevalent in ye smell, not scenting like a leek, neither unpleasant for ye taste to ye taste, & easily changing into a white colour. But the Cyreniacall although one shall taste it never so little, raiseth a moisture over all ye body, & it is very gentle to ye smell, so that to him that tastes it ye mouth doth not breath but a little of it. But ye Median & Syriacall are weaker in strength, & they have a more poisonous smell. But all ye juice is adulterated before it be dry, Sagapen or Bean meal being mixed with it, which thou shalt discern by ye taste, & by ye smell, & by ye sight, & by ye lotion. But some have called the stalk Silphium, but ye root Magudarim, & the leaves Maspeta. But ye juice is ye most effectuall, then ye leaves, & then ye stalk. But it is inflative & sharp, curing ye Alopecia by anointing it with wine, & pepper, & Acetum. It is a causer of quickness of sight, & a dispenser of ye beginning suffusion being smeared on with Honey. For the teethache it is put into their concavities, or being put into a linen cloth with franckincense, it is wrapt about ye tooth, or ye mouth is washed therewith with hyssop & figs, being sodden with Posca. It is good also for ye dog-bitten, being laid on the wounds, & for ye hurts of all poisonous beasts, & of poisoned arrows, being anointed on or drank; but for ye scorpion-smitten, being diluted in oil it is anointed on about, & it is poured into gangrened parts they being first sacrified. And for Carbuncles, with rue & nitre & honey or by itself, & it takes away corns, & fleshy hardness, they being first cut in round about, & it first kneaded together with Cerat, or ye inside of dry figs, & with Acetum it cures ye late-come Lichens; but ye Carcomata, & ye Polypi being anointed on for some days together with Coblers ink, or Aerugo, but pull off extuberancies with a pair of Pincers. It helps also ye long continued exasperations of ye Bronchi. And being diluted in water, & supt up, forthwith it clears ye voice which was grown hearse upon ye sudden; & it represseth ye Uvulas being smeared on with Honey. And with Melicrat it is a profitable gargarisme for Synanchicall. It makes men better coloured, being taken in meat, & it is good for ye cough being given in a rear egg, & for ye Pleuriticall to be supt up & with dry figs it is given profitably to ye Ictericall, & ye Hydropicall. And it dissolves Rigors being drank with pepper, & Frankincense, & wine. Having made into a round form ye quantity of an Obolus of it, give it to swallow to such as have the Tetanus, and ye Opisthotonical. And being gargarized with Acetum, it casts off horseleaches that stick to ye throat, & it is good for such whose milk curdles within, & ye Epilepticall it helps, being taken with Oxymel. But being drank with Pepper & Myrrh, it moves ye menstrua & being taken in ye Acinum of Uva passa it helps ye Coeliaci. But being drank with lixivium, it helps ye sudden convulsions, & ruptures. It is dissolved for potions with bitter almonds, or Rue or warme bread, and ye juice of ye leaves performs ye same, but a great deal less effectually. It is eaten with Oxymel, being good for ye Artery, but especially for ye cut off voices. They use it also eating it with Lettuces instead of Eruca.

There is said also to be another Magudaris growing in Lybia, ye root like Silphium, but somewhat less thick, sharp, & of a loose substance, & not having any juice. But it performes ye same action, as Silphium.

Sagapenum is ye liquor of ye Ferulacean herb growing in Media. But of this that is best which is transparent, of a yellow colour without, but white in ye inward parts, smelling between ye juice of Silphium & Galbanum, sharp in ye taste. But it is good for ye pain of ye breast, & of ye side, for ruptures, convulsions, old coughs. It cleanseth out ye gross stuff in ye lungs. It is given also to ye Epilepticall, to ye Opisthotonicall, ye Spleneticall, ye Paralyticall, to ye benummed with cold, & for ye periodical fevers in drinks, & it is put profitably into compound ointments. It expells also ye menstrua, & being drank with Hydromel it kills ye Embryo. It heales also ye bitten of venemous beasts, being taken with wine. It raiseth up also ye strangled in ye womb being smelled to with Acetum. And it cleanseth cicatrices, those in ye eye, & dullness of sight, & the things that darken ye Pupilla, and Suffusions. It is dissolved as ye liquor, with Rue & water & bitter Almonds, or Honey, or warm bread.

Euphorbium is a Ferula-resembling tree of Lybia, growing on Tmolus, an hill by Mauritania; full of very sharp liquor, which ye men there being afraid of for ye extraordinariess of ye heat, do gather thus; binding therefore about ye tree sheeps’ mawes washed, and standing afar off, they pierce ye stalk with long tools; & presently there flows out much liquor as out of some vessell into ye bellies, and being thus pierced, is also sprinkled on ye ground. But there are 2 kinds of ye liquor: One transparent as Sarcocolla, about ye bigness of Ervum, but ye other that is taken in ye bellies is of a glassy look & compact. But it is adulterated with Sarcocolla & glue mixed together. But choose that which is transparent & sharp, but that which is taken by ye tast is very hard to be tried, because ye tongue being once bitten, the burning doth remain for a long time, so that whatsoever is brought them seems to be Euphorbium. But ye first finding of it is known to be when Juba was king of Lybia. But ye juice hath a faculty of dissolving suffusions, being anointed on, but being drank it burns one through a whole day, whence it is mixed with Honey & Collyriums, according to ye proportion of ye sharpness. It is good also for griefs of ye hips, being mixed with an aromaticall potion, & so drank. It doth away scales from ye bones the self-same day, but it behoves them that use it to secure the flesh lying about the bones with linen cloths or Cerats. But some give out that no hurt doth follow upon them that are serpent-bitten, if one having cut ye skin of ye head even unto the bone, do pour in ye liquor beaten small, & sew up ye wound.
°97. CHALBANE. Ferula Ferulago or Selinum Galbanum

Galbanum is ye liquor of ye Ferula growing in Syria, which some call Metopium. But ye best of this is like Franckincense, clotty, pure, fat, not woodish, having something of ye seed & of the Ferula mixed, of a strong scent, neither too much moist, neither again over dry. But they doe adulterate it, mixing rosin & bruised beans & Amoniacum. But it hath a warming, burning, attractive discussive faculty; being either applied or suffited, it expels ye menstrua, & ye Embryo & it takes away ye Lentigines being smeared on with Acetum & nitre. It is also swallowed down for ye old cough, hard breathing, Asthmas, ruptures, Convlusions, and being drank with Acetum & myrrh it withstands poison. And being taken so too, it casts out ye dead Embryo. And it is also aplied for the pain of ye side, & for ye Furunculi, & being smelled to it raiseth up ye Epilepticall, & ye womb-strangled, & ye vertiginous; & being suffited it drives away poisonous beasts, & it keeps such as anointed herewith, unbitten, & being laid on round about with Sphondylium & oil it kills serpents. And it assuageth ye pain of ye tooth being smeared round about it, or put into ye concavitie, & it seems to be good for ye dysureticall. It is also dissolved into potions with bitter almonds & water, or rue, or melicrate, or warm bread or otherwise with Meconium, or brass burned, or with liquid gale. But if you would purify it, put it into warm water, for it being melted, ye filth of it will swim above, which you shall sever thus. Having bound ye galbanum in a clean thin linen cloth, hang it in a brasen pot, or earthen vessel, so that the bundle doe not touch ye bottom of ye vessel, & having stopped it close, put it into seething water, for soe the best will be melted as through a strainer, but ye woody stuff will remain in ye linen cloth.
98. AMMONIAKON. Ferula orientalis or F. tingitana

Ammoniacum [is an herb from which ye Ammoniacall incense is gathered, which some call Agasyllon, some Criotheos, some Heliastrus, ye Romans Gutta] & this is ye liquor of a Ferula growing in Lybia which is by Cyrene. But ye whole shrub together with ye root is called Agasyllis. But that is thought ye best of it which is well coloured, not woody, & without stone, like franckincense in ye little clots, clear, & thick, having no filth, like Castor in ye smell, but bitter to ye taste, and such as this is called Thrausma. But ye earthy or stony is called Phurama. It grows in Libya by Ammon’s temple, being ye juice of a tree like Ferula. It hath a faculty of mollifying, attracting, warming, dissolving of hardness & Panos. And being drank it brings down ye belly, & drives out ye Embryo. It lessens ye spleen 1 dragm being drank with Acetum, & it takes away ye paines of ye joints & of ye hips. And helps also ye Asthmaticall, Orthopnoicall, Epilepticall, & those who have moisture in ye thorax, being lickt in with hony, or supt up with ye juice of Ptissana. It expells also bloody urine, & it cleanseth ye albugines in ye eyes, & consumes ye ruggedness of the Gene. Being beaten small with vinegar & applied, it mollifies ye hardnesses about ye spleen & ye liver, & it dissolves ye knobs about ye joints, being applied with honey or else mixed with pitch. It is also good for lassitudes & Sciaticas, being anointed on when it is mixed with Acetum & nitre & Oleum Cyprinum, instead of an Acopicall medicine.

Sarcocolla is ye tear of a tree growing in Persis, like unto thin franckincense, of a dark yellow, somewhat bitter to ye taste. It hath a faculty of conglutinating of wounds, & stopping of ye rhumes in the eyes. It is also mixed with plasters. But it is counterfeited by gum being mixed with it.

Glaucium is ye juice of an herb growing at Hierapolis of Syria, but ye leaves of it are like horned Poppy, but fatter, & scattered on ye ground, & of a strong scent, & bitterer in ye taste. It hath much juice of a saffron colour. The inhabitants casting the leaves of this into a pot, warm it in ovens half cold even to withering, afterward beating them they press out the juice. But ye use of it is for ye eye-griefs in ye beginning, it being of a cooling nature.

Glutinum which some call Xylocolla, or Taurocolla, the best is that of Rhodes, made of bull hydes. But such as this is white & transparent, but ye black is worse. Being dissolved in acetum, it hath ye power to take away those Impetigines & leprosies on ye outside of ye skin. And being diluted with warm water & smeared on it suffers not ambusta to be pustled, but being diluted with honey & acetum it is good for wounds.

But that which is called Fish glue is ye belly of a whale fish, but that is ye best which is made in Pontus, being white, somewhat rough, not scabbed, very quickly melted. It is good to be put into head-plasters, & medicines for ye leprosy, & into medicines for making the skin of faces smooth.
°103. IXOS. Viscum album? or Loranthus Europaeus

That Viscum is good which is new, & looking like a leek in colour as concerning ye inner parts, but of a pale yellow without, having nothing rough, or branny. It is made of a certain round fruit growing on ye oak, that hath leaves like unto Box. This fruit is pounded, then washed, afterward sodden in water, but some make it by chewing it. It grows also on ye appletree, & pear tree, & on other trees. It is of force to discusse, to mollify, to attract, to concoct swellings, ye Parotidas, & ye other suppurations, being mixed with equal wax, & rosin. And it heals ye Epinyctidae in a Splenium. But with franckincense it mollifies old ulcers, & malignant suppurations, and being sodden with quick lime or ye Agat stone, or Asiaticall, & applied it lessens ye spleen. And it draws off also nails being smeared with Arsenick or Sandarach. But being mixed with unslacked lime and wine-lees it doth extend the strength of it.
104. APARINE. Galium verrucosum or G. Aparine

Aparine, but some call it Ampelocarpum, some Omphelocarpum, & some Philanthropum, & some Ixos, has many branches, little, & square, rough but ye leaves at a distance lying round about like a circle, as those of Rubia. The flowers white, ye seed hard, white, round, somewhat hollow in ye midst as ye navel; & the herb sticketh to cloths, and ye shepherds doe use it instead of a strainer for the milke, for ye taking out of hairs in it. The seed & ye stalks & the leaves of this being juiced, doe help ye Phalangia-bitten, & ye viper-bitten; being drank with wine & ye juice being dropped in doth cure ear-pains. But ye herb being taken in Swines grease beaten, dissolves ye strumas.
