Alyssum [some call it Aspidium, some Haplophyllon some Accuseton, some Adeseton] is a little shrub somewhat rough, having round leaves, by which is ye fruit like double little shields, wherein is ye seed somewhat broad; it grows in hilly & rough places. The decoction of this being drank dissolveth vexings such as are without a fever, & being held, or smelt to it works ye like effect. Being beaten small with honey it cleanseth ye Lentigines, & ye Ephelis. It is thought also to cure ye madness of a dog, being beaten together in meat & given him. And being hanged in an house it is said to be wholesome, & an Amulet for men, & beasts, & being hanged about with a purple cloth it drives away ye griefs of cattle.

Asclepias [some call it Cission, some Cissophullon] send out long little branches, like to Ivie, many & slender roots of a sweet scent, ye flower smelling strong, but ye seed as it were of Securidaca. It grows on hills. But ye roots being drank in wine doe help such as have ye tormina, & such as are bitten of poisonous beasts, & the leaves being laid on are good for malignant griefs in ye duggs, & ye matrix.
107. ATRAKTULIS. Atriplex hortensis, Sprengel, Carthamus lanatus

Atractylis [but some call it Amyron, some Cnicus sylvestris, some Aspidium, the Magi Aphedros, ye Egyptians Cheno, ye Romans Presepium, some Fusus agrestis, some Colus rustica] is a Spina like Cnicus, having much longer leaves upon ye top of ye shoots, but ye most part of it is naked & rough, which also women use instead of a spindle, it hath also on ye top little prickly heads, a pale flower; but ye root is thin, & unuseful; ye leaves & ye hair & ye fruit of this, being beaten small, & drank with pepper & wine doe help ye smitten of Scoprions. Some also relate, that the smitten thus are without pain as long as they hold the herb, & laying it away, are pained again.
Polycnemon [which some call Clinopodium, some Polygonatum, some colus Iovis, some Echeonymon, ye Romans

Puteologonthria] is a shrub full of spriggs, having leaves like to Origanum, but a stalk with many joints, as of Pulegium. It hath not a tuft, but little clusters on the top with a certain sharp pleasant smell. It is effectual being laid on green, or dry with water, for conglutinating wounds. But you must loosen it when it has been laid on 5 days. It is also drank with wine for ye stragurie, & ruptures [Experience hath taught, how the little branches being bruised in white wine are a great help for such as are possessed with ye so-called water-frenzies.]

Clinopodium [some call it Cleonicum, some Ocimoides, & some call it Zopyrum] is a little shrub, & that full of shoots, 2 spans high, growing upon rocks, having leaves like unto Serpyllum, & ye flowers like as it were to ye feet of a bed, round by distances like to Marrubium. But ye herb & the decoction of it is drank for ye bitings of venemous beasts, & convulsions, & ruptures, & ye strangury. And it drives out ye menstrua, & embryo, & it casts off hanging warts being drank for many days [& it stays ye belly being sodden two thirds, & drank in wine for ye unfeverish, but for ye feverish with water].

Leontopetalum [some call it Leontopodium, some Leontium, some Doris, some Doricteris, some Lychnis Sylvestris, some Pardale, some Thorybethron, some Rapeium, some Papauer corniculatum, some Anemone, ye Romans Papauerculum, and semen Leoninum] sends out a stalk a span long, or rather more, having many wings on whose tops are codds like Ciceres & in these two or three little seeds ye flowers of a phoenician colour, like to Anemone, but ye leaves like Colewort, cut in as those of Poppy, ye root black as Rapum, having excrescencies, as it were some knotts. But it grows in fields & amongst wheat. But ye root of this being drank with wine doth help ye serpent-bitten, making them quickly without pain. It is mixed also with ye glysters for ye Sciatica.
111. TEUKRION. Teucrium flavum or Veronica Teucrium

Teucrium but some this call Chamedrys, [some Teucris] is an herb like a rod, resembling Germander, of a thin leaf, having a leaf like Cicer. It grows very much in Cilicia, in that part near Gentias, & Kissas so-called. But being drank green with Posca, or dry & sodden, & drank mightily it hath ye power to diminish ye spleen, but with figs, & Acetum, it is laid on ye Splenicall, but on such as are bitten by poisonous beasts with Acetum alone without figs.

Chamaedrys [ye Romans call it Trissago minor] some Chamedrops, or Linodrys, but because it keeps a certain likeness to Teucrium, some also have called it Teucrium. But it grows in rough, & rocky places. It is a small shrub, a span long, having little leaves, like in shape & in ye jagging to an oak, bitter, ye flower of a pale purple, little. But it must be gathered when great with seed; being newly taken, & soe sodden with water, & given for a drink, it hath ye power, to help convulsions, ye cough, ye spleen having a schirrhus, ye dysureticall, & ye hydropicall in ye beginnings. It expells also ye menstrua & embryo & being drank with Acetum it abates ye spleen. It is good also against venemous beasts, being drank with wine & smeared on, & being beaten small it may also be formed into pills, for ye purposes afore-said, & to cleanse old ulcers with honey, being beaten small, & anointed on with oil it takes away dimnesses that are in the eyes, & being anointed on it is of a warming faculty.

Leucas of ye hill, is broader leaved than ye sative, having a seed, both sharper, and bitterer, & worse rellishing ye mouth, yet it is more operative than ye sative, but both of them smeared on & drank are good with wine against ye venome of poisonous creatures especially those of ye Sea.

Lychnis coronaria [some call it Athanates, some Aquilonium, some Vallarium, some Geranopodium, some Corymbion, some Taurion, some Sceptrum, some Maloion, ye Egyptians Seneom. The Magi ye blood of a menstruous woman. The Romans, Genicularis, some Vallaria] is a flower, like to ye white violet but bearing on a purple, plated into little crowns, of which ye seed being drank with wine doth help ye scorpion-bitten.

Lychnis Sylvestris [some call it Tragonoton, some Atocion, some Hieracopodion, some Lampas, ye Egyptians Semura, ye Magi ye genitall of a menstruous woman, ye Romans Intybus agrestis, some Lapathum, or Caphaguina, some Seris] is like to ye Sative in all things. But ye seed of it being drank ye quantity of 2 dragms doth expell by ye belly colerick matter & helpeth ye Scorpion-smitten. They say also that when this herb is laid by them they become benumed & not able to hurt.

Lilium regium [Some call it Crinanthemom, some Callirium ye Magi Sanguis Martis, Osthanes Aura Crocodili, the Egyptians Symphaephu, some Tialos, ye Romans Lilium some Rosa Iunonis, ye Syrians Sasa, ye Africans Abiblabon] ye flower of this is used to make crowns and is called by some Lirium, of which also is made ye ointment, which some call Lirinum, some Susinum being a mollifier of ye sinews, & properly of the hardnesses about ye matrix. But ye leaves of the herb being applied do help ye serpent-bitten, & being sodden they are good for burns, & being condited in Acetum, they are good for wounds. But ye juice of them being mixed with Acetum or honey, & sodden in a brass vessel becomes a liquid medicine for old ulcers & new wounds. But ye root being rosted & beaten small with Rosaceum doth cure & mollifies ye matrix, & expells ye menstrua, and cicatriceth ulcers. Being beaten small with honey, it cures ye cutting asunder & ye laxations of ye nerves, & cleanseth leprosies, and the Alphos, & it takes off ye Furfures, & it cleareth ye faces & makes them without wrinkles. But beaten small with acetum, or with ye leaves of Hyoscyamus, & wheaten meal it assuageth ye inflammations of ye stones. But ye seed being drank is an Antidot for ye bitings of serpents. And both ye seed, & the leaves being beaten small, with wine are a cataplasme for ye Erysipelata. But some say that there are flowers of Lilly of a purple colour. But ye effectuallest for ye making of ye ointment grows in Syria, & Pisidia of Pamphilia.

Ballota or Marrubium nigrum [Some call it Nophtham, some Notianoscemin, some Cynosprasion, some Notheras, some Nochelis some Nostelis, some Nophrys, some Gnothuris, some Gnotera, ye Romans Apnium, some Melita, some Ulceraria, some Marrubium, some Cantherinum, ye Egyptians Asphos, some Esce, the Magi ye blood of Isis] doth send out stalks that are 4-cornered, black somewhat rough, many out of one root, but ye leaves are like to Marrubium, yet greater, and rounder, & black, & rough, by distances of ye stalk, after ye manner of Apiastrum, of a strong scent whence also they have called this Apiastrum; and the flowers withall lie about the white stalks like a circle. The leaves of this being applied with salt are good for ye bitten of dogs, being warm’d till they wither in warme ashes, they repress ye Condylomata, and with honey they cleanse foul ulcers.

Apiastrum, which some call Melittena, [some call it Melitteon, some Meliphyllon, some Erythra, some Temele, ye Romans Apiastrum, some Citrago, ye French Merisimorion] because the Bees do delight in ye herb. But ye leaves of it & ye little stalk are like to ye aforesaid Ballota, but these are greater, & thinner, & not so rough, but smelling of a Pome-citron. But ye leaves being drank with wine, & also applied are good for the Scorpion-smitten, & ye Phalangium-bitten, and ye dog-bitten & ye decoction of them, by way of fomentation for ye same purposes. And it is fitting for women’s insessions for ye moving of ye menstrua & a collution for teeth pains, & a glyster for ye dysentericall, & ye leaves being drank with nitre do help those which are strangled of mushrooms, and ye Torminosi. And taken in a Lohoc helps ye Orthopnoeici, but being applied with salt they dissolve ye strumas, & it cleanseth ulcers. And being smeared on they assuage ye pains of ye goutie.

Marrubium [some call it Eupatorium, some Phyllophares, some Tripedilon, some Camels foot, some Philophares, ye Egyptians Asterope, the Magi Sanguis tauri, some Aphedros, genitura Hori, ye Romans Marrubium, some Labeonia, ye Africans Atierberzia] is a shrub of many branches from one root, somewhat rough, white, 4-cornered in ye rodds, but ye leaf is equal to ye great finger, somewhat round, thick, wrinkled, bitter to ye taste. But ye seed on ye stalks by distances, & ye flowers as ye vertebra of ye backbone, sharp. It grows in places near to houses, & rubbish of buildings. The dry leaves of this, with ye seed being sodden with water, or juiced when green is given with honey to ye phthisicall asthmaticall, & to such as cough, & if dry Iris be mixed with it it brings up thick stuff out of ye Thorax. It is also given to women not yet cleansed, for ye driving out of ye menstrua, & ye secondines, and to women having hard labours, & to ye venemous beast-bitten, & to such as have drank some deadly thing. Yet it is offensive to ye bladder & ye veins. But the leaves being smeared on with honey, doe cleanse foul ulcers, & drive away ye Pterygia, & ye Nomas, and assuage the pains of ye sides; and the juice that is made out of ye pressed leaves, and thickened in ye sun makes for the same purposes. It is also a sight-quickener, being anointed on with wine & honey, & it purgeth away also ye Icterus through ye nostrils. It is good also for ear pains, being dropt in by itself, or with Rosaceum.

Stachys is a shrub like Marrubium, yet somewhat longer, & having many leaves, thin, somewhat rough, hard, of sweet scent, white, many small shoots from the same root, but whiter than those of Marrubium. It grows in hilly & rough places, but it hath a warming sharp faculty, whence ye decoction of the leaves being drank expells ye menstrua & ye secondines.

Phyllitis [some call it Phyllis, some Acaulon, some Lapathum sylvestre] sends out leaves like to Rumex, something longer & more flourishing, 6 or 7 upright, smooth on the fore parts, but on ye hinder parts having as it were little worms hanging, thin. It grows in shady places & Viridaries, bitter to him that tasteth it, but it bears neither stalk nor seed, nor flower. The leaves of this being drank with wine are good for ye serpent-bitten. It is helpfull also for 4-footed beasts being poured in through ye mouth. It is drank also for ye dysenteria, & ye Diarrhea.

Phalangium, but some call it Phalangite, others also call this Leucacantha. The branches are two or three or more, distant from one another, ye flowers white like to ye Lillie, having many incuts, the seed thick, black, like ye half of Lens, but much slenderer; a small little root, thin, green at ye drawing it up out of ye earth, for afterward it is contracted. It grows in hillocky places; the leaf of this, & the seed, and ye flower being drank with wine do help ye scorpion-smitten & such as are bitten of ye Phalangium: it also dissolves ye Tormina.

Trifolium, but some call it Oxyphyllon, some Menyanthes, some Asphaltium, & some call it Cnicium [ye Romans Trifolium, some Trifolium acutum odoratum], is a shrub higher than a cubit, having slender black, onion-stalk-like rods, having branches annext, on which are leaves like to ye Lote tree, three on every Sprigg. But ye smell of them being but new put-out is of Rue, but of them being grown, as of Bitumen. It sends out a flower of a purple colour, but ye seed is somewhat broad & somewhat rough having at ye one end as it were an horn. The root is thin, long, strong. But the seed, and ye leaves drank in water doe help ye pleuriticall, ye dysureticall, ye Epilepticall, such as begin to have the dropsy & ye womb-strangled. It expels also ye menstrua, but there must be given of ye seed 3 dragms, but of ye leaves 4 dragms. But ye leaves beaten small being drank with Oxymel do help ye venemous-beast-bitten. And some say that ye whole decoction of the shrub & of the root, and of ye leaves being fomented on ye serpent-bitten assuageth ye pains, but if another having an ulcer be fomented in ye water wherein another was healed, he feels ye same pains as the bitten did. Some give in drink for the Tertian three leaves, or three seeds with wine, & for the quartan 4 as dissolving ye circular courses of agues. But ye root of it is mixed also with Antidots.

Polion ye mountainous [some call it Teuthrion, some Pheuxaspidion, some Achaemenis, some Ebenitis, some Melosmon, some Belion, some Leontocharon] which also is called Teuthris, & of which there is use. It is a little shrub, thin, white, a span long, full of seed, having a small head on ye top like a Corymbus, little as gray hair, of a strong scent with some pleasant smell; but ye other is more shrubby, not altogether so strong to ye smell, & not so effectuall for its working. But ye decoction of them being drank is of force to help ye bitten of venemous beasts, ye hydropicall, & ye Ictericall, & ye spleneticall with Acetum, but it is a causer of headache, & bad for ye stomach. It also moves ye belly & ye menstrua, but being strewed under or suffited, it drives away venemous beasts, & being applied conglutinates wounds.

Scordium [some call it Scorbium, some Pleuritis, some Dysosmon, some Calamintha sylvestris, some Chamedrys, some Mithridanios, the Magi Sanguis Podotis, ye Egyptians Apho, ye Romans Trisago palustris] it grows in mountainous & marshy places having leaves like to Chamedrys, but greater & not so incut about ye compass, somewhat resembling garlick in ye smell, but binding and bitter according to ye taste. Ye little stalks are 4-cornered, from which a pale red flower. But ye herb hath a warming, diureticall faculty being given in drink green & beaten, as also dry; being sodden with wine it is good for ye bitings of serpents, and poisons. And for ye gnawing of ye stomach, & ye dysentery, & ye Dysury, 2 dragms with Hydromel. It expells also purulent thicknesses out of the thorax. It avails also for ye old cough & ruptures & convulsions, being mixed dry in a Lohoc with Nasturtium and honey & Rosin: & being taken in a Cerate it lenifieth ye Hypochondrium a long time enflamed. It is good also for ye gout, being smeared about with sharp acetum, or applied with water. But being laid to, it moves ye menstrua, & conglutinates wounds. It cleanseth old ulcers, & with honey brings them to a Cicatrix. But being dry it restrains ye excrescencies of the flesh. And the juice also of it is drank for ye said griefs. But ye effectuallest is the Pontick, & the Cretick.

Tussilago [some call it Richion, some Petrina, some Peganon, some Pithion, some Pagonaton, some Chameleuce, some Procheton, some Arcophyton, some Chamegiron, ye Egyptians Saartha, ye Romans Tussilago, some Pharpharia, some Pustulago, ye Bessians Asa] hath leaves like unto Ivy, but greater, 6 or 7 from the root, as concerning ye lower side white, but as concerning ye upper side green, having many corners, a stalk a span long, a pale yellow flower in ye spring-time, but it doth quickly cast off both ye flower & the stalk, whence some have thought ye herb to be without stalk & without flower: ye root thin & of no use. It grows about Scaturiginous & watery places. The leaves of this beaten small, & laid on doth cure ye Erysipelata, & all inflammation, but being suffited when it is dry, & ye smoke taken in through a tunnel, it cureth such as are troubled with a dry cough, & ye Orthopnea: when gaping they take the smoke in at ye mouth, & swallow it down. It breaks also the Impostumes in ye thorax, & ye root also being suffited doth do ye same, & casteth out ye dead Enbryon, being drank when it is sodden in Hydromel.

Artemisia some is Polyclonos, some Monoclonos [some call it Toxetesia, some Ephesia, some Anactorios, some Sozusa, some Lea, some Lycophrys. The Magi Sanguis hominis, some Chrysanthemon ye Romans Valentia, some Serpyllum, some Herba Regia, some Rapium, some Tertanageta, some Artenisia, ye French Ponem, ye Dacians Zuoste] it grows for ye most part in places near ye Sea, a shrub-like herb, like unto wormwood but greater & having ye leaves grosser. There is one sort of it prosperous, having broader leaves and rods, another lesser, ye flowers little thin white, of a strong smell, it flowers in ye summer. But some do call ye slender-branched little herb in ye Mediterranean parts, single in ye stalk, extremely small, abounding with flowers, of a tawnie yellow by colour, Artemisia Monoclonos. But ye scent of this is sweeter than of that. They both do warm & extenuate. But being sodden they are good to be put into womanish insessions for ye driving out of ye menstrua, & ye secondines, & ye Embryo, & ye preclusions, & ye inflammation of ye matrix, & ye breaking of stones, & ye stoppage of urines. But much of ye herb being applied to ye lower part of ye belly moves ye menstrua, but ye juice of it being kneaded together with myrrh, & applied, doth draw from the matrix as many things as ye Insession; ye hair of it is given in drink ye quantity of 3 dragms for ye bringing out of ye same things. [If any have ye herb Artemisia with him in ye way, it dissolves weariness, & he that bears it on his feet, drives away venemous beasts & devils. After that ye blood is hardened about ye joints, taking ye greater branches with Rosaceum & having made it seeth in a pot, anoint ye sick man all over as he goes to sleep; and it helps very much women womb-strangled, assuageth ye strangury, & ye rupture of ye Opisthotonum.

Artemisia tenuifolia grows about riverlets, & hedges, & in sown fields. The flower therefore of this, & ye leaves being bruised doe give ye smell of Sampsuchum. If therefore any be grieved at his stomach, & shall pound this herb well with oil of almonds, & shall make as it were a malagma, & shall lay it on the stomach, he shall be healed: and if any be pained in his sinews, having mixed ye juice of this with oil of Roses, let him anoint herewith, & he shall be whole.]

Ambrosia some call it Botrys, some Botrys Artemisia [the Romans Caper sylvaticus, or Apium rusticum, the Egyptians Merseo] is a little shrub ye highth of 3 spans, full of branches having leaves about the putting out of ye stalk, small as of Rue. But ye small stalks full of little seeds like unto little bunches of grapes, which never flower pleasant smelling like wine. But ye root is slender, 2 spans long. It is plaited in Cappadocia into crowns. It hath a faculty of repressing, repelling, & being smeared on is an astringent for ye humors fallen down.

Botrys is an herb all yellowish, like a shrub, broad spread, having many wings, but ye seed grows about all the branches; ye leaves like unto Cicorie, many, & all of it is of an wonderful sweet scent, wherefore it also is laid amongst cloths. It grows especially about running waters, & brooks. It hath a faculty being drank with wine to ease the Orthopneas; & ye Cappadocians call this Ambrosia but some call it Artemisia.

Geranium [some call it Pelonitis, some Trica, some Geranogeron, ye Romans Echinaster, ye Africans Iesce] hath a leaf like to Anenome, jagged but longer, a root somewhat round, sweet being eaten, which being drank in wine to ye quantity of a dragm dissolves ye inflations of ye Vulva.

It is called also of some alterum Geranium [but some call it Oxyphyllon, or Mertryx, or Myrrhis or Cardamomum, or Origanum, the Magi Hierobryncas, ye Romans Pulmonia, some Cicotria, some Herba gruina, the Africans Ienk] having slender little stalks, downy, 2 spans long, leaves like Mallows, & on ye tops of ye wings certain excrescencies looking upward, as ye heads of Cranes with ye beaks or ye teeth of dogs, but there is no use of it in Physick.

Gnaphalium [some call it Hires, some Mertryx, some Anaxeton some Anaphalis, ye Egyptians Semeon, ye French Gelasonen, ye Romans Centunculus, some Tucularis, some Albinus], some use the leaves of this instead of flocks, they being white & soft. But ye leaves being given to drink with hard wine are good for ye Dysentery.

Typhe sends out a leaf like to Cyperis, a stalk smooth & equal, compast about on ye top with a thick flower, which turns into down, which some call Panicula. The flowers of this being taken in old swines grease washed doth cure Ambusta. It grows in marshes & places standing with water.

Circea, but some call it Dircaea, hath leaves like unto garden Solanum, but many shoots, black flowers, small, many, & ye seed like Milium in certain (as it were) little horns, ye roots 3 or 4 of a span long, white, sweet-smelling, warming. It grows chiefly in some rocky, & wind-open sunny places. As much as 3 pounds of the root being bruised, & steeped a day & a night in 6 Hemine of sweet wine, & drank in 3 days doth cleanse ye matrix, but ye seed being taken in liquors to be supt, draws down ye milk.

Oenanthe, some call it Leucanthon [but some Kerascomion] hath ye leaves as it were of Staphulinus, but white flowers, & a thick stalk, a span long, but ye seed as it were of Atriplex, a great root, having many round heads. It grows on rocks. The seed of this & ye stalks & the leaves are given to drink with honeyed wine for ye casting of ye secondines, but ye root is good with wine for stranguries, & ye Icterus.

[Conyza magna, some call it Cynozematitis, some Danais, some Tanachium, some Phycos, some Ischys some Dinosmos, ye Magi Brephoctonos, some Anubias, some Hedemias, ye Egyptians Ceti, ye Romans Intubus, some Militaris mina, some Delliarion, some Febrifuga, some Phragmosa, some Musteri, some Pissan.]

Conyza, that which is called little, being of a better smell, but ye greater sort is higher in ye stalk & broader in ye leaves & of a strong scent, but both are like in the leaves to ye Olive, but these are rough & gross. But ye highth of ye stalk, the greater sort hath two of cubits, but ye lesser of a foot. Ye flower is foul, of a tawny yellow, somewhat bitter, falling into down. Ye roots are unuseful. The shrub being strewed under with the leaves, & suffumigated hath ye power to drive away poisonous beasts, & to keep off gnats, it kills also fleas. But the leaves are laid on profitably on ye serpent-bitten & swellings & wounds, & ye flower & ye leaves are drank with wine for ye expulsion of ye menstrua & ye casting out of ye Embryo & for ye strangury, & ye Tormina, & ye Icterus, but being drank with acetum they help ye epilepticall, & the decoction of them by way of insession do cure ye griefs in ye matrix & cleanse away the menstrua. And ye juice being applied causeth abortions. But ye herb being anointed on with oil also is good for rigors.
Being thin laid on it cureth also headaches, Conyza parua [some call it Panios, some Libanotis, ye Magi Cronos]

There is also a third kind of Conyza, but it is thicker, & softer in ye stalk but greater in ye leaves than ye smaller sort. It is lesser than ye greater, not fat, but of a great deal stronger smell, & more unpleasant, & less effectual; it grows in watery places.

Hemerocallis [some call it Hemerocatallacton, some Lilium sylvestre, some Crinanthemon, some Porphyranthes, some Bulbus sanguineus, some Anticantharon, ye Egyptians Iocroi, ye Romans Bulbus, some Lilium agreste, some Lilium marinum, ye Africans Abiblabon] hath leaves & a stalk like to ye Lilly, but green like Leeks, but ye flowers in 3s or 4s at every breaking out like in the cutting to ye Lilly when they shall begin to gap, having a colour very like ochre, a root like to a great Bulbus, which being small beaten & drank or applied with honey in wool, is a Pessum drawing out water, & drawing out blood. But ye leaves beaten small being applied do assuage ye inflammation of ye duggs which come by childbirths, & of ye eyes; & ye root & ye leaves are applied profitably upon ambusta.

Viola alba [some call it Basilion, ye Romans Opula alba, some Viola alba, some Augustia, some Viola matronalis, some Passarina, some Polyphura] is commonly known, but there is a difference of it in ye flower, for it is found either white, or yellowish, or azure, or else it is of a purple. But of these, ye fittest for medicinal use is the yellowish, of which ye dried flowers being sodden, are good by Insession for ye inflammations about ye matrix, & ye expelling ye menstrua. But being taken in Cerat they cure the chaps which are in ye seat, & with honey the Aphthas, but ye seed of it being drank with wine, ye quantity of 2 dragms, or applied as a Pessum with honey doth draw out ye menstrua, & ye secondines, & ye Embrya, but the roots being smeared on with acetum do repress ye spleen & help ye goutie.

Crataeogonon, some call it Crateonon, hath leaves like to those of Melampyrum, but many knotty shoots growing out of one root, but it hath a seed like to Milium. It grows as for ye most part in shady and shrubby places, but it is extremely sharp. It is said by some, that ye drinking of ye seed doth cause a woman to bring forth a male, if any after ye cleansing of ye menstrua, before ye time of conjunction do drink fasting, 3 times a day ye quantity of 3 Oboli with 2 Cyathi of water for 40 days, & let ye man drink it likewise as many days, and then lie with her.

Phyllon, some call it Elaeophyllon, some Bryonia, it grows on rocks. That which is called Thelygonon having as it were moss, the leaf greener than ye Olive, a thin short stalk, a slender root, a white flower, a greater seed, as it were of Poppy. But Arrhenogonon in other things is like to ye afore-spoken of but differs, having ye seed, like Olives coming in a cluster out of the flower. It is said that Arrhenogonon being drank bringeth males but ye Thelygonum causeth females. Carteuas relates this concerning these, but he seems to me, to relate these things, according to ye report of them.

Orchis, which some call Cynosorchis, hath leaves about ye stalk strewed upon ye earth, & the bottom of it, like to ye olive being tender, but narrower, & smooth, & longer, a stalk ye heighth of a span, on which are flowers of a purple hue: roote bulbous, somewhat long, narrow, as of ye Olive, double, the one above, ye other beneath, one full but the other soft & full of wrinkles, but ye root is eaten being sodden like a Bulbus. And of this it is said that if the greater roote is eaten by men, it makes them beget males, & the lesser, being eaten by women, to conceive females. It is further storied that ye women in Thessalia do give to drink with goates milke ye tenderer root to provoke Venerie, & the dry root for ye suppressing, dissolving of Venerie. And that it being drank, ye one is dissolved by the other. It grows in stony, & sandy places.

Testiculus alter, which some call Serapias, as Andreas doth for the manifold use of ye root, hath leaves like unto ye leek, somewhat long, but broader & fat, winding about in the wings, little stalks a span long, ye flowers almost purple, the root lies under like ye Testiculi, which being laid on, hath ye force of dissipating Oedemata, & of cleansing ulcers, & of repressing ye Herpes. It destroys also Fistulas, & assuageth ye inflamed parts being smeared on. And being sprinkled on dry stays ye Nome, & it cures ye belly, being drank with wine. There is ye like story told also of this, as there is of the dogs-stone.

Satyrium, but some call it Trifolium, because it bears leaves in 3s as it were, bending down to ye earth like to Rumex or Lilium, yet lesser, and reddish. But a naked stalk, long, as of a cubit; a flower like a Lilly, white; a bulbous root, as bigg as an apple, redd, but within white, like an egg, to ye taster sweet, & pleasant to ye mouth. This one ought to drink in black hard wine for ye Opisthotonon, & use it, if he will lie with a woman. For they say that this also doth stirr up courage in ye conjunction.

Satyrium Erythronium, some call it Satyrium Erythraicum [some Melium aquaticum, some Entaticon, or Priapiscus, or Morion or Satyriscus, or testiculum Satyri, ye Romans Molorticulum Veneris] hath a seed like to flax seed, but greater, & firm, & glittering, & smooth. It is said that it doth stirr up conjunctions, like ye Scincus doth. The bark of ye root of it is somewhat thin & red, but ye inside white, pleasant to ye mouth to him that tastes it, & sweet. It grows in sunny, & hilly places. It is storied that the root being taken into ye hand doth provoke to Venerie, but much more, being drank with wine.

Sative Horminum [ye Romans call Geminalis, ye Dacians Hormia] is an herb like to Marrubium in ye leaves, but ye stalk 4-cornered half a cubit high, about which are excrescencies like to husks, as it were looking towards ye root, in which is a different seed, for in the wild it is found round swart, but in the other somewhat long, and black, of which there is use, & this also is thought being drank with wine to provoke conjunction. But with Honey it cleanseth away ye Argema & ye Albugines of ye eyes, & being smeared on with water it dissolves Oedemata & draws out splinters, and ye herb being applied, doth perform ye same things. But ye wild hath a stronger force, whence also it is mixed with compound ointments, especially with Gleucinum.

Hedysarum called Pelecinus by ye Unguentarii, is a shrub having little leaves like to Cicer, but cods like little horns, in which is ye red seed, like to an axe that hath 2 edges, whence also it is named, bitter to him that tastes it, good for ye stomach being drank; it is mixed also with Antidots, but being taken as a Peessum with honey before ye conjunction, it is thought to hinder conception. It grows amongst barley & wheat.

Onosma, but some call it Osmas, some Phlonitis, some Ononis, hath the leaves like to those of Anchusa, somewhat long, soft, ye length as of 4 fingers, but the breadth of a finger, strewed on ye earth, very like to those of Anchusa, but it is without stalk, without seed, without flower. The little root lies under, somewhat long, weak, thin, a little reddish. It grows in rough places. The leaves of this being drank in wine expel ye Embryo. They say also that if one with childe go over this herb she makes abortion.

Nymphea grows in marshes & standing waters, but it hath leaves like to ye Egyptian bean yet lesser & somewhat longer, many of ye self-same root, some in a manner standing above ye water, & others also in ye water. Ye flower white, like a Lilly having ye middle of a saffron dye, but when it hath done blowing it becomes round in the circumference like to an apple, or ye head of Poppy, black, in which is a black seed, broad, thick, clammy to ye taste, but ye stalk smooth, not thick, black, like to that of ye Egyptian bean. Ye root black, rugged like a sceptre, which is cut in the Autumn. This then being dry, & drank with wine, doth help ye Coeliaci, and dysentericall, & abates ye spleen, but ye root is applied for ye griefs of ye stomach & bladder, & with water takes away ye Alphi, & being laid on with pitch it cures ye Alopecie. The root is drank also for leacherous dreams, for it doth allay these, & it works a faintness of ye privity for a few days, if one drink it continually, & the seed also being drank doth ye same. But it seems to be called Nymphaea because it loves a watery place. It is found much as Helis on ye river Anigrus, & in Aliartus of Boeotia.

There is also another Nymphaea [some call it Nymphona] of which ye flower is called Nuphar, having leaves like to ye aforesaid, but it hath a white & rugged root, a yellowish flower, glittering, like to a Rose, but ye root, & ye seed being drank in black wine is good for ye flux of women. It grows in places about Thessalia by the river Peneus.

Androsaces [but some call it Picras, some Leuce, some Thalassia] grows in Syria in Sea-bordering places, but ye herb is thin, with slender branches, bitter, leaf-less, having on the head a cod containing ye seed. Being drank with wine ye quantity of 2 dragms, it hath ye force to provoke much urine in ye hydropicall, & ye decoction of ye herb & ye seed being drank, performs ye same. It is smeared on also profitably upon the gouty.

Asplenon, some call it Scolopendrium, some Splenium, some Hemionion, some Pteryx [some Lonchitis, some Aturius, some Phrygia, some Phrygitis, some Philtrodotes, ye Magi ye blood of a weasel] hath leaves like ye creature Scolopendra, many growing round about out of one root. It grows upon walls, and shady rocks that are of pebble stones, stalk-less, flower-less, seed-less, cut in, as those of Fern, beneath yellowish & rough, but above green. But ye leaves being sodden with Acetum, & drank for 40 days hath ye power to abate ye spleen, but you must also anoint ye spleen with ye leaves beaten small with wine. It helps also ye strangury, ye Singultus, & ye Icterus, & breaks ye stones that are in ye bladder. It is thought to be a causer of barrenness of itself, or being hung about one with ye spleen of a mule, but they say that this to cause barrenness, must be digged up when ye night is moonless.

Hemionitis, but some call it Splenium, puts out a leaf like to Dracunculus, horned like ye 3rd day moon. Ye roots are under, many, slender, but it bears neither stalk nor seed, nor flower. It grows in rocky places; but ye herb is astringent to ye taster, which being drank with Acetum doth abate ye spleen.

Anthyllis [but some call it Anthyllon, some Anthemis, some Eranthemis, some Leucanthemon, some Soranthis, some Flos campestris, ye Romans Solaster] is twofold, for one hath leaves like unto Lens, & a little branches ye heighth of a span, but upright, & ye leaves soft, but ye root slender & little. It grows in sandy & sunny places, somewhat salt to ye taster.

But ye other kind, is like in ye leaves & small branches to Chamepitys but they are rougher & shorter & sharper. The flower is of a purple colour, smelling extremly strong, ye root as it were of Cichorie. It is of force mightily to help ye dysureticall & nephriticall, being drank ye quantity of 4 dragms. But being beaten small, & given as a Pessum with Rosaceum & milk, they do mollify ye inflammations which are in ye matrix. They do also heal wounds, but that which is like Chamepitys amongst other things, doth heal also ye Epilepticall being drank with Oxymel.

Anthemis which some call Leucanthemon, some Eranthemon, because it doth flower in ye spring, some Chamemelum, because of ye likeness of it in smell to apples [some Melanthemon, some Chrysocome, some Callias, ye Romans Malium, the Africans Astertiphe] of this there are 3 kinds, differing only in ye flowers, ye branches a span long, shrubby, having many wings; ye small branches, little, thin, many, little heads of a round compass, within ye flowers of gold colour, but without there lie round about, white or yellowish or purple leaves, of ye bigness of those Rue. It grows in rough places, & by the ways. It is gathered in ye spring. But ye roots, and ye flowers, & ye herb have a warming, extenuating faculty. But being drank, or by Insession, they expell ye menstrua, & ye Embryo, & ye stones, & ye urine. It is drank also for the inflations, & for ye torments of ye Ileus, & they cleanse away the icterus & cure ye Hepaticall, & ye decoction of them is taken in fomentations which are for ye bladder. But ye most effectuall for ye troubled with ye stone is that of a purple colour, which in all respects is ye greater, being properly called Eranthemon, but that which is called Leucanthemon is more ureticall as also ye Chrysanthemon. They do also cure Egilopses being smeared on. But being chewed they cure ye Aptha. Some also use it for a glister with oil, beating them small, also for recurrent fevers. Ye leaves, & the flowers must be laid up when they have been beaten apart & made them into little balls; but ye root, when they have dried it. When there is need of it, give sometimes of ye herb 2 parts, some times of ye flower or ye the root one part. Sometimes on ye contrary, of the flower 2 parts & of the herb one, doubling it by turn each other day; but you must drink it in mulso diluto. [Camomell being beaten small, with Rosaceum it doth cure ye feverish. It is a profitable plant for such as are reasonable well. But ye short & best grows in sandy places, which Physicians take away at ye beginning of ye Spring.]

Parthenium, but some call it Amaracum, some Leucanthemon [some Anthemis, some Chamemelum, some Chrysocalis, some Melabathrum, some Flos campestris, ye Romans Solis oculus, or Millefolium, ye Hetruscians Cautan, ye Africans Thamacth] hath leaves like Coriander, thin, ye flowers white in a circle but ye middle yellow, somewhat poisonous in ye smell & bitterish to ye tast. It is of force, being dried, & drank with oxymel, or with salt to drive out Phlegm, & cholera downward, & to help the Asthmaticall, & melancholicall. But ye herb without ye flower is profitably given in drink to ye Calculosi & ye Asthmatici. But ye decoction of it is a fit Insession for an hardened and enflamed womb. It is applied also with ye flowers for ye Erysipelata & inflammations.

Buphthalmum, but some call it Cachlan [some Balsamina, the Magi Haemorrha, some genitura Mercurü, some semen incorruptibile, some Mnesitheos, ye Romans Kappacorania, ye Africans, Narat] sends out tender little stalks somewhat slender, but ye leaves of ye fashion of Fennill, yellowish flowers, greater than Anthemis, like unto eyes, whence also it is named. It grows in fields & about towns. The flowers of this being beaten small with Cerat do dissolve ye oedemata and hardnesses. They say also that in a bath being drank after ye coming out thence, it causeth a good colour to ye Ictericall for some time. [You must gather Buphthalmum the moone increasing. It is of force against fears & devils & enchantments and poisons, turning aside these things, & if any having chewed ye root do after spit it out, forthwith stopping ye rhume it easeth ye tooth & it looseneth ye belly.]

Peonia, or Glycyside, some call it Pentoboron [ye male Peonie, some Orobelium, some Orobax, some Haemagogum, some Paeseden some Menogenion, some Menion, some Paeonium, some Panthiceratos], some Idaei dactyli, some Aglaophotis, some Theodonium, some Selenion, the Magi Selenogonon, some Phthisi, ye Romans Casta] they call ye root Paeonia. The stalk grows upon high as two spans having many branches. The male hath leaves like ye Walnut, but the female is jagged in ye leaves like Smyrnium. It sends out certain codds on the top of ye stalk like unto almonds, which being opened there are found many red grains, little, like to those of ye pommegranate, black in ye middle, inclining to purple, five or six. Ye root of the male is about ye thickness of a finger & ye highth of a span, astringent to ye taster, white, but on ye root of ye female having 7 or 8 extuberations like acorns as Asphodelus. The root is given to women who after childbirth are not cleansed. It moves also ye menstrua being drank ye bigness of an almond & it helps the pains in ye belly being drank with wine. And it doth help the Ictericall, & nephriticall & ye pained in ye bladder. Being sodden in wine, and being drank doe stop ye belly. But of ye seed 10 or 12 red grains being drank in black hard wine stay ye red flux (in women), & being eaten they help such as feel gnawings at ye stomach, & being drank, & eaten by children they take away ye beginnigs of ye stone. But the black are good both for the suffocations that come of nightmares, & for ye suffocations of ye womb, & griefs of ye mother, being drank as much as 15 grains in Melicrat or wine. But Peony grows on ye highest mountains, & the tops of them. [The herb Peony is plucked up in ye heat of ye dog days before the rising of ye sun & it is hanged about one & is good against poisons & bewitchings & fears & devils & their assaults, & against a fever that comes with shivering, whether by night or by day, or a quartan. And it is said that sometimes growing on an hill where there were devils, it drove them away].

Lithospermon, some call it Aegonychon, some Exonychon [Some Leontion, some Lapis Leoninus, some Gorgonium, some Tantalitis, some Diosporon, ye Romans Columba, ye Dacians Gonoleta]. Some call it Heraclean because of ye strength of ye seed, whence also it is called Lithospermon. It hath leaves like those of ye Olive, but longer & broader and softer, & those about ye bottom lie on the ground; the small branches are straight, slender, ye thickness of ye sharp bulrush, strong, woody but on ye cloven top of them a springing-out like Cauliculi, having long leaves amongst which is a round, white stony seed, like to ye little Ervum. It grows in rough, and eminent places. The seed being drank with white wine hath ye power to break ye stone & expell ye urine.

Phalaris sends out little stalks from slender & unuseful roots, many, of 2 hands breadth, knotty, like reeds, resembling those of Zea, yet slenderer, & sweet in taste, but ye leaves are like to those of Zea. The seed is of ye bigness of Milium, white somewhat long. But ye herb being cut, & juiced by water or wine, & so drank, hath ye power to be effectuall for ye griefs of ye bladder & ye seed, ye quantity of a spoonfull being drank with water is good for ye same purposes.

Eruthrodanum [some call it Erythodanon ye root, some Dracons, some Cinnabaris, ye Romans Rubia passiva, ye Hetruscians Lappa minor, ye Egyptians Sophobi] or Ereuthodanum, but some call it Teuthrion. The root is red, fit for dying. Some of it is wild, some sown, as in Thabana of Galilee, & Rauenna of Italy, & in Caria being sown amongst the olives, as in ye fields. And it is sown profitably, because there is made much gain of it. But ye stalks of it are 4 cornered long, rough, like to those of Aparine, but in every respect greater & stronger, having ye leaves by distances at every joint, lying about like stars in a circle; ye seed round, at ye first green, afterward red, after when it is ripe, black. The root thin, long, red, diureticall; whence being drank with melicrate it helps ye Ictericall & ye Ischiaticall & ye Paralyticall: It drives out much & thick urine, & sometimes also blood. But yet they who drink it must be washed every day & the difference of ye voided excrements viewed. And ye stalk being drank with ye leaves doth help ye bitten of venemous beasts, but ye stalk being drank with Oxymel abates ye spleen. Ye root put up as a Pessum, expels ye Embryo, & ye menstrua, & ye secondines. It doth cure also the white Vitiligines, being smeared on with Acetum.

Lonchitis [which some call Cestron, or Medusa, ye Romans Venerea, or Lanceola] hath leaves very like to ye Leek, yet broader, & many somewhat red, broken about towards the root, as it were lying on the ground. It hath also a few about ye stalk, on which are flowers like little hats, in fashion like to Comical Persons gaping, & they black, but some white thing ariseth from them, from the gaping towards ye lower lip, as it were a little tongue. But the seed is shut in 3-cornered cases like to a spearhead, whence also it was thought worthy of ye surname. The root is like unto Daucus. It grows in rough and dry places. The root of this is diureticall being drank with wine.

Lonchitis altera, but some call it ye rough Lonchitis, sends out leaves like to Scolopendrium, but sharper & greater & more jagged. It hath power of curing wounds, & of freeing from inflammations, & it abates also ye spleen, being drank with Acetum.

Althaea but some call it Ibiscus, some Althiocon, is a kind of wild mallow, ye leaves round as Cyclaminus, downy. It hath a rose-like flower, ye stalk of 2 cubits, a clammy root, white within. But it is called Althaea for ye much vertue & divers use of it. For being sod in Melicrate or wine, or beaten of itself, it is good for wounds, ye Parotides, ye struma, Suppurations, enflamed duggs, ye griefs of the seats, bruises, flatulent tumors, ye distentions of ye nerves, For it dissolves, & ripens, or breaks & brings to a Cicatrix. But being sodden as is said & kneaded together with swines grease or goose grease, or turpentine, it is good in a Pessum for ye inflammations & preclusions of ye matrix, and the decoction of it performes the same, expelling also ye so-called after-purgaments. And the decoction of ye root being drank with wine doth help ye dysentericall, ye ischiaticall, ye tremblers, ye troubled with ruptures & assuageth ye pains of ye teeth, being sodden with vinegar, & ye mouth washed with it. But ye seed either green, or dry, being beaten small, & anointed on with acetum in ye sun, is a cleanser of ye vitiligines. But being anointed on with Oxelaeum, it is a preventer of being hurt by poisonous beasts. It is effectuall also against dysenteries, & ye casting up of blood, & ye belly flux. But ye decoction of the seed being drank, is good against ye stings of bees and of all small beasts, being drank in wine, or Posca; & ye leaves with a little oil are laid upon the bitings, & upon such as are Ambusti. And ye root also doth thicken water being mixt when it is beaten small, & set abroad withall in ye open air.

Alcea, & this also is a kind of wild mallow having leaves cut in near like those of ye holy herb. Stalks 3 or 4 having a bark like to Cannabis, a little fower like ye Rose, 5 or 6 broad white roots, almost a cubit long, which being drank with wine or water doe cure ye Dysentery & ruptures.

Cannabis [some call it Cannabium, some Schoenostrophon, some Asterion, ye Romans Cannabis] is a plant of much use in this life for ye twistings of very strong ropes, it bears leaves like to the Ash, of a bad scent, long stalks, empty, a round seed, which being eaten of much doth quench geniture, but being juiced when it is green is good for the pains of the ears.

Cannabis sylvestris [some call it Hydrastina, ye Romans Terminalis some Cannabis] bears little rods like to those of Althea, but blacker & sharper & smaller; but ye leaves like to ye sative but sharper and blacker; ye flowers reddish like to Lychnis, but ye seed & roote like to Althea. The root being sodden, & so laid on hath ye force to assuage inflammations & to dissolve Oedemata, & to disperse ye obdurate matter about ye joints. Ye bark also of this, is fitting for ye twining of ropes.

Anagyris, but some call it Anagyros, some Acopon [some Agnacopum] is a shrub like a tree, in ye leaves, & ye rods, very like Agnus castus, of an extreme strong scent. The flower like to Brassica, ye seed in long little horns, of ye fashion of kidneys, divers coloured, solid. But it is hardened about ye ripening of the grape. The tender leaves of this being beaten small & so laid on do repress ye Oedemata. It is given to drink ye quantity of a dragm, in Passum for ye Asthma, & ye casting out of ye Secondine, & ye menstrua, & ye Embryo. But for ye headache with wine. It is to be hanged like an Amulet on such as have hard labours, yet one must at once after ye womans delivery take off ye Amulet & cast it away. But ye juice of ye root doth dissolve, and ripen. And the seed being eaten provokes vomiting mightily.

Cepea is like to Portulaca, yet it hath blacker leaves, a thin root. But ye leaves being drank with wine doe help ye strangury-sick, and such as have a scabbed bladder, & it doth doe it most when it is drank with ye decoction of ye roots of Asparagus which is called Myacanthus.

Alisma, but some call it Alcea, some Damassonium, some Acyron some Lyron, hath leaves like to Plantaine, but narrower & bending down toward ye earth, but ye stalk slender, single, higher than a cubit, having little heads like a Thyrsus; ye flowers thin, white, somewhat pale; ye roots, as of black Ellebore, thin, sweet-smelling sharp, somewhat gross; it loves watery places. The root being drank with wine as much as 1 or 2 dragms is good for such as have eaten a Sea hare, & those which are bitten of a toad & such as have drank Opium. And it helps ye tormina & dysentery by itself, or drank with as much Daucus seed. It is good also for convulsions & for ye griefs of ye matrix. But ye herb itself stops ye belly & expells ye menstrua & being laid on assuageth ye Oedemata.

Onobrychis [some call it Onobrochilos, some Eschasmene, some Hypericum, some Corion, some Chamepitys, ye Romans Opaca, some Brichilata, some Lopta, some Iuncinalis, ye Dacians Anias-sexe] hath leaves like to Lens, but a little longer, a stalk a span long, a purple flower, a small root. It grows in moist, & restie places. But ye herb being beaten small & smeared on hath ye power to dissolve tubercula, & being drank with wine it cures the Strangury, & being anointed on with oil it provokes sweats.
171. UPERIKON. Hypericum crispum or H. barbatum

Hypericum, but some call it Androsemon, some Corion, some Chamepitys, because that the seed is like in smell to ye rosin of ye Pine. It hath leaves like to Rue. A shrub full of branches a span high, reddish, having a yellowish flower which being crushed with ye fingers yieldeth a bloody juice, whence also it is called Androsemon; ye small twigs somewhat rough, long in ye Compasse, of ye bigness of barley, in which is a black seed smelling of rosin. It grows in tilled, and rough places. But it hath a diureticall faculty, & of moving ye menstrua being put up as a Pessum, & being drank with wine it drives away tertians & quartans. And the seed being drank for forty days together doth cure ye Sciatica, & ye leaves being laid on together with ye seed doe heal Ambusta.

Ascyron, but some call it Ascyroides, some Androsemon, & this also is a kind of Hypericum, differing in greatness being greater in ye branches, more full of spriggs, & with the small leaves looking of a purple colour; it bears yellow flowers, but ye fruit like to Hypericum, smelling of Rosin & in being bruised, as it were, staining with blood ye fingers, so that it is called Androsemon for this. And ye fruit of this is available for Sciaticas, being drank with 2 Hemine of Hydromel. For it expells many cholerick excrements. But it must be given continually until that they be cured, & being smeared on it is good for Ambusta.
°173. ANDROSAIMON. Hypericum perfoliatum or H. ciliatum Sibth

Androsemon, but some call it Dionysias, some also call this Ascyron yet it differs from Hypericum and from Ascyrum, it being a shrub of thin branches, full of sprigs, ye little rods dyeing of a purple colour, ye leaves are 3 times or 4 times bigger than Rue, which being bruised send out a juice wine-like. But it hath many wings on the top, open on each side, & feathered, about which are small little flowers of a yellowish colour. Ye seed in a little cup, like to that of black Poppy, as it were, marked with lines & points. But ye hair being bruised yields a Rosin-like smell. And ye seed of this, beaten small, & ye quantity of two dragms drank, expells cholerick excrements, but especially it cures Sciaticas. But a man must after ye purging, sup up water. And ye herb being smeared on heals ambusta & stops blood.

Coris, but some also call this Hypericum, hath a leaf like to that of Erica, but lesser and fatter and red. But it is a shrub a span long, well relishing, sharp & of a good smell. The seed of this being drank with wine, moveth ye urine & menstrua & helps ye bitten of a Phalangium, & ye Ischiaticall, and ye Opisthotonicall, & for Rigors being drank with Pepper, & it is also a profitable ointment for ye opisthotonicall with oil. [But ye root of this being sodden with wine & drank, is thought very much to help such as faint. But it behoves the patient when he drinks it to be well covered all over; for it causeth ye whole body to sweat, & from this hee recovers agility.

Chamepitys [some call it Pitusorusis, some Orizelon, they in Pontus call Holocyron or wilde Bryonie, ye Athenians Ionia, but in Euboea Sideritis, ye Magi sanguis Minervae, ye Romans Cupripum, ye Dacians Dochela] which is an herb creeping upon ye ground, bow backed, but it hath leaves like to ye lesser Sempervivum, but much thinner & fatter & rough, thick about ye branches, having ye smell of ye Pine. ye flowers thin, yellow, [or white] but ye root as of Chichory. The leaves of this being drank with wine for 7 days do cure the Icterus. But being drank with Hydromel for 40 days, do cure ye Ischias. It is given also to ye hepaticall & dysureticall, & nephriticall properly, being good also for ye torminosi. And they also in Heraclea of Pontus use it as an Antidot, giving ye decoction to drink against Aconitum. And with Polenta moistened with ye decoction of ye herb it is applied for ye aforesaid purposes. But being beaten small with figs & given like a pill, it mollifies ye belly. But being taken with Honey & squama aeris and Rosin, it purgeth. And applied as a Pessum with honey it expells things from ye womb. It dissovles also hardnesses of ye duggs, & conglutinates wounds, & represseth ye Herpetas, being smeared on with honey.

There is also another Chamepitys having branches a cubit long, curved in fashion of an anchor, with thin sprigs, but an hair like the last, & a white flower, but a black seed. And this also smells of ye Pine.

And there is a third kind called ye Male. But it is a smooth little herb having thin small leaves, white, rough, but a rugged white, stalk, small yellowish flowers, & a little seed by the wings. And this also smells of ye Pine. And these also have ye like force to the afore-spoken of, but yet not soe effectuall.

roprieties of places, & their peculiar natures & the airs & not a few other things. But for ye most part, that is best which is pure & sweet, unpartaking any other whatsoever quality, & not staying in ye Hypochondrions ye least time, & furthermore soon passing without trouble, & not inflative, nor corrupted.

In the three books before this, best beloved Areius, having spoken of Aromaticall matters and Oils and Ointments and Trees and Living creatures and Corn and Pot herbs and Roots and Juices and Herbs and of Seeds. In this being the fourth book we will discourse of ye Herbes and Roots left unspoken of.
The figure is not of a Labiate plant

Cestron that which is called Psychotrophon because it is found in the coldest places, which ye Romans call Vetonica or Rosmarinus, is an herb having a thin stalk ye highth of a cubit, or more, 4 cornered, ye leaves long, soft, like to ye oak jagged round about, smelling well, but they are greater towards ye root, & on the top of ye stalks lies ye seed encased in an ear as of Thymbra. They ought when gathering ye leaves, to dry them, of which there is also ye most use. The roots are under, thin as of Ellebore, which being drank with Hydromel do provoke a vomit casting up phlegmy stuff. There is given of ye leaves ye quantity of a dragm being drank with hydromel for ye convulsions, ruptures, & for ye disaffections which are in ye matrix, & womb stranglings, & to ye bitten of venemous beasts 3 dragms with 2 Hemine of wine. And the herb being applied doth help ye venemous-beast-bitten, and a dragm being drank with wine, helps against deadly poisons. And if any drink it before hand, he shall take no hurt although he take a deadly medicine. It is also ureticall & a looser of the belly. It doth cure also ye Epilepticall, & ye frantick, being drank with water, & ye Hepaticall & Spleneticall being drank ye quantity of 1 dragm with Oxymel. It maketh also digestion if after supper one swallow down ye bigness of a beane with sodden honey. In like sort also it is given to ye troubled with sour belchings, but to ye stomachicall to chew, & swallow down the juice & then after to sup up diluted wine. It is given also to ye blood-spitter ye quantity of 3 Oboli with one Cyathus of diluted wine, milk-warm, & to ye Ischiaticall & nephriticall & bladder-grieved with water. But to ye hydropicall 2 dragms with Hydromel if they have a fever, but if they be without one, with mulsum. And ye quantity of 1 dragm being drank with wine relieveth ye Ictericall, & drives out ye menstrua. And 4 dragms being drank with 10 Cyathi of Hydromel do purge. And it is good for ye phthisicall, & spitters of Pus, with honey, but the leaves must be laid up, dried & beaten small in an earthen vessel.

Britannica or Vettonica is an herb having leaves like to Lapathum sylvestre, but blacker, & more hairy, binding in the taste. It sends out a stalk not great, a thin and short root. But the leaves of it are juiced, & thickened by stirring in ye sun or the fire. It hath a binding faculty properly serving for the nomae in ye mouth, & the Tonsillae. And it is available for all things else that need binding.

[Betonie grows in meadows, & hilly & clean and mild places, about the shrubs. It keeps both the soules & bodies of men. It is effectual against both night-walkings & harmful places, & difficult sleeps, & it is commended for all manner of cures. It hath a root all red and of a good scent, but ye leaves leekish, & the middle of ye leaves of a reddish colour, and three cornered into an upright stalk, and upon them flowers of a purple colour. And ye force of it is this. For being bruised when it is new, and laid on to a broken head upon the wound it makes it painless, & it conglutinates wounds, and it draws out broken bones. And it doth this being changed day by day, till it be healed. But being sodden with water it heals ye headache being fomented on & being anointed about ye temples with bitumen, ye root also being suffumigated unto them.]

Lysimachia, but some call it Lytron, sends out stalks a cubit high or rather higher, thin, at ye joints of which are putting out of thin leaves like to those of ye willow, binding in the taste. The flower red, or of a golden colour. It grows in marshy places, & near waters. But ye juice of ye leaves being binding, a potion of it, or glyster is good for ye casting up of blood, and dysenteries. And, in a Pessum it stays ye womanish flux & for ye issue of blood out of ye nostrils ye herb being stuft in is profitable. And it is also a woundherb & stauncher of blood. And being suffumigated it hath a most sharp fume, so that it both drives away serpents, & kills flies.

Polygonon ye male [some call it Polygonaton, some Cynochalem, some Herculea, some Asphalton, some Chiliophullon, some Clema, some Polycarpon, some Carcinethron, some Peuthalida, some Myrtopetalon, some Cnopodion, some Zarithea, some Pedalion, ye Egyptians Thephin, some Stemphin, The Magi genitura Herois, some Unguis muris, ye Romans Seminalis, some Stopinaca, ye Africans Chulum] is an herb having slender branches, tender, many, compast about with joints, creeping upon ye earth as grass, but ye leaves like those of Rue, but somewhat longer, & softer. It hath ye seed by every leaf, whence also it is called ye Male, but ye flower white or purple. But ye juice being drank, hath a binding refrigerating faculty. It is commodious for ye blood-spitters, & ye fluxes by the belly, & for ye sick of choler, & ye strangury. It moves ye urine also manifestly, & it helps ye venemous-beast-bitten, being drank with wine, & ye circuits of agues, being taken one hour before ye fit. It stops also ye womanish flux taken as a Pessum, & it is good for ear-griefs & ye mattering of them, being dropt in. But being sodden with wine & withall taking honey, it doth excellent well for the ulcers in ye privities. But ye leaves are laid on for ye burning of ye stomach, & ye casting up of blood & for ye Herpetes, & Erysipelata, & inflammations, & wounds newly made.

Polygonon ye female [ye Romans call it Seminalis] is a little shrub with one stalk, tender, like a reed having continued joints lying one upon another, as it were of a trumpet, and round about ye joints, small leaves like those of ye Pine, ye root for no use It grows in watery places. It hath a binding, cooling faculty doing ye same things to that before it, because it is not weaker.

Polygonatum grows upon hills, a shrub higher than a cubit, having leaves like ye Laurel, but broader, and smoother, somewhat like to ye taster to a quince or ye Pomegranate, for it tastes with binding, but at every putting out of ye leaves, are white flowers, in multitude exceeding the leaves, the number being reckoned from the root. But it hath a white root soft, long, with many joints, thick, strong scented, having ye thickness of a finger, being good when it is laid on for wounds, & it takes away also ye spots which are in the face.

Clematis, but some call it Daphnoides, some Myrsinoides, some Polygonoides [some Philetaerium]. It grows in good land, but it hath small vine-like branches, as much as ye thickness of a juncus, a little leaf, like to ye Laurel both in figure & in ye colour but much lesser. The leaves & ye stalks of this being drank with wine do assuage ye belly flux, & ye dysentery, and applied in a Pessum with milk & Rosaceum or Cyprinum, it cures ye pains of ye matrix, & being chewed it easeth ye pains of ye teeth, & being applied it helps ye venemous-beast-bitten. And it is said also, that being drank with Acetum it helps ye Aspick-bitten. It grows in untilled ground.

[There is another Clematis, which some call Epigetis, ye Egyptians Phylacuum, ye Romans Ambuxus, sends out a vine-like-branch, reddish, flexible, ye leaf extreme sharp to ye taster, and exulcerating. It is clasped about trees like a Smilax. The seed of this being beaten small, & drank with water, or Hydromel, doth drive phlegm, & choler downward. But ye leaves laid on as a cataplasme drive away leprosies. They are preserved with Lepidium for meat.]

Polemonia, but some call it Philetaeria, ye Cappadocians call it Chiliodynamis. It has little thin branches, winged, but leaves a little greater than Rue, but longer aunswerable to those of Polygonum, or of Calaminth, but on ye top of them are as it were Corymbi, in which is a black seed. Ye root a cubit long, whitish, like to Struthium. It grows in hilly and rough places. The root of this is drank in wine against venemous beasts, & ye Dysentery, & ye Dysurie, and the Sciatica, with water. It is given to ye splenicall, as much as a dragm, with Acetum. And ye roote of this is hanged about one against ye stroke of a Scorpion. And they say that they which have this shall not be beaten & though they be smitten, yet they shall suffer nothing; & being chewed it easeth also ye toothache.

Symphitum Petraeum grows on rocks. It hath little branches like Origanum, thin leaves, but little heads as of Thyme. But the whole is woody, & of a sweet smell & sweet to the taste, & provoking spittle. It hath a long root, of a faint purple, almost ye thickness of a finger. This being sodden with Melicrate, and drank doth rid up noysome stuff from ye lungs. And it is given with water to such as cast up blood, & to ye nephriticall. And being sod with wine it is drank for ye dysentery, & ye womanish red flux, but with oxymel for Convulsions & ruptures, & being chewed it is a quencher of thirst. And it is good for ye roughness of ye sharp artery, & it conglutinates new wounds, & represseth ye Enterocelas used as a cataplasme, & it makes to join together, pieces of flesh being sodden with them.

Symphyton alterum, some call it Pecton [ye Romans Solidago] sends out a stalk 2 cubits high, or rather more, light, thick, cornery, empty, like that of Sonchus. About which come, from not great distances, rough leaves, narrow, somewhat long, like those of Buglosse. But ye stalk hath some puttings out, stretching along at the corners of slender leaves cleaving to it: from every wing are ye flowers standing over, yellowish; & ye seed is about the stalk as of Verbascum. Ye whole stalk, & ye leaves, have a somewhat prickly down, causing an itching by the touch. The roots are under, to ye outward appearance black, but within white, & slamy, of which also there is use. They being beaten small, & drank, are good for ye blood-spitters, and ruptures, & being applied they close up new wounds. And being sodden with them they join pieces of flesh together. But they are smeared on for inflammations, most profitably for those in ye seat with ye leaves of Senecio.

Holostium is a little herb, above ye ground about 3 or four fingers. But it hath leaves and tendrills near to those of Coronopis, or grass, binding; a root very thin, like hair, white to see to, ye thickness of 4 fingers. It grows on hillocks. And this can also, being sodden with them join pieces of flesh together, & it is given to be drank with wine for ruptures.

Stoebe [some call it Tobion, ye Romans Stupa] is well known, of which ye seed, & the leaves bind, whence also ye decoction of them is given for a glister to ye dysentericall, it is also droped into ears that are purulent. But ye leaves being applied helps ye blood-shottenness of ye eyes, that comes by a stroke, & stays ye bloody flux.

Clymenon [but some call it Calycanthemom, some Periclymenon, some Helyophyes, some Hepatitis, some Smilax, some Anatolicon, some Dyticon, some Merginem, ye Romans Volucrum, or Volucrum maius, ye Egyptians Oxiui, Clymenon, some Clumenion, which they also call Agonon] send out a stalk 4-square like to that of ye Bean, but leaves suitable to those of Plantain. But it hath little cods on the stalk nodding to one another, like to Iris, & ye curled tufts of ye Polypus. But that on ye hills is the best. It is all juiced together with ye root. The juice being drank is good for ye casting up of blood, & for ye Coeliacalls, & for ye red flux, binding & cooling, & it stoppeth issues of blood which come out of ye nostrils, but ye leaves beaten small, or ye cods applied to new wounds brings them effectually to a Cicatrix.

Periclymenon [some call it Aegine, some Clymenon, some Carpathum, some Splenium, some Hepatitis, some Helxine major, some Clematitis, some Myrsine, some Calycanthemon, the Magi Poliom Veneris, ye Egyptians Turcum the Romans volucrum majus, ye Africans Lanath], is a little shrub, single, having by distances small leaves encompassing him, whitish, like Ivy, & by the leaves’ shootings out, are the seeds like to Ivy, on top is a white flower like the bean, an hard seed, somewhat round, in a manner lying upon the leaf and hard to be plucked out: ye root thick, & round, It grows in fields, & hedges, & winds itself about ye neighbouring shrubs. The seed of this being gathered when it is ripe, and dried in the shade, is drank ye quantity of a dragm, for 40 days & it abates ye spleen, & dissolves weariness, & is good for ye orthopnea, & ye singultus. After ye sixth day it makes one piss blood. It is also a birth-quickener & ye leaves also have the same force, being drank 37 days, & it is said, to make men unfit for generation, & being anointed on with oil on such as have ague fits by set returns, it drives away ye shiverings.

Tribulus is of two kinds: ye land kind is like in ye leaves to Portulaca, which yet are thin, & ye vine-like branches long, strewed on ye ground, and on them prickles stiff, & hard. It grows near rivers, & in courts by houses. There is another kind also, of ye water, [which some call Bucephalus, some Tauroceros, ye Romans Tribulus aquaticus] growing in rivers, with ye haire standing above but hiding the prickle. The leaves broad, having a long stem, but ye stalk thick at ye top, rather than in ye bottom. There are on it also certain hairy excrescencies like ears: ye fruit as that of ye other, is hard. But they both do bind & cool, & are cataplasmes for all inflammations. But with honey they heal ye Aphthae & ye Tonsillae, & ye rotten ulcers of ye mouth & ye gums. They are juiced also for eye medicines: the seed of them being drank while it is new doth help ye stone-sick. As much as a dragm of ye land kind being drank, & applied doth recover ye viper-bitten, & it is good against poisons being drank with wine & the decoction of it being sprinckled kills fleas. And ye Thracians dwelling by ye river Strymon do fat horses with ye herb being green but ye seed being sweet & nourshing they take for food, using it instead of bread.

[Saxifragum, which some call Saxifrangum, or Empetrum, some Scolopendrium or Bruchum, the Romans Saxifraga or Sanaria, is a shrub growing on rocks and in rough places, like Epithymon. The herb sod with wine hath a helpful faculty in cases of strangury and when there is no fever, but it is given with warm water while the fever lasts. It also cures the stones in the bladder, and drives the urine.]

Limonium which some call Neuroides, [some Potamogeton, some Lonchitis, some Rapronium, ye Mysians Mendruta, ye Syrians Meuda, some Lycosemphyllon, some Helleborosemata, some Scyllion, ye Magi Cor Lupi, ye Romans Veratrum nigrum, some Tintinabulum terrae, ye French Iumbarum, ye Dacians Dacina] hath the leaves like to ye beet, yet thinner, and lesser, ten or more a thin stalk, upright, equal as it were to ye Lilly, full of red seed, binding by the taste. The seed beaten small & drank with wine ye quantity of an Acetabulum, is of force to help ye dysentericall, and coeliacall, & to stay ye womanish red flux. It grows in fields.
Figure is not of Trifolium but possibly Echinops

Lagopus [but some call it Cuminum Leporis] hath a restrictive faculty of ye belly being drank with wine, but of those which have a fever, with water. It is also hanged about one for ye inflammatio inguinum. It grows in ye ranks of corn.

Medium [which some call Medica, some Trifolium, some Clemation, some Osmos, some Trigonos, some Cybellium, some Polyphyllon, ye Romans Trifolium odoratum, the Egyptians Epaphou] grows in shadowy & rocky places; it hath leaves like Seris, ye stalk is of 3 cubits, ye flowers purple coloured great, and round, the seed small like Cnicus; ye root a span long, having ye thickness of a staff, bitter to ye taster, which being beaten small, when it is dry, & licked in with honey that is sodden for certain days stays the red flux. But ye seed being drank with wine drives out ye menstrua.

Epimedium [which some call Erineos, some Thrias, some Polyrrhizon, ye Romans Vindicta] ye stalk is not great, having about 10 or 12 leaves like to Ivy, but it bears neither seed nor flowers, ye roots are thin, black, strong scented, unsavoury to ye taster. It grows in watery places. The leaves of this beaten small, with oil, is a Cataplasme for ye duggs, that they may not swell. Ye root causeth barrenness & ye leaves beaten small & drank in wine after ye menstrual purgation, ye quantity of 3 dragms for 3 days keeps women from conception.

Xiphion which some call Phasganon, some Machaeronion, [some Anactorion, some Arion, the Romans Gladiolus, some Genitalis] because of ye fashion of ye leaf for it is like Iris, yet lesser, and narrower, & pointed like a little sword, & fibrous. It sends forth a stalk a cubit long, on which are purple flowers distant from one another by set ranks: a round seed: 2 roots, one of them resting upon the other, like little Scallions. Of these that which lies under is slender, but that above fuller. It grows especially in fields. But ye root that is uppermost is of force, being layed on with wine & frankincense to draw out prickles & Splinters, & with meal of Lolum, & Hydromel to dissolve ye Pani. Whereupon it is mixed with such-like plasters & being used for a Pessum, it drives out ye menstrua. They say also that the upper root being drank with wine doth provoke venery, but that ye undermost doth make them lustless and that ye upper root is profitably given to children that are broken in a potion with water.

Sparganium [but some call it Xiphidion, some Bolon] hath leaves like unto a little sword, but narrower, & more bending downward, & on ye top of the stalk little balls in which is ye seed. The root, & ye seed is given with wine to ye venemous-beast-bitten.

Xyris, but some call it Iris agria, some Cactos, ye Romans Gladiolus some Iris agrestis, ye Dacians Aprus] hath leaves like to Iris, but broader & sharp at ye top: a stalk, breaking out out of ye middle of ye leaves, thick enough 1 cubit long, on which are triangular cods & upon them a purple flower, but that in ye middle a phoenician colour; the seed in little cases like beans, round, red, sharp: ye root with many joints, long, red, being good for the wounds in ye head, & fractures, it draws out prickles & all sorts of weapons without pain, there being mixed with it of ye flour of brass a 3rd part, & of ye root of Centaury a fifth part, and sufficient honey. It doth also cure ye oedemata & inflammations, being applied with acetum. But ye root being bruised with Passum is drank both for convulsions, & ruptures, & Sciaticas, and stranguries, & belly fluxes. But the seed, as much as 3 oboli being drank in wine is most ureticall & it abates also ye spleen being drank with acetum.

Anchusa, which some call Calyx, some Onoclea [Some Catanchusa, some Lybica, some Archibellion, some Onophyllon, some Porphyris, some Mydusa, some Salyx, some Nonea, ye Africans Buinesath] hath leaves like to the sharp-leaved lettuce, rough, sharp, black, many, on every side of ye root joining to ye earth, prickly. The root, ye thickness of a finger of ye colour almost of blood in ye summer becoming severe, dyeing of the hands. It grows in good grounds. The root is of a binding nature, being good for burnings, and old ulcers being sodden in wax & oil, and being laid on with Polenta it cures ye Erysipelata & ye vitiligines & Leprosies being smeared on with acetum & being given as a Pessum it draws out ye Embrya. But ye decoction of it is given also to ye ictericall, nephriticall & spleneticall, if they have a fever, with melicrate. But ye leaves being drank with wine do stop ye belly. And ye Unguentarians do use the root for ye thickening of ye ointments.

Anchusa altera, which some have called Alcibiadian, or Onocheiles, this differs from ye former in having lesser leaves, yet alike sharp, & the little branches thin on which is a flower of a purple colour drawing to a Phoenician, but ye roots red, very long, about harvest, having some thing like blood in them. It grows in sandy places. But ye faculty of it, & ye leaves, is to help ye venemous-beast-bitten, especially ye viper-bitten, being eaten, or drank or hanged about one. And if one having chewed it, do spitt it out into ye mouth of ye venemous beast, it will kill him.

There is also another like unto this, but having a smaller seed of a Phoenicean colour, which if one having chewed doe spit out into ye mouth of a serpent, it will kill him, but ye root being drank ye quantity of an Acetabulum with Hyssop, & Nasturtium it drives out ye broade worm.

Lycopsis, & some also have called this Anchusa, hath leaves like to Lettuce, but longer, and thicker, & sharp, and broader, lying down about ye head of the root. It sends out a stalk, long, straight rough, having many shoots, a cubit long, prickly, and upon them little flowers near upon a purple: ye root red, binding. It grows in level fields. Ye root laid on with oil heals wounds, & with Polenta ye Erysipelata, but being beaten small, and anointed on with oil it moves sweats.

Echion, some call it Aridan, some Alcibiadion [ye Romans Alcibiacum] hath leaves, long, sharp, somewhat thin, like those of Anchusa, but lesser and fat, thin little prickles lying upon them, like those which make ye leaves rough: many, thin, little stalks, & on either side little leaves, thin, spread abroad like wings, black, but lesser as they grow nearer to ye top of ye stalk. Ye flowers by the leaves of a purple colour, in which also is ye seed like ye head of a viper: ye root thinner than a finger, somewhat black which not only helps those already bitten by serpents beind drank with wine, but also makes those which drink it before, unbitten. In like sort also do both ye leaves, & ye seed. It doth also assuage ye pain of ye loins being taken with wine or some other supping.

Ocimoides, or Philetaerium [but some call this Echion, some Scorpiuron, some Sparganon, some Althaea, some Amaranthis, some Probataea, some Elaphion, some Antimimon, some Porphyris, some Augion, some Nemesion, some Hyaenopsolon, some Thersites, some Thermutis, some Misopathos, ye Romans Ocimastrum] hath leaves like to Ocimum, but branches a span long rough, but Cods like Hyoscyamos, full of black seed, like to Melanthium. But ye seed being drank in wine hath ye power to cure ye viper-bitten, and ye other bitings of serpents. It is given also to ye Ischiaticall with myrrh, & Pepper. But ye root lies under, thin & unuseful.

Erinus [some call it Ocimoides, some Hydrero, ye Romans Ocimum] grows by rivers & fountaines, it hath leaves like those of Ocimum, yet lesser & jagged at the upper parts, little branches, 5 or 6 a span long, white flowers, but a little black seed, of a displeasant taste. The stalk is full of liquor & so are ye leaves. Of these ye seed being mixed ye quantity of 2 dragms to four of honey & smeared on do stay ye fluxes of ye eyes, but ye juice asswageth ye pains of ye ears being droped in with sulphur that never felt ye fire, & Nitre.

Gramen, [some call it Aegicon, some Amaxitis, ye Egyptians Anuphi, ye Romans gramen, some Assefolium, some sanguinalis, some Uniola, ye Spaniards Aparia, ye Dacians Cotiata, ye Africans Jebal] hath little branches, full of joints, creeping upon ye earth, & growing out from ye stalks, sweet roots, knotty, ye leaves sharp hard, broad, as of a little reed, nourishing cows & labouring cattle. The root of this beaten small, being applied conglutinates wounds. But ye decoction of it being drank is good for ye tormina, & ye dysurie, & ye ulcers about ye bladder, & it breaks ye stone.
Reed-grass is greater in every respect then Gramen but being eaten it is a killer of labouring beasts, & especially that which grows in Babylon by ye wayside.

But the grass which grows on Parnassus is more full of branches. It bears leaves like to Ivy, a white flower, & of a sweet scent, a small seed, not unuseful root 5 or 6 of a fingers thickness, white, soft, strong, of which ye juice being sodden with wine, & as much honey, & an halfpart of myrrh, & with pepper & a 1/3 part of Franckincense, is an excellent medicine for ye eyes.
