It is laid up in a brassen box. But ye decoction of ye roots is good for ye same griefs, as that. And ye seed of it is strongly diureticall, and a stayer of vomits, & of a fluxing belly.
But that which grows in Cilicia, which ye inhabitants call Cinna, being often fed upon when it is moist, inflames rude beasts.

Sideritis, some call it Heraclea [ye Magi Genitura, some the blood of Titan, some ye taile of a Scorpion, Pythagoras Parmiron, Andreas Xanthophanes, Osthanes Buphthalmum, the Egyptians Sendionor, ye Romans Vertumnus, some Solaster, ye Africans Asterchillos] is an herb having leaves like to Marrubium, but longer, like those of sage, or ye oak, yet lesser, & sharp: it sends out stalks 4-square, a span long or rather more, not unpleasant in ye taste, & somewhat binding gently, on which at distances are round verticilla like as of Marrubium, & in them a black seed. It grows in places under rocks. But the leaves being laid on have a faculty of conglutinating wounds, & of uninflaming.

The other Sideritis hath slender branches of 2 cubits, but leaves upon long stems like to those of Fern with many incuts towards ye top on either side, & from the upper wings long, thin shoots, having on ye top, a rough head, round like a sphere, in which is ye seed like to Beet, but rounder, and harder. And ye virtue of this also, & of ye leaves is to be good for wounds.

There is said also to be yet another Sideritis, which also Crateuas call Heraclea, growing in walls and vineyards, having many leaves from one root like to Coriander, little stalks about a span long, smooth, tender, somewhat white, & ruddy, ye flowers of a Phoenician dye, little, bitter to ye taster, clammy, & ye virtue of this being applied, is that it is conglutinating of bleeding & new wounds.

Achillea, some also call Achillea Sideritis [some Myriomorphon, some Chiliophyllon, some Stratioticon, some Heracleon, ye Romans Supercilium Veneris, some Acorus sylvaticus, some Militaris, some Millefolium, ye Africans Asterchillos]. It bears small rods, a span long or rather more, of ye fashion of spindles, & about them little leaves, thin, having often incuts across, like Coriander, somewhat red, clammy, smelling much, not unpleasant but having a medicine-like smell. A round tuft on ye top: ye flowers white, & resembling gold. It growes in fertile places. And ye hair of this beaten small is conglutinative of bloody wounds, & uninflaming, & a stayer of their bleeding, as also of that of ye wombe in a Pessum; and the decotion of this is an Insession for wombe-fluxing women. And it is drank also for ye dysentery.

Rubus [some call it Cynosbatos, some Selinorition, some Asyntrophon. The Magi Sanguis Titani, some Sanguis Ibis, the Romans Sentis, some Rubus, some Mora Vaticana, ye Dacians Mantia, ye Egyptians Haemœos, some Ametros] which wee know, binds and drys: it dyes ye hair. But the decoction of the tops of it being drank stops ye belly, & restrains ye flux of women, & is convenient for ye biting of ye Prester. And the leaves being chewed do strengthen ye gums, and heal ye Apthae. And ye leaves being applied, do restrain ye Herpetas, & heal ye running ulcers which are in ye head, & ye falling down of the eyes, & the Condylomata and Haemorrhoids, & it is available for ye stomachicall, and ye Cardiacall, being beaten small, & so laid on. But ye juice of it got out of ye bruised stalks and leaves, & stirred in ye sun, doth do better for all ye purpose aforesaid. But ye juice of ye fruit of it being thoroughly ripe is good to be put into mouth-medicines. It doth also stop ye belly being eaten when it is but half ripe. And ye flower also of it being drank with wine doe stop ye belly.

It is called Rubus Idaeus, because it grows much in Ida, but it is much tenderer than that before it, having little prickles; but it is found also without a prickle. It performes ye same things as the aforesaid, & moreover the flower of it beaten small, with honey being anointed on helps eye-inflammations, & doth extinguish ye Erysipelata. It is given in drink with water to ye stomachicall.

Helxine [but some call it Elitis, some Canochersaea, some Amelxine, some Eusine, some Amorgine, some Sucotachos, some Psychuacos, some Melampelon, some Cissampelon, some Cissamethon, some Analetamenon, ye Romans Volutum laparou, ye Egyptians Hapap] hath leaves like to Ivy, but lesser, & little branches, long, clasping about wherever it happens. It grows in hedges, & in vineyards, & in corn but ye juice of ye leaves being drank hath a laxative faculty of ye belly.

Elatine hath the leaves like to Helxine, but lesser, and rounder, hairy, ye branches thin, a span long, 5 or 6 from the root, full of leaves sharp in ye taste. It grows in corn, & tilled places. But ye leaves being applied with Polenta, have the power to help enflamed and rhumatick eyes, but being sodden, and supt up, it stays ye Dysentery.

Eupatorium [some call it Hepatorium, some Hepatitis, ye Romans Volucrum maius] is an herb like a shrub, putting out one rod, thin, woody, straight, black, rough, a cubit long, or rather more, but ye leaves jagged by distances, most commonly into 5 parts, or rather more, like to those of Quinquefolium or rather Cannabis, & those inclining to black, cut in by ye outsides like a saw. The seed grows round about from ye middle of ye stalk somewhat rough, bending downward, so that being dried it hangs upon clothes. The leaves of this being applied when they are beaten small, with old swines grease, do heal ye difficult cicatrizings of ulcers. But ye seed, and ye herb being drank with wine do help ye dysentericall, & serpent-bitten. Some being deceived have called this Artemisia, for it is diverse, as we have shown.

Quinquefolium [some call it Pentapetes, some Pentatomon, some Pentadactylon, some Pseudoselinon, some Callipetalon, some Xyloloton, some Xylopetalon, some Asphalton, some Pentacoenon, some Thymiatitis, ye Egyptians Orphitebeoce, some Enotron, ye Magi Unguis Ibis, some ala Ibis, some Hermodactylon, ye Romans Quinquefolium, ye French Pempedula, ye Dacians Propedula] bears branches like Festuca, thin, a span long, on which is ye seed. It hath leaves like unto mint, five upon every stem but rarely any where more, cut in round about like a saw: ye flower pale-white, yellowish like gold. It grows in moist places & by rivers, but it hath a reddish root somewhat long, thicker than black Ellebore, but it is of much use. The decoction of ye root being brought down to ye third by seething, is of force being held in ye mouth to assuage toothache, & it stays ye rotten ulcers that are in ye mouth by collution & it doth alay ye roughness of the artery by being gargarized, & it helps a fluxing belly, & ye dysentery, & ye Arthriticall & Ischiaticall by being drank; but being beaten small, sodden in acetum & applied, it restrains ye Herpetas, dissolves ye Strumas, hardnesses, Oedemata, Aneurusmata, Suppurations, Erysipelata, ye Pterygia on ye fingers, & doth heal ye Condylomata, & ye Psoras; but ye juice of ye roote when tender is good for the griefs in the liver, & the lungs, & for deadly poisons. But the leaves are drank also with Hydromel, or diluted wine, and a little Pepper, for ye periods of agues, for a quartan ye leaves of four little branches, but for a tertian, of three, & for a quotidian of one: they help Epilepsies being drank for 30 days, and the juice of ye leaves being drank for some days ye quantity of 3 Cyathi doth soon cure ye Icterus, & being laid on with salt, and honey, they heal both wounds & Fistuals. It helps also such as are broken, and doe stop fluxes of blood being drank, or else applied. And it is cut also for lustrations & fluxes of blood & Purifications. [If any bear Pentadactylon about his body, he remains without any grief, & it helps ye eyes, ye Strumas, ye hardened Tonsillae, ye Uva and ye griefs under ye tongue, & ye joints, & ye griefs of ye nerves & ye teeth, & ye Psora got by a pernicious famine, drawing down ye menstrua of ye afterbirths; but being poured on the hands it is excellent good against fears & enchantments, therefore take ye herb when ye moon increaseth, ye sun arising.]

Phoenix, which some call Rhus, some Anchinops [some Phoenicopteron, some Rhus stachyos, some Ostheles, ye Romans Palolucupinum, ye Egyptians Athnon]. hath the leaves like unto barely, but shorter, & narrower, but ye ear like unto Lolium, & branches about ye root of six fingers, and ears 7 or 8. It grows in fields, and upon roofs which are newly mortered. But being drank in hard wine, it hath ye power to stop ye belly flux, & ye flux of blood that is from ye womb, & ye too much issuing of Urine. Some say also that it is a blood stancher, being bound in wool of a Phoenician dye & hanged about one.

Idaea radix, is like in ye leaves to Oxymyrsine, but by them there grow out as it were little tendrils from which also comes the flower. The root of this is exceeding binding, serving for such, for whom there is need. It is drank also for ye fluxes of ye belly, and ye womanish flux. And it stays all fluxes of blood.

Rhodia radix [some call it Rhodida] grows in Macedonia being like to Costus, but lighter, & uneven, making a scent in ye bruising, like that of Roses. It is of good use for ye agrieved with headache, being bruised & layed on with a little Rosaceum, & applied moist to ye forehead, & ye temples.

Equisetum [but some call it Trimachion, some Anabasis, some Cheredranon, some Phaedra, some Itiandendron, some Gis, some Schoniostrophon, ye Egyptians Pherphram, ye Magi cibus Saturni, ye Romans Equinalis, some Salix equinalis, some Anabasion, some Ephudron]. It grows in moist places & ditches, it hath empty little stalks, reddish, distinguished by joints growing one into another, & about them many, thin rushy leaves. It grows into heighth climbing upon ye trunks of trees standing by & hangs on them, being compast about with many black hairs, like as ye tail of a horse. The root woody, hard, but ye herb binding. Whence ye juice of it doth stop fluxes of blood which come from the nostrils & being drank with wine, it helps dysenteries: it moves ye urine also. But being beaten small, & sprinckled on it closeth bleeding wounds. Both ye root & ye herb do help ye Tussicall, & Orthoponoicall. It is said also that ye leaves being drank in water, do conjoin ye divisions of ye Intestinum & ye cutting asunder of ye bladder, & ye Enterocele.
47. IPPOURIS ETERA. Equisetum arvense or limosum

Equisetum alterum [which some call Equitium, some Chedra, some Gyon, ye Romans Salix equinalis] ye stalk is straight, even higher than a cubit, as it were, empty, having shorter, & whiter, & softer hairs by distances; which also itself molded with acetum, doth heal wounds, having ye same faculty as ye former.

Coccum tinctile, is a little shrub, full of sprigs to which cling the grains as Lentils, which being taken out are laid up in store. But ye best is that of Galatia, & that of Armenia, then that in Asia, & that of Cilicia, & last of all, that in Spain. It hath a binding faculty, being good for wounds & hurts of ye Sinews, being beaten small & laid on with Acetum. But that in Cilicia grows upon oaks, in fashion like to a little snail, which ye women there, gathering with ye mouth, doe call Coccum.

Tragium alterum [which some call Tragos, some Tragoceros, some Scorpion, some Garganon, ye Romans Cornulaca, some Bituensa, ye Dacians Salia, ye Egyptians Sober, ye Africans Achiosim] hath ye leaves like to Scolopendrium, but a thin white root like to wild Raphanus, which being eaten, either raw or sodden doth help ye dysentericall. But ye leaves about ye Autumn do cast out ye scent of a goat. Whence also it is called Tragium. It grows in hilly, and steep places.

Tragus, which some call Scorpion, some Traganos, growes by the sea especially. A little shrub on ye ground somewhat long, not great, about a span or more. It hath no leaves, but on the branches there hang as it were little kernels, red, about ye bigness of wheat, sharp on ye top, many, exceeding binding to ye taster. The seed of this, as ten kernels drank with wine, do help ye Coeliacall, & women having their fluxes. And some also beating it make it into Trochiscks for ye laying up, & soe they use it.

Juncus [which some call Juncus laevis, some Oxypternos, some Supercilium Solis, ye Romans Juncus marinus, some Juncus manualis, ye Africans Chudua] of this there is a double kind, the one of which is called ye smooth Juncus, ye other ye sharp Juncus pointed on the top, & of this again there is a double kind, for one is barren, but ye other hath a round, black seed, but the reeds of this are thicker, & more fleshy. And there is a third, much more fleshy, and rougher than ye two, which is called Holoschoenos, & this also hath seed on ye top like to that before it. Ye seed of either of them being parched, & drank with diluted wine, doth stop ye belly, and the red flux, & move ye urine: it is good also for ye headache but ye tender leaves by ye root being laid on; is good for ye Phalangium-bitten. But ye Aethiopicall Juncus hath a seed that will cause sleep. But we must beware of too much of it in potions, for it provokes sleep mightily.

Lichen, that which grows upon rocks, but some call it Bryon, is a moss sticking to moist rocks. This being laid on doth stop ye fluxes of blood, & doth assuage inflammations, & doth heal Lichenas, & it doth help the Ictericall being laid on with honey, and doth help also the rhumes of ye mouth, & ye tongue.

Paronychia [which some call Adocetos, some Neuras, some Phrynion, ye Romans Unguinalis] grows in rocks, is a small shrub like to Peplus, in length less, but greater in ye leaves, which being laid on all, when it is small bruised, doth heal ye Paronychias, & ye Favos.

Chrysocome [which some call Chysitis, some Chrysanthemon, some Amarantum, some ye beard of Juppiter, ye Romans Jovis barba, ye Africans Dubath, some Burchumath] is a small shrub of a span long, having hair like Corymbi, resembling hyssop, a thick root, slender, as of black Ellebore, not unpleasant to ye taster being equal to Cyperus, somewhat sour in ye sweetness. It grows in shadowy, & rocky places. But ye root hath a warming & binding faculty, of fit use for ye Hepaticall, & Peripneumonicall. It is taken also sod with Hydromel for ye cleansing of ye matrix.

Chrysogonum hath leaves like to ye oak, but ye shrub is thick beset, & hath ye flower like to Verbascum Coronarium, ye root like to Rape, within strongly red, but without black, which being beaten small with acetum, and applied, doth help ye bitings of ye shrew mouse.

Helichrysum, but some call it Chrysanthemon, some also call this Amarantum, wherewith also they crown their Idols, having a little rod, white, green, straight, strong: narrow leaves by distances, like those of Abrotanum, ye hair circular, shining like gold, a round tuft, as it were dry bunches of berries: a thin root. It grows in rough, & water running places. The hair being drank with wine doth help Dysuries, & ye bitings of serpents, & Sciaticas, & ruptures, & it moves ye menstrua, & consumes the clots of blood which are in ye bladder or ye belly, being drank with mustum. It stops also distillations, being given as much 3 Oboli in a dilution of white wine to one fasting. It is laid up also together with clothes keeping them uneaten.

Chrysanthemon, or Calchas, some call it Bupthalmum [some Chalcitis, some Chalcanthum, some Chalcanthemon, ye Romans Acantha, ye Thuscans Garuleum, ye Africans Churzeta] is a tender shrub-like herb, bringing out smooth stalks, and leaves much jagged, yellowish flowers, strongly shining, & an eye round about, for which cause also, it is so-called. It grows about towns, but ye stalks are eaten as potherbs. The flowers beaten small with Cerat are said to dissolve ye Steatomata. And it makes ye Ictericall have a good colour in good time, being given to drink after ye coming out from the long stayings in ye baths [Chrysanthemon, if you take it out of ye earth before the arising of the sun, & bind it to ye body and hang it about the neck, doth good, averting the women witches, and all enchantments.]

Ageratum is a shrub full of sprigs, a span long, low, single, like especially to Origanum, having a tuft, on which is a flower, like a boss of a golden colour, less than Helichrysum. It is called Ageratum, because the flower is kept for a long time, keeping his colour. But ye decoction of it hath a burning faculty. And ye herb itself being suffumigated, hath ye power to move ye urine, & to mollify ye hardness about ye womb.

Peristereon [which some call Trygonium, some Bunion, Some sacra herba, some Philtrodotes, ye Egyptians Pempsempte, ye Magi Iunonis lachryma, some ye blood of ye weazel, some ye blood of Mercury, ye Romans crista gallinacea, some Ferrea, some Trixalis, some Exupera, some Herba sanguinalis] grows in watery places. It seems to be so named from this that doves do gladly stay about it. It is an herb, having ye heighth of a span or rather more, ye leaves incut, whitish, growing out of the stalk. It is found for ye most part with but one shoot & one root. And is seems that ye leaves applied as a Pessum with Rosaceum or new swines grease, do cause a cessation of ye womb-pains, & being applied with acetum it represseth ye Erysipelata, and rotten ulcers, & conglutinates wounds, and with honey cicatriceth old ones. [Peristereo, ye upright, doth extend ye pudendum, but that which is bending is drying, but ye upright tied to one, is good for ye pains of ye eyes, for ye dimness of sight, and ye pain of ye head, & it easeth weariness, being bruised with acetum it forthwith dissolveth ye strumas, & ye tonsillas induratas. But when any shivers with an ague, let one taking ye branches from this stand only before him that hath ye shivering, and forthwith he is cured.]

Hierabotane [which some have called Peristereon [huption] some Erigenion, some Chamaelycon, some Sideritis, some Curitis, some Phersephonion, some Jovis colum, some Dichromon, some Callesis, some Hipparison, some Demetrias, ye Egyptians Pemphthephtha, Pythagoras Erysisceptron, ye Romans Cincinnalis] sends out rods of a cubit or rather more, cornery, about which are ye leaves by distances, like to ye oak, but yet narrower and smaller, but incut round about, drawing to an azure, ye root somewhat long, thin, ye flowers purple, thin. Of this ye leaves & ye root being given to drink with wine, or smeared on, are of force against serpents, but for ye Icterus ye leaves ye quantity of a dragm, with 3 Oboli of frankincense, with one Hemina of old wine being drank by one fasting, for 40 days. And being alid on they assuage inflammations & Oedemata of long continuance, and cleanse foul ulcers, but ye whole herb being sodden with wine, breaks ye crusts round about which are in the tonsillae, & being gargarized it stays ye fretting ulcers in ye mouth, and ye infusion of it being sprinkled in feasts is said to make ye guests ye merrier. To such as have a tertian, is given to drink ye third joint from the earth, with ye leaves round about: to such as have a quartan ye fourth joint. Now they call it Sacra herba, because it is of fit use in ye expiations to serve for Amulets.

Astragalus [which some call Chamaesyce, some Onyx, some Gatales, ye Romans Pinus trivius, as also Ficus terrae, some Glandula, some talum, [some Nonaria] is a little small shrub on ye ground, in ye leaves & sprigs like to Cicer: ye leaves of purple, little; but ye root lies under, round, of a good bigness like ye Radish, having strong, black, hard adcrescencies, folded one within another as horns, rellishing binding to ye taster. It grows in windy and shady and snowy places, & in great abundance in Memphis of Arcadia. But ye root being drank in wine stays a fluxing belly, & moves also ye urine. It is good likewise for old ulcers being dried into powder, & so sprinkled one, & it stancheth blood. But it is beaten with difficulty, because of ye solidity of it.

Hyacinthus [which some call Helonias, some Porphyranthes, ye Romans Vaccinium, some Ulcinum] hath leaves like to a Bulbus, a stalk a span long, smooth, thinner than ye little finger, green, a curld hair lying upon it full of flowers of a purple colour, & the root like to Bulbus, which being smeared on with white wine upon boyes is thought to keep them impuberes; it also bindes ye belly & being drank moves ye urine & helps ye bitten of a Phalangium. But ye seed is more binding, & that also serves to be put in treacles, & it cleanseth ye Icterus being drank with wine.

Papaver erraticum [which some call Oxytonum, ye Romans Papaveralis, ye Egyptians Nanti] is so called because it quickly casteth away ye flower; it grows in fields in ye spring, at what time also it is gathered. Ye leaves are like to Origanum, or to Eruca, or to Cichory, or Thyme, jagged, but longer, and rough; but a downy stalk, straight, rough, as of a cubits height: ye flower purple, & sometimes also white, like to that of Anemone ye wild: ye head somewhat long, yet somewhat less than that of Anemone: ye seed red: ye root somewhat long, whitish, having ye thickness of a little finger & bitter. Having sod 5 or 6 little heads of this with three Cyathi of wine, to bring it as to two, give it to drink to such as you would make sleep. As much as an acetabulum of ye seed being drank with Melicrate, doth soften ye belly gently. It is mixed also with honeyed confections & cakes for ye same purpose. But ye leaves being laid on together with ye heads doe heal inflammations. But ye decoction of them being fomented, or sprinkled on, is soporiferous.

Poppy, there is some that is sative [some call it Chamaesyce, some Mecon Rhoeas, some Oxytonon, the Romans Papaver, ye Egyptian Nanti] & set in gardens, of which ye seed is made into bread, for use in ye time of health, & with honey they use it instead of Sesama, & it is called Thylacitis, having a little head somewhat long, & the seed white.
But the other which is wild hath the head bending down, which also is called Pithitis, & of some also this is called Rhoeas, because ye liquor doth flow out of it.

There is a third more wilde, & more medicinable, & more long than these, having an head somewhat long, but ye common virtue of them is cooling. Whence ye leaves, & ye heads being sodden in water, and fomented on, cause sleep. And ye decoction is drank against want of sleep. But ye heads being beaten small, & so mixed with Polenta into Cataplasmes, are good for inflammations, & ye Erysipelata. But it behoves them that beat them when they are green to make them into trochiscks, & having dried them to lay them up in store, & so use them. But ye heads being sodden by themselves in water to ye half, & then sodden again with honey till that ye moisture be thickened, they make a licking medicine, being a lenitive for coughs & distillations of ye Artery, & Coeliacall affections. But it becomes ye more effectual if juice of Hypocisthis & Acacia are mixed with it.

Ye seed of the black Poppy beaten small is given to drink with wine for ye flux of ye belly, & ye womanish flux. It is applied unto such as cannot sleep with water upon ye forehead & the temples, but the liquor itself is more cooling & thickening & drying. A little of it taken as much as a grain of Ervum, is a pain-easer & a sleep causer, & a digester, helping coughes, & Coeliacall affections. But being drank too much, it hurts, making men lethargicall & it kills. It is helpful also for ye headaches, being bedewed on their heads with Rosaceum, & for ye pained in ye ears, being droped in with oil of almonds, & saffron, and myrrh. And for ye inflammations of ye eyes with an egg’s yolk roasted & saffron, & for Erysipelata & wounds with Acetum, but for gouts with womans milk, and saffron. But being put up with ye finger for a suppository, it causeth sleep. But that liquor is ye best, which is thick, & heavy & sleepy in ye smell, bitter in the taste, easily pierced with water, smooth, white, not sharp, neither clotty, nor growing thick in ye straining as wax does, & being set in the sun flowing abroad, & being lighted at a candle, not of a dark flame, & keeping, after it is put out, strength in ye smell. But they counterfeit it by mixing Glaucium or gum, or ye juice of ye wild Lettuce, but that which is made of Glaucium looks of a saffron colour in ye dissolving, but that of ye wild Lettuce is but faint in ye smell and rougher, but that of Gum is without strength & transparent. But some are come to so much madness as to mix grease with it. But it is set on fire for eye-medicines, in a new earthen vessell until it appear to be softer & of a more yellowish red. But Erasistratus saith that Diagoras doth disallow the use of it for such as are sick of ear-griefs, or eye-griefs, because it is a duller of ye sight, & a causer of sleep. And Andreas saith that except it were adulterated they would be blind which were anointed with it. And Mnesidemus saith that ye use of it is only that for ye smell, being good to cause sleep & that else it is hurtfull, which things are false being confuted by experience, because that ye efficacy of ye medicine doth bear witness to ye works of it. But it is not out of place to describe also ye manner, how they gather ye liquor. Some therefore beating the heads with the leaves, squeeze it out through a press & beating it in a mortar make it into Trochiscks, & such as this is called Meconium, being weaker than Opium. But it behoves them that make Opium after that the dew is dried away to scarify about the asterisck with a knife, so that it do not pierce into ye inside, & from ye sides of the head make straight incisions in ye outside, & to wipe off ye tear that comes out with ye finger into a spoone, & again to return not long after, for there is found another (tear) thickened, & also on the day after. But it must be beaten in a mortar, & be laid up when made into trochiscks, but in ye cutting it, you must stand back, to ye end that the liquor be not wiped away of your clothes.

Papaver cornutum, which some call Paralion, some Agreste Papaver [some Thalassium, ye Romans Pabulum marinum, ye Africans Sisimaca] hath white, rough leaves like to Verbascum, jagged like a saw round about, as those of wild Poppy, and the stalk alike, ye flower of a yellow pale, but a little cod, bending as an horn, like to that of Foenigreek, whence also it is so-called: the seed small, black, like to that of Poppy: a root growing on ye surface of ye ground, black, thick. It grows in maritime and rough places. The root being sodden in water to halfs, and drank hath ye power to cure Sciaticas, and Liver griefs & to help such as piss thick, or cobweb-like matters. But the seed being drank ye quantity of an Acetabulum with melicrate doth purge ye belly gently, & ye leaves & the flowers do root out ye crusts of ulcers being smeared on with oil, & being anointed on it takes away ye Argema, & ye Nubeculas growing in ye eyes of beasts. But some have been deceived thinking that Glaucium was made of this, because of ye resemblance of ye leaves. [In ye eating, or drinking this same horned Poppy, ye symptoms are inferred such as were in taking of ye Opium, & they fall under ye selfsame remedies. But ye seed is gathered dry in the summer. But ye decoction of ye root is drank & it cures dysenteries.]

Papaver Spumeum, called of some, Heracleum, hath a stalk a span long, & ye leaves exceeding small like unto Radicula, ye seed white between them, & all ye small herb is white, and frothy: a root, thin for ye most part. The seed of this is gathered in ye summer when it is fully grown, & being dried falls away. It purgeth by vomitings, being taken ye quantity of an Aetabulum with Melicrate but such a purging as this, is properly good for ye Epilepticall.
Hypecoon, but some call it Hypopheon, grows in ye wheat & the fields; it hath a leaf like to Rue, little branches, but it hath a faculty proportionable to ye juice of Poppy.

Hyoscyamus [which some call Dioscyamos, some Pythonion, some Adamas, some Adamenon, some Hypnoticum, some Emmanes, some Atomon, some Dithiambrion, Pythagoras & Osthanes Xeleon, Zoroastres Tephonion, ye Romans Inanaoentaria, some Apollinaris, ye Magi Rhaponticum, ye Egyptians Saptho, ye Thuscans Phoebulonga, ye French Bilinuntiam ye Dacians Dieliam] is a shrub sending out thick stalks: ye leaves broad, somewhat long, jagged, black, rough. By the stalk come out flowers in order, as ye flowers of ye pommegranate, hedged in with little shields, full of seed, as of Poppy. But there is a 3-fold difference of it. For one bears flowers almost purple, leaves like to Smilax, a black seed, & little shields hard, and prickly. But ye other bears yellowish flowers, ye leaves, & ye cods more tender, ye seed of a faint yellow, as that of Iris. But both these are causers of frenzies, & of sleep, scarce usable.

But ye fittest for cures is ye gentlest, being ye third kind, fat & tender and downy, having white flowers & the seed white. It grows by ye sea & amongst rubbish of buildings, you therefore must use the white, but if this be not present, then you must use ye yellow, but refuse the black as which is worst.

Ye seed is juiced when tender, & the leaves & the stalks are beaten and pressed, ye moisture being dried in ye Sun. But ye use of it holds but for a year, because it is soon corrupted. But ye seed also of it is juiced in particular, it being pounded when it is dry, under hot water poured upon it, & so prest out. But the juice is better than the liquor, & a more easer of pain. But ye green being pounded & mixed with 3 months wheatmeal, is made into trochiscks, & so laid up. But first of all ye juice & that which is made of ye dry seed, is made for Collyries to take away pain, & for ye sharp & hot rhume, & for ye ear pains & ye griefs about ye matrix, & with meal or Polenta both for ye inflammations of ye eyes, & of ye feet, & ye other inflammations. And ye seed doth performe ye same things, being good both for coughs, & Catarrhs, & ye rheume of ye eyes, & ye griefs about them, & for ye womanish flux, & the other fluxes of blood, as much as an Obolus being drank with ye seed of Poppy, & melicrate. It is good also for gouts, & ye inflated genitories, the duggs in childbirth being swollen, if it be beaten small with wine, & so applied. And it is profitably mixed with other Cataplasmes made to cease paine. And the leaves made into little balls, are of good use to be put into all Anodynas, being mixed with Polenta, or else laid on of themselves. But the fresh leaves smeared on are ye most lenitive of pain for all griefs. But three or four being drank with wine do cure fevers called Epialae. But being sodden like potherbs, & eaten ye measure of a Tryblium, they cause a mean disturbation of ye sense. They say also that if any do glisterize him herewith that hath an ulcer in ye seat, that it works ye same effect. But ye root being sodden with Acetum is a collution for teeth pains.

Psyllium [which some call Cataphysis, some Cynocephalion, some Crystallium, some Cynomuia, some Psylleris, some Sicelioticon, but ye Sicilians Conidiis, ye Romans Silvacium, some Herba pulicaria, ye Africans Vargugum] hath a leaf like to Coronopis rough, & longer, branches a span long, and ye whole herb little as Hay. Ye hair of it comes from ye middle of ye stalk, it hath little heads 2 or 3 rolled on ye top close together, in which is ye seed like to fleas, black hard. It grows in field, & untilled places. It hath a refrigerating faculty: being laid on with Rosaceum or acetum, or water, it helps ye Arthritic, ye Parotidas, Tumors, Oedemata, luxations, ye headache. And it heals ye Enterocelae that are on children, and such whose navels come out, being smeared on with Acetum. But they must having beaten small ye measure of an Acetabulum, macerate it in two fingers of water, & smear it on when ye water is grown thick, for it cools abundantly. Being put into seething water it suppresseth ye heat, it is good also against ye Erysipelata. They say also that it being brought into an house, green, doth not suffer fleas to breed. And being pounded with grease, it doth cleanse ye foulness, & malignancies of ulcers, but ye juice with honey is good for running ears, & such ears as have worms.

Solanum hortense [which some call sative, ye Romans Strumum, some Cacubalum, ye Egyptians Allelo, ye French Scubulum, ye Africans Astrismunim] is a little shrub that is edible, not great, having many wings, ye leaves black, greater & broader than Ocymum, ye fruit round, green, which becomes black, or yellow after that it is ripe. But ye herb is harmless to ye taste: it hath a cooling faculty, whence ye leaves being applied are good for ye Erysipelata & ye Herpetae with ye flower of Polenta. And of themselves being laid on beaten small they cure ye Aegilops, & the headach, and they help a burning stomach, and dissolve ye Parotidas being beaten small with salt & so applied. And the juice of it is good against ye Erysipelata, & ye Herpetas with Cerusa, & Rosaceum, & Lithargyrum; but for ye Aegilops with bread. It is good also for children that have ye Syriasis being gently poured on with Rosaceum. It is also mixed with Collyriums instead of water, or an egg, for anointings in sharp fluxes; & being droped in it helps ye ear pain, & also it stop ye womanish flux being applied as a Pessum in wool. And ye juice is necessary for Aegilopses being kneaded together with ye yellow dung of barn hens & applied in a linen cloth.

There is also another Solanum which they call properly Halicacabum or Physalis [some Dirceaum, some Solanum furiale, some Dorycnion, some Calliada, ye Romans Apollinaris minor, some Herba Ulticana, some Opsaginem, & some call it Vesicaria, ye Dacians Cucolida, ye Africans Cacabum], like in leaves ye afore spoken of, yet broader, but ye stalks of this after they are growne, grow bending to ye earthward. It hath a fruit in round cods like bladders, reddish, round, smooth, as ye kernel of a grape, which also ye crown-playters use playting therewith the crowns. It hath ye same force and use as ye garden Solanum, except ye being eaten. But ye fruit of it being drank is of force to cleanse away Icterus, as which is ureticall. But ye herb of either of them is juiced & is dried in ye shade for ye laying up, and it is available for ye same effects.

Solanum Somnificum, some call this Halicacabum, is a shrub having many branches, thick, with tails, hard to break, full of fat leaves, like to the quince, a red flower of a good bigness, ye fruit in cods of a saffron colour, ye root having a bark somewhat red, of a good bigness. It grows in rocky places not far from ye sea. The bark of this root being drank in wine ye weight of a dragm, hath a soporiferous faculty, milder than ye liquor of the Poppy. But ye fruit is too much ureticall. As it were 12 Corymbi are given to ye hydropicall, but more being drank, do work a trance. But such are helped by much melicrate being drank, & ye juice of it is mixed with Anodynalls, & Trochiscks. And being sodden in wine, & held it helps ye toothache. But ye juice of ye root being anointed on with honey takes away ye dullness of ye sight.

Solanum furiale, which some have called Persion, some Thyron [some Anydron, some Pentadryon, some Enoron, some Orthogyion]. The leaf of this is a neighbour to Eruca, but greater, coming near to those of Acanthus, which also is called Paederos. It sends out 10 or 12 tall stalks from the root, having ye heighth of an ell, ye head lying upon, as an olive but rougher, as ye ball of ye Plane tree but greater and broader, ye flower black, & after this it hath a fruit cluster-like, round, black, paritions 10 or 12, like ye Corymbi of Ivy, soft as a grape: the root lies under, white, thick, hollow, ye length as it were of a cubit. It grows in hilly places, & open to ye wind, and rocks neere ye sea. The root being drank with wine ye quantity of a dragm, hath ye power to effect not unpleasant fantasies. But 2 dragms being drank, make one beside himself for three days & 4 being drank kill him. But ye remedy of this is Melicrate, much being drank, & vomited up again.

Dorcynium, Crateuas calls it Halicacabum, or Caleam, is a shrub like to ye Olive new put out, having branches less than a cubit. It grows in rocks, not far off from ye sea. It hath leaves near to the Olive in colour but lesser and stronger, & extremely rugged: the flower white, on the top it hath little cods, thick as those of ye Cicer, in which are 5 or 6 little rounds seeds, about ye bigness of ye little Ervum, smooth, firm & of divers colours: a root ye thickness of a finger, & ye length of a cubit, & this seems also to be of a sleepy quality & that taken too much, it kills. And some also say that ye seed thereof is taken for love medicines.

Mandagoras, which some call Antimelon, some call it Dircaea, some Circaea [some Circaeum, some Xeranthe, some Antimnion, some Bombochylon, some Minon, ye Egyptians Apemum, Pythagoras Anthropomorphon, some Aloitin, some Thridacian, some Cammaron, Zoroastres Diamonon, or Archinen, ye Magi Hemionous, some Gonogeonas, ye Romans Mala canina, some Mala terrestria]. Since that the root seems to be a maker of love medicines. There is of it one sort that is foemall, which is black, called Thridacias, having narrower & longer leaves than lettuce, of a poisonous & heavy scent to ye smell, scattered upon the ground, & amongst them ye apples like Service berries, pale, of a sweet scent, in which is ye seed as of a pear: ye roots two or three of a good bigness, wrapped within one another, black according to outward appearance, within white & of a thick bark, but it bears no stalk.

But of ye male, and white which some have called Norion, ye leaves are greater, white, broad, smooth as of the beet, but ye apples twice as big, drawing to saffron in ye colour, sweet smelling with a certain strongness which also ye shepherds eating are in a manner made asleep, but ye root is like to that before it, yet greater and whiter, & this also is without stalk. Ye bark of ye root is juiced being beaten when it is new, & set under a press. But it will behove ye beaters, after it is stirred about to lay it up in an earthen vessel, & ye apples also are juiced in like manner. But ye juice of them becomes remiss. And ye bark of the root being peeled off & done through with a thread is hanged up for store. And some do seeth the roots in wine to thirds, & straining it set it up. Using a Cyathus of it for such as cannot sleep, or are grievously pained, & upon whom being cut, or cauterized they wish to make a not-feeling pain. Ye juice being drank ye muchness of ye quantity of 2 Oboli with Melicrate, doth expel upward Phlegm, and black choler, as Ellebore doth, but being too much drank it drives out ye life. And it is mixed with eye-medicines, & Anodynas, & mollifying Pessums, but being put to of itself, as much as half an Obolus, it expels ye menstrua, & ye Embryo, & being put up into ye seat for a suppository, it causeth sleep. But ye root is said also to soften Ivory when sodden together with it for six hours, & to make it ready to be formed into what fashion a man will. But ye new leaves are good both for ye inflammations of ye eyes, and those upon ulcers, being laid on with Polenta; & they dissolve also all hardness, & Apostumes, Strumas & tumors, & being rubbed on gently for 5 or 6 days, it doth deface scars without exulcerating. Ye leaves preserved in brine are laid up for ye same uses. The root being beaten small with acetum doth heal ye Erysipelata, but for ye strokes of serpents, with honey, or oil; & with water, it disperseth ye strumas, and Tumors, & assuageth ye pains of ye joints with Polenta. Ye wine of ye bark of ye root is prepared without seething but you must cast in 3 pounds into a Metreta of sweet wine, & that there be given of it 3 Cyathi to such as shall be cut, or cauterized, as is aforesaid. For they do not apprehend the pain, because they are overborn with dead sleep, but the apples being smelled to, or eaten, are soporiferous, & ye juice that is of them. But used too much they make men speechless. The seed of the apples being drank purgeth ye matrix, & given as a Pessum with brimstone that never felt ye fire it stays ye red flux. It is juiced, ye root being scarified about divers ways, & that which runs out being gathered into a concavity; but ye juice is more effectual than ye liquor. But ye roots do not bear liquor in every place: experience doth show as much. They give out also that there is another sort called Morion, growing in shady places, & about dens, having leaves like to ye white Mandrake, but less, as it were a span long, white, lying round about ye root, it being tender, & white, by a little longer than a span, ye thickness of ye great finger, which they say being drank as much as a dragm or eaten with Polenta, in Placetum, or Obsonium it doth infatuate. For a man sleeps in ye same fashion, as when he ate it, sensible of nothing for 3 or 4 hours, from ye time that it is brought him. And Physitians also, use this, when they are about to cut, or cauterize. And they say also that ye root being drank with Solanum that is called Manicum is an Antidot.

Aconitum, which some call Pardalianches, some Cammarum, some Thelyphonum, some Myoctonon, some Theriophonon hath leaves three or four like to Cyclamen or Cucumter, yet less, and a little rough, but ye stalk of a span, ye root like to ye tail of a scorpion, glittring like as Alabaster. They say that ye root of this being laid on a scorpion, doth mortify him, & that he is raised again by Ellebore put to him. It is mixed also with eye-anodynall medicines. But it kills both Panthers and Sowes, and wolves, & all wild beasts, being put into gobbets of flesh, & given to them.

Aconitum alterum, which some do call Cynoctonon, some Lycoctonon [some white bean, ye Romans Colomestrum] grows plentifully in Italy on the hills called Vestini, differing from that before it. But it hath leaves like to those of ye Plane tree, but more jagged and a great deal less, & blacker, but a stalk, as the stem of fern, bare, ye height of a cubit, or more; and ye seed in Cods in a manner somewhat long, ye roots like ye Cirri of Squills, black, which they use for the hunting by wolves, putting them into raw flesh, for being eaten by the wolves, they kill them.

Cicuta [which some call Aegynos, some Ethusa, some Apolegousa, some Dolia, some Amaurosis, some Paralysis, some Aphron, some Creidion, some Coete, some Catechomenion, some Abioton, some Apseudes, some Ageomoron, some Timoron, some Polyanodynos, some Dardanis, some Catapsyxis, Osthanes Babathy, ye Egyptians Apemphin, ye Romans Cicuta] sends out a knotty stalk, like as Fennil, great, but leaves like to Ferula, but narrower, & of an heavy smell, & on ye tops, excrescencies, and tufts, a whitish flower, ye weed like to Annisseed whiter, ye root hollow, & not deep. And this also is of ye venemous herbs, killing by its coldness, but it is helped by unmixed wine. The tops, or ye hair are juiced before that ye seed be dry, and being beaten it is pressed out, & thickened by stirring it in ye sun, which being dried is of much use for service in cures. The juice being fitly mixed with Anodynall collyries. It doth extinguish ye Herpetas, & ye Erysipelata being smeared on. And ye herb, & ye hair being beaten small & smeared on about ye stones doth help wanton dreamers, & seed shedders, & doth enfeable ye genitales being smeared on, & drive away milk, & forbids ye breasts to grow great in time of virginity & makes ye stones in children unnourishable. But that is ye most potent which grows in Crete, & in Megara and in Attica, then that which grows in Chios & Cilicia.

Smilax, which some call Thymalus, but ye Romans call it Taxus, is a tree like unto ye fir in ye leaves & bigness, growing in Italy, & Narbonie which is by Spain. But ye chicken which eat ye fruit of that which grows in Italy, wax black, & ye men that eat it fall into a looseness. But that in Narbonie doth participate of so great force, that they which sit under, or fall asleep are hurt of the shade, & that often times they die. But this is storied of it, to ye end that it may be taken heed of before.

Apocynon, which some call Cynanchon, some Pardalianches some Cynomoron, & some call it Cynocrambe [some Cynoctonon, some Phaleos, some Cynanche, some Oligoros, some Hippomanes, some Onistis, some Ophioscorodon, some Cynarice, some Elaphoscordon, ye Magi Paralysis, the Romans Brassica rustica, & some Canina]. It is a shrub having long withy-like, rods, hard to break, leaves like to Ivy but softer & sharper towards ye top, of an heavy scent somewhat viscous, full of yellow juice; but ye fruit as a cod of beans about ye thickness of a finger, like a bladder, in which are little seeds, hard, small, black. The leaves of this being made into bread, & cast unto them doth kill dogs, wolves, foxes, panthers, and forthwith dissolves ye hips of them.

Nerion which some call Rododaphne, some Rhododendron [some Spongos, some Haemostaris, ye Romans Rhododendron, ye Lucanians Icmane, ye Egyptians Scinphe, ye Africans Rhodedaphane], is a known shrub, having longer and thicker leaves than ye almond, but ye flower like a rose, and a fruit like that of ye Almond, as with an horn, which being opened is full of a downy nature, like to thistle-downs, ye root sharp-pointed, & long, woody, brackish to ye taster. It grows in enclosed greens & sea-bordering places & in places near rivers. But ye flower & the leaves have a power destructive of dogs & of Asses & of Mules & of most four-footed living creatures, but a preserving one of men, being drank with wine against ye bitings of venemous beasts, & ye more if you mixed it with Rue, but ye more weak sort of living creature, as goats & sheep, die, if they drink ye maceration of them.

Of Fungi there is a double difference, for either they are edible, or they are poisonous, & come to be so upon many occasions, for either they grow amongst rusty nails or rotten rags, or ye holes of serpents, or amongst trees properly bearing harmful fruits. Such as these have also a viscous concreted humour, but being laid away after they are taken up, they are quickly corrupted growing rotten. But they which are not such sod in broth are sweet, yet for all that, those taken too much doe hurt, being hard of digestion, choking, or breeding choler. But all are helped being drenched with Nitre, and oil, or lie with ye decoction of sharp brine, or of Thymbra, or drinckifyed with Origanum, or hen dung with acetum, or lohockified with much honey, but they are nourishing, & hard to dissolve, but are cast out whole, as for ye most part, with ye excrements.

Colchicum, which some call Ephemerum, some agrestis Bulbus [ye Romans Bulbus agrestis] the Autumn ceasing, sends out a whitish flower like to ye flower of saffron; afterward it bears leaves like to ye Bulbus but fatter, a stalk a span long, having a redd seed, ye root having a bark of a tawny black which being peeled is found white, & tender, & full of liquor, & sweet. But ye Bulbus hath a midling partition, at which it sends out ye flower. It grows very much in Messenia, & at Colchos. But being eaten it killeth by choking like to ye mushrumps. But we have described it, that it may not lie hid and be eaten instead of Bulbus, for it is strangely alluring to ye unexperienced for ye pleasantness. But there help them which eat these, whatsoever helps such as eat mushrumps, & cows milk being drank, so that when this is at hand, there needs no other help.

Ephemerum, which some call agrestis Iris, hath leaves & a stalk like to ye Lilly, but whiter, ye flowers white, bitter, & ye seed soft. The root lies under being single, ye thickness of a finger, long, binding, sweet smelling. It grows in woods, & shady places. The root of this is a remedy for ye toothache, by way of collution. But ye leaves being sodden in wine & smeared on do dissolve Oedemata, & tumors, having not yet an humour.

Helxine, but some call it Sideritis, some Parthenium, some Heraclia, some Asyria, some agrestis Hygiena, some Clibadium, some Polyonymon. It grows in mounds, & walls, it hath thin little stalks, somewhat red, leaves like to Mercury, rough, & about ye stalks, as it were little seeds, sharp, catching hold of cloths. The leaves have a binding cooling faculty, whence being smeared on, they heal Erysipelata, Condylomata, adustions, ye Pani beginning and all manner of inflammation, ye Oedemata, but ye juice of it being mixed with Cerussa, & smeared on, doth help ye Erysipelata & ye Herpetas, & feet gouts, being taken with Cyprin & goats grease, & ye juice being supt up as much as a Cyathus, helps such as have coughed long, and it is a profitable Gargarisme & ointment for ye enflamed Tonsillae, & being dropt in with Rosaceum it is good for ear pains.
87. ALSINE. Parietaria cretica (Cf. Bk. ii, ch. 214)

Alsine, some call it Mouse ear [some Anthyllion, some Myortochon, some Myortosplenon, ye Romans muris Auricula, ye Africans Laphotholabat] from ye having leaves like to ye little ears of a mouse, & it is called Alsine because it loves shady and woody places: it is an herb like to Helxine, but lower, and longer-leaved, & not rough, & being bruised it smells of Cucumers. But it hath a cooling binding faculty, being good for ye inflammations of ye eyes being smeared on with Polenta, & ye juice of it being droped in for ye pain of ye ears, & in general it performs whatsoever Helxine doth.
88. PHAKOS EPI TON TELMATON. Lemna sp.

Lens which grows in marshes [some call it wild Lens, some Epipteron, ye Romans Viperalis, some Iceosmigdonos] is found in standing waters, being a moss like to Lenticula, cooling by operation. It is good for all inflammations, & Erysipelata, and feet gouts, being laied on both by itself, and with Polenta, & it also conglutinates the Enterocelas which are upon children.

Sempervivum ye great [but some Aeithales, some Ambrosion, some Chrysospermon, some Zoophthalmon, some Bouophthalmum, some Stergethron, some Aeonion some Aichryson, some Holochryson, some Chrysanthemom, some Protogonom, some Boros, some Notios, ye Magi Paronychia, some Chrysitis, ye Romans Ceriacuspia, some Jovis caulis, some Leapetes, some Sedum majus ye Egyptians Pamphanes] is so-called because of ye ever green of ye leaves. It sends out stalks a cubit long, or rather more, ye thickness of ye great finger, fat, very flourishing having ye incuts, as it were, of ye Characian Tithymal. The leaves fat, ye bigness of ye great finger, like a tongue towards ye top, & those of the leaves below bending downwards, but those about ye head set together one to another, describing an eye-like circle. It grows in hilly, & tylie places. But some plant it on the houses. It hath a cooling, binding faculty, being good for ye Erysipelieta, ye Herpetas, Nomas, inflammations of ye eyes, Ambustions, ye feet gouts, the leaves being laid on by them selves & with Polenta. But ye juice is poured on with Polenta, & Rosaceum, for headaches, and it is given in drink to ye Phalangian-bitten, & to ye belly-fluxed, & to ye dysentericall. And being drank with wine it drives out ye teretes lumbricos, & in a Pessum it stops ye womanish flux. And the juice is profitably anointed on the weak-eyed, by reason of blood.

Sempervivum parvum [some call Petrophues, some Brotion some Theobrotion, some Crobysson, some Chimerinen, some Ceraunia, ye Romans Vitalis, some herba Semperviva, ye Egyptians Etiicelta]. It grows in walls, & rocks, & mounds, & in somewhat shady ditches; ye little stalks from one root, many, thin, full of little leaves, round, fat, small, sharp on ye top. It sends out also a stalk in ye middle, in bigness about a span, having a tuft & flowers, thin, & green. The leaves of this have ye self same force to ye aforesaid.
[Sempervivum ye thin-leaved, some call Sempervivum parvum, some Petrophyes, some Sempervivum sylvestre, ye Romans Sempervivum minus.]

But there seems also to be a third kind of Sempervivum which some have called Portulaca agrestis, or Telephium, but ye Romans Illecebra. This hath ye little leaves thicker like to those of Portulaca, and rough. It grows in rocks.. But it hath a warming, sharp, exulcerating faculty, dissolving of Strumas, being laid on with Axungia.

Umbilicus Veneris, some Scytalium, some Cymbalium [some Hortus Veneris, some terrae umbilicus, some Stichis, some Stergthron, ye Romans Umbilicus Veneris] hath a leaf as an Acetabulum, round, hiddenly hollow. A short little stalk in ye middle, in which is ye seed: a root as ye Olive, round. The juice of this, and of ye leaves being anointed on round with wine, or squirted in, do loosen ye stoppages of ye skin in ye privities; being laid on it doth help both inflammations & ye Erysipelata, & ye Perniones, & ye Strumas & a burning stomach. But ye leaves being eaten with ye root doth break ye stones, & move ye urine & it is given with Mulsum to ye Hydropicall, & they use it also for love-medicines.

There is also another kind of Cotyledon [which some call Cymbalium] having broader, & fat leaves, like little tongues, thick about ye root, describing as it were an eye in ye middle, like as ye greater Sempervivum, binding by ye tast; a little thin, stalk, & upon it flowers, & seeds like to Hypericum, but ye root greater. It is good for ye same uses that Sempervivum is.

The Nettle which some call Knide [some Adice, ye Romans Urtica, ye Egyptians Selepsion, ye Dacians Dyn. Another Acalyphe some call it Knide, ye Romans Urtica mollis]. There is a double kind of them, for ye one is wilder, sharper, & blacker in ye leaves but it hath a seed like to Hempseed, but smaller, and ye other is of a thin seed, & not alike sharp. But ye leaves of either of them being smeared on with salt, doe heal things bitten by dogs, & Gangranicall, and malignant, & cancrous, & ye foulness of ulcers, & luxations, tumours, ye Parotidas, ye Pani, Apostumations. But they are laid to ye splenicall with Cerat. And ye leaves being beaten small, & applied with the juice are good for ye fluxes of blood from ye nostrils. They move also ye menstrua being small beaten & applied with Myrrh, & ye new leaves being laid to, do restore ye fallings down of ye matrix. And ye seed being drank with Passum doth incite to conjunction, & doth unstop ye womb, but being licked in with honey it helps ye Orthopneas & Pleurisies & Peripneumonies, & fetcheth up ye stuff out of ye Thorax. It is mixed also with septicalls. But ye leaves being sodden together with small shell fish, do mollify ye bellies, dissolve windiness, move ye urine. But being sodden with Ptisana, doth bring up ye stuff from ye Thorax. But ye decoction of ye leaves being drank with a little myrrh, moveth ye menstrua, but ye juice being gargarized doth keep down an inflamed Uvula.

Galiopsis, some call it Guleobdolon [some Galephos, ye Egyptians Aethopi, ye Romans Urtica Labeonis]. Ye whole little shrub with the stalk, and the leaves is like unto ye nettle, but smoother are ye leaves, and strongly smelling in ye being bruised. The flowers near a purple, thin. It grows in hedges & by the ways & in house courts, everywhere. The leaves, & ye juice, & ye stalk, & ye seed, have a faculty dissolving of hardnesses, and of Cancers, & of the Strumas, of ye Parotidas, & ye Pani. But they must lay this cataplasme on twice a day, making the Cataplasme luke warm, & ye decoction of this is used by way of fomentation profitably. It is good also for ye Nomas, Gangreens & rotten ulcers, being laid on with salt.

Gallion, which some call Gallerium, some Galatium, but is it so-called because coagulates milk instead of Rennet. But it hath ye little branches, & ye leaf very like to Aparina, yet straight, & a yellowish flower on ye top, thin, thick, abundant, well smelling, of which ye flower is smeared on for ye fire-burnings, & it stops fluxes of blood. It is mixed also with Ceratum Rosaceum, being sunned till it becometh white, & such as this is medicamentum acopon. But ye root doth provoke to conjunction. It groweth in marshy places.

Senecio [some call it Erechthites, ye Romans Herbulum, some Senecium] is a little stalk a cubit high, reddish having continued little leaves, like Eruca, jagged at ye outsides, but a great deal smaller; ye flowers yellowish, quickly opening, & after blowing turning up ye foresaid downs, whence also it was called Erigeron because ye flowers in ye spring doe turn gray like hair: ye root is for no use. It grows chiefly upon stone walls unmortered, & about townes. But ye leaves with the flowers have a cooling faculty. Whence ye leaves being smeared on with a little wine, or else of themselves do cure ye inflammations of ye stones, & of ye seat, but with Manna Thuris, it heals both other wounds, & those in ye nerves, & ye downs being smeared on by themselves in acetum perform ye same. Yet being drank new, they cause strangling. But ye whole stalk being sod with water, & drank with Mustum do cure ye pains of ye stomach which come of choler.

Thalictrum hath leaves like to Coriander, but fatter, & a little stalk ye thickness of Rue, on which are ye leaves, which being beaten small, & so laid on do cicatrize ye long continuedness of ulcers: it grows especially in fields.

Muscus marinus [some call it Ballaris, some Irane, ye Romans Gnomeusilum] it grows upon stones, and shells by ye Sea, hairy, slender, without stalk, very binding, being good for inflammations, & feet gouts wanting binding.

Fucus marinus, one sort of it is broad, ye other somewhat long & drawing to a purple, but ye third, white, but growing in Crete near ye ground, very flourishing & incorruptible. All have a refrigerating faculty in Cataplasmes being good for gouty affections, & inflammations, but they must use them while they are moist before they be dry. But Nicander saith also, that ye Phoenician is good against serpents, which some have thought to be that which women use, that being a little root, in like sort also called, Fucus.

Potamogeton [some call it Stachyitis, ye Romans Fatalis, ye Egyptians Ethenchis] ye leaf is like to ye Beet, thick, & a little standing out above ye water. It cooleth & bindeth, being good for itches & feeding and old ulcers. But it is so-called, because it grows in marshes, & in watery places. [There is also another Potamogeton, the leaves alike, but longer, and thinner, ye little stalks alike, thin, full of a reddish seed, which being eaten, binds; but being beaten small with wine, & drank ye quantity of an Acetabulum, it helps ye dysentericall, & Coeliacall: it stays ye red womanish flux. But it grows in watery, & marshy places.]
102. STRATIOTES O EN TOIS UDASIN. Stratiotes aloides

Stratiotes, that which grows in the water, some call it River-Stratiotes [ye Egyptians Tibus, the Magi ye blood of a cat] but it is so called because it swims upon ye waters, & lives without a root, but it hath a leaf like that of Sempervivum, yet greater, & having a cooling faculty, that stops ye bloody fluxes which come from ye kidnies. Being drank & being smeared on with Acetum, it keeps wounds & ye Erysipelata, & ye Oedemata uninflammed.

Stratiotes Millefolius is a little small shrub a span long, & more, having leaves like ye feather of a young bird, but ye excrescencies of ye leaves are very short & jagged. But ye leaves are most chiefly like in ye shortness & the roughness to wild Cumin & yet they are shorter, & the tuft is thicker than this, & fuller, for it hath on ye top small shoots, on which are ye tufts, after ye fashion of Dill: ye flowers small white. It grows in somewhat rough fields, and especially about ye ways. This very herb is excellent good for a flux of blood, and old and new ulcers, & for Fistulaes.

Verbascum [some call it Plenos, ye Romans Verbasculum, some Foeminalis] hath a double difference, for one sort of it is white, ye other black; & of ye white, one is female, & ye other male, ye leaves therefore of ye female are like to Brassica, but with much more hair, & broader, and white: the stalk a cubit high & more, white, somewhat rough: ye flowers white, or of a faint aker, ye seed black, ye roote long, of an hard taste, having ye thickness of a finger: it grows in fields. But that which is called ye male, is white-leaved, but somewhat long, & narrower in ye leaves & thinner in the stalk. But the black is like to ye white in all things yet it is broader-leaved, & blacker in the leaves.

There is also another sort, called wild, bearing high rods & treeish, the leaves like to Sage, but it hath sprigs about the rods like as Marrubium, a yellowish flower, like gold. These Phlomides also are twofold, rough, growing near ye ground, having round leaves.

There is a 3rd Phlomis, called Lychnitis, some Thryallis, having 3 or 4, or more thick, fat, rough leaves good for Candle wicks. Of the 2 former, ye root is binding. Whence as much as an knucklebone is profitably given with wine in a drink to ye fluxing But the decoction of it is good for ruptures & convulsions and Squatts, & old coughs, and being colluted assuageth ye toothaches, but ye golden-coloured in ye flowers, dyes the hair, & wehresoever it be put, draws to it woodworms. But ye leaves sodden in water are laid on for Oedemata, & inflammations of ye eyes, and with honey or wine for eating ulcers. But with Acetum, it heals wounds, & helps ye Scorpion-smitten. But ye leaves of ye wild kind are cataplasmes for ye ambusti. And they say that ye leaves of the female being laid up together with figs, doth keep them from corrupting.

Aethiopis, & this hath leaves, like to Verbascum very rough & thick, in a circle about the bottom of ye root: ye stalk 4-square, thick, & rugged, like to Apiastrum, or Arction: putting out many wings, but ye seed about ye bigness of Ervum, with two in one vessell: many long, thick, roots from the very bottom, gluey to ye taster, but being dry, they become black and hard, like unto horns. It grows abundantly in Messenia, and in Ida. The root of this being sodden & drank, doth help ye Sciatica, ye Pleurisy, ye spitting of blood, & ye roughness of ye Artery. But it is taken with honey instead of a Lohoc.

Arction, some call it Arcturum, & this hath ye leaves like to Verbascum, but rougher, and rounder, ye root, tender, sweet, white, but ye stalk soft, long, like to little Cumin. The root & the seed of this being sodden in wine are of force being held in ye mouth, to assuage the toothache, & it is a fomentation of ye ambusti, & ye Perniones It is drank also for Sciaticas, & ye Dysurie, in wine.

Arcion, but some call it Personata, Prosopis, some Prosopion [some Aparine, ye Romans Personacea, some Lappa] hath leaves like to those of Colocynthis, yet greater, & harder, & blacker, and rough: a whitish stalk, & sometime also ye herb is without: ye root great & white within, but without black. Which being drank ye quantity of one dragm with Pine kernels doth help ye spitters of blood & of corrupt matter, & it assuageth ye griefs that come by wrenchings about ye joints, being smeared on; & the leaves are profitably laid on upon old ulcers.

Petasites is a little stalk higher than a cubit, ye thickness of ye great finger, on which is a great leaf like an hat, lying upon it as a mushrump. Being good for malignant and Phagedoenicall ulcers, being beaten small, & so smeared on.
Epipactis, which some call Elleborine [some Borion] is a small little shrub, having very small little leaves. It is drank against poisons, and for ye griefs in ye Liver.

Fumaria [which some call Corydalion or Coryon, some Corydalion sylvestre, some Capnos that is amongst barley, some Capnites, some Marmarites, some Capnogorion, some Chelidonion parvum, some Peristerion, some Cantharis, some Caliocri, ye Romans Apium, some Fumaria, ye Egyptians Cynx, some Tucis] is a shruby little herb like to Coriander, very tender; but ye leaves whiter, & of ye colour of ashes, many everywhere, ye flower purple, ye juice sharp, quickning ye sight, drawing of tears, whence also it drew this name. But being smeared on with gum it is of force also not to suffer ye hairs pulled from off ye eye-brows to grow again. The Herb being eaten expels cholerick urine.

Lotus Sativa, which some call Trifolium [some Tripodion, some Trifolium] grows in gardens, which being juiced & mixed with honey doth dissolve ye Argema, & ye nubeculas, & ye Albugines, & ye things that darken ye apples of ye eyes.

Lotus Sylvestris which some call Libyon [some Trifolium, ye Romans Trifolium minus] grows in great abundance in Libya, bearing a stalk of 2 cubits or rather more, having many wings, ye leaves like the 3 leaved Lotus which grows in meadows, the seed like to Foenigreec, but a great deal smaller, medicine-like in ye taste. But it hath a warming faculty gently binding, cleansing away of ye spots, which are upon the face, & ye sun burnings, being anointed on with honey. Being beaten small, & drank of itself, or else with ye seed of mallows with wine or Passum it helps ye griefs about ye bladder.

Cytisus [which some call Teline, some Lotus grandis, some Trifolium, ye Romans Trifolium majus] is a shrub all white as Rhamnus, sending out branches a cubit long, or more, about which ye leaves like to Foenigreeck, or to Lotus trifolia, but smaller, & having a greater backbone, & when crushed with ye fingers smelling of Eruca, & in the taste like to green Cicers; but the leaves have a cooling faculty, dissolving of Oedemataes in ye beginning, being beaten small, & smeared on with bread. But the decoction of them being drank doth move ye urine. But some do plant it near the Bee hives, as an allurer of ye bees.

Lotus, which grows in Egypt in ye water, the fields being over-flown, is a stalk like that of ye bean, having a little flower, white, like ye Lilly, which they say doth open at ye rising of ye sun, & close when it sets, & that all the head is hidden in the water, and that again at ye rising of ye sun it stands above, but the head is like ye greater Poppy, in which is ye seed, as Milium, which they in Egypt drying doe cast into their bread-making: it hath a root like to Malum Cydonium, which is also itself eaten both raw, or sodd. But being sod, it is answerable in quality to ye yolk of an egg.

Millefolium [which some Myllophullon, some Stratiotice, some Achillea, ye Romans Millefolium, some supercilium Veneris, ye French Beliucandas] is a little stalk, growing single, tender, of one root, about which are many smooth leaves, like to Fennill, whence also it is named. But ye stalke is somewhat hollow, of divers colours, as it were of set purpose artificially polished. It grows in marshy places. This keeps ye late hurts of ulcers uninflamed, being smeared on green, or dry with Acetum. It is also given to drink for falls, with water & salt.

Myrrhis [which some call Conila] but some call it Myrrha, is like to Cicuta in ye stalk, & in ye leaves, but it hath a long root, tender, round, sweet smelling, pleasant to be eaten. Now being drank with wine doth help the Phalangian-bitten, and it purgeth out the menstrua & after-purgeings, and being sodden in liquor to be supt, it is given profitably to the Phthisical. And some do say, that it being drank twice or thrice a day with wine in pestilentiall seasons it doth help men to make them continue uninfected.

Myagros which some call Melampyrom, is an herb of ye brushy kind, of 2 cubits, having ye leaves like to those of Rubia, pale, ye seed like to a neck, or verticillum, fat, which they use bruising it being scorched, & anointing ye rods, & using it instead of a candle But it seems that ye fat of them doth make sleek, & smooth the roughnesses of ye body.

Oenagra, which some call Oenothera, some Onuris, is a shrub like a tree, of a bigness, having leaves like the Almond tree, but broader, & answerable to those of ye Lilly. The flowers Rose-like, great. But ye root white, long, which being dried, yields forth ye smell of wine. It grows in hilly places. But ye Dilutum of ye root being drank of ye wild Living creatures, hath ye power, to make them tame, & being smeared on it assuageth wild ulcers.

Cirsium [which some call great Buglosse, ye Romans Spina mollis] is a tender stalk, as of 2 cubits, three-square: ye small leaves from beneath rose-like, having the corners prickly by distances, soft, but ye leaves like to Buglosse, pretty rough and longer, somewhat white, prickly at ye ends. But the roundall at ye upper end of ye stalk is rough, & on it little heads purple on ye top, turning into down. Andreas writeth that it being bound upon ye agrieved place doth cease ye pains of ye Varices.

Aster Atticus [which some call Asteriscos, some Asterion, some Bubonium, some Sowes-eye, ye Romans Inguinalis, ye Dacians Rathibis] is a woody little rod, having a purple flower on ye top or a yellowish one, cut round about as ye little head of Anthemis, but it hath small leaves like a star. But ye leaves about ye stalk are somewhat long, & rough. It helps an inflamed stomach being smeared on & ye inflammations of ye eyes, & ye thighes, & ye fallings down of ye seat. They say also, that ye purple part of ye flower being drank with water doth help ye Synanchicall, & ye Epilepsies of children. But it is good being applied fresh, & moist for ye inflammations of ye thighes. But being gathered when it is dry, with ye left hand of ye pained party, & hanged about ye thigh, it doth free him of ye pain. [But it grows amongst rocks, & rugged places. The stars of this do shine in ye night, for they which do not know it when they see it, do think it to be a spirit, but it is found by ye keepers of sheep, Crateuas ye Herbalist relates, that this being beaten when it is green, with old swines grease, is good for ye mad-dog-bitten, and the throat-swollen, but being suffited it drives away serpents.]

Isopyron, but some Phasiolum call it, from its being like to Phasiolus, that which towards ye upper leaf bears a pampinus. There are on ye top of ye stalk thin little heads, full of small seeds, like to Melanthium according to ye taste, but ye leaf to Annis. The seed of this being drank with Melicrate doth help ye griefs about ye Thorax, & coughs, & is good for ye blood-spitters, & ye liver-sick.

Viola [which some call Dasypodion, some Priapeion, wild Violet, or Cybelion, ye Romans Setialis, some Muraria, or Viola purpurea] hath a leaf less than Ivy, & thinner, but blacker, and not unlike a little stalk in ye midst from ye root, on which a little flower very sweet, of a purple: it grows in shady and rough places. But it hath a cooling faculty, so that ye leaves being laid on by themselves, and with Polenta do help a burning stomach, and ye inflammations of ye eyes, & the fallings down of ye seat. And they say that ye purple part of ye flower, being drank with water doth help ye Synanchicall & Epilepsies that are upon children.

Cacalia, some call it Leontice, bears white leaves of a good bigness, but ye stalk of them in ye middle, is straight, white, having a flower like to Bryonie, but it growes on hills. The root of this being macerated in wine as Tragacantha & licked in, or chewed by itself doth cure coughs, and roughnesses of ye Artery, but ye grains which come after ye flowering, beaten small, & taking it with Cerat, & smearing it on, doe keep ye face extended & without wrinkles.

Bunium [but some Aton, some Actine, some Anemosphoron, ye Magi Paradacry, ye Egyptians Erxoe, ye Romans Scopa regia, ye Africans Zigar, some Thepso] sends out a quandrangular stalk, of a good length, a fingerly thickness, but ye leaves like to Smallage, but much thinner, near to those of Coriander, ye flower of Dill: ye seed of a sweet scent, less than that of Hyoscyamus. It is ureticall warming, a drawer out of ye seconds, & of fit use for ye spleen, & ye kidnies, & ye bladder. But both moist & dry, & when juiced with the roots & stalks, & leaves, it is used with Melicrate..

Pseudobunium is a small shrub of a span long in Crete, having leaves like to Bunium, of a sharp taste. And 4 small branches of this being drank with water, are of force to heal ye Tormina, & Stranguries, and ye pain of ye side. It dissolves also the Strumas, being laid on luke warm with salt, & wine.

Hedera humi repens [but some, Chamaeleuce, some unfruitful Ivy, some ye crown of ye earth, some Selinitis, ye Romans Hedera pluviatica] hath many, leaves like to Ivy leaves, but longer and thinner; small branches of a span, full of leaves from ye ground 5 or 6: ye flowers like to Leucoion, smaller, & strongly bitter to the taste. Ye root thin, white, unuseful. It grows in tilled places. But ye leaves are good for ye Ischiaticall being drank as much as 3 Oboli to 3 Cyathi in water, for 40 or 50 days. It cleanseth away also ye Icterus being drank after that sort for 6 or 7 days.
Chamoepeuce is good for ye griefs of ye loins, beaten small & drank in water; but it is an herb that is all green, having little leaves crumpled, & the branches crumpled, and flowers like Roses.

Buglossum [which ye Magi call genitura felis, Osthanes Tzanuchi; ye Egyptians Antuenrin Besor, ye Romans Lingua Bovis, some Libanis, ye Africans Ansanaph, it grows in plain & vaporiferous places, but it is gathered in ye month July. They say that it is good for ye rigors of agues: for a Tertian give to drink of the Buglosse that hath 3 stalks, seething to thirds ye whole herb with the roots, & of ye seed; & of that which hath 4 stalks, to him that hath a quartan, but ye seething of these, must be with wine. And they say, that it is of good use for Abscessus] is like to Verbascum, but it hath a leaf lying on ye ground, both rough, & blacker, like to ye tongue of an ox, which being put into wine is thought to be a cause of mirth.

Cynoglosson [which some call Phytom, some Caballation, some Splenion, some Scolimos, ye Romans Lingua Canis, some Lingua Canina] hath leaves like to ye broad-leaved Plantan, but narrower and smaller, downy, without stalk, strewed on ye ground: it grows in sandy places. But ye leaves beaten small with old swine grease, hath ye power to heal things bitten of dogs, & ye Alopeciae, and Ambustions; but ye herb being sodden, & drank with wine, is a mollifier of ye belly.
Phyteuma hath leaves like to Radicula, but smaller, much seed, bored through, little root, thin, close to ye earth, which some relate to be good for a love medicine..

Leontopodion [which some call Zoonychon, some Aetonychon, some Cemus, some Damnamene, some Idiophyton, some Phytobasila, some Crossion, some Crossophthoon. The Magi Sanguis Crocodili, some Crocomerion, ye Egyptians Daphnoenes, ye Romans Minercium, some Neumatus, some Palladium, some Falmmula.] is a 2-finger-long little herb, having slender small leaves strong, ye length as of four fingers, or also 3, rough, more woolly towards ye root & whitish on ye tops of ye stalks, little heads, as it were bored through, in which are black flowers, but ye seed to it is hardly seen, because of ye down that doth enwrap it: ye root lying under is small. And they also say that this is of set use for love medicines, being hanged about, and that it dissolves small swellings.

Hippoglosson [And some also call this Antirrhinon, some Anarrhinon, & some also call it Lychnis sylvestris] is a little shrub like to Myrtus agrestis, & having thin leaves, but it hath prickly hair, & on ye top, as it were a little tongue, by ye leaves. But ye hair seems to be an Amulett profitable for ye headachers. And ye root & the juice are mixed also with malagmata.

Antirrhinon, which some call Anarrhinon & some have called it Lychnis agrestis, is an herb like to Anagallis in ye leaves & ye stalk, but ye flowers are purple, like ye Leucoion, but lesser, whence also it was called sylvestris Lychnis. But it bears a fruit like ye nostrils of a calf, carnation like in appearance. But it is storied that this is opposite to poisons, being hanged about one, & that it makes one fair, being anointed on with lilly-oil, or Cyprine.

Catanance [which some call Damnamene, some Dionysias, some Thyrsion, some Demos, some Cemos, some Crotion, the Magi Archaras, some Arcopus, ye Romans Herba Filicula, some Datisca, some Jovis madius, ye Dacians Caropithla]. One sort of it hath long leaves as those of Coronopis, a thin root, 6 or 7 rush-like heads, in which ye seed like to Ervum. But being withered it bends down to ye ground, & is like ye clawes of a dead kite. But ye other hath ye bigness of a little apple, ye root small, about ye bigness of an Olive, but ye leaves like in fashion & colour to ye Olive, but soft, strewed on the earth, and jagged: ye seed small on ye little rods, bored through in many parts like a Cicer, of a phoenician colour. But some report that both kinds are good for Philters, & they say that the Thessalian women do use them.

Tripolium [which some call Psyche, some Meris, some Potamogeton, some Stachyites, ye Romans Calamaris] grows in places near ye sea, which ye sea overflows & departs, neither is it in ye dry, nor in ye sea. But it hath leaves like unto Woade, yet thicker, a stalk a span long, jagged towards ye top. It is said, that ye flower of this, doth change his colour three times a day, in ye morning white, about noon purple, & at ye evening Phoenician. Ye root white, sweet-smelling hot to ye taster, which being drank in wine ye quantity of 2 dragms, doth expel water & urine by ye belly. It is cut also for Alexipharnicall medicnes.

Adiantum, which some call Polytrichon [some Callitrichon, some Trichomanes, some Ebenotrichon, some Argion, some Coriandrum aquaticum, the Egyptians Epier, ye Romans Cincinnalis, some Terrae Capillus, some Supercilium terrae, ye Dacians Phithophthethela] hath little leaves like Coriander, jagged on the top, but ye little stalks on which they grow, are black, very thin, a span long, glistning. The leaves like to Filix, very small. But it bears neither stalk, nor flower, nor seed: ye root is unuseful. The decoction of ye herb being drank is of force to help ye Asthmaticall, Dyspnœicall, Ictericall, Splenicall, dysureticall. It breaks also ye stones & stays ye belly, & helps ye venemous-beast-bitten, & ye flux of ye stomach, being drank with wine. It drives out also ye menstrua, & after purgaments. It stays also ye spitting up of blood. It is smeared on also raw, for venemous-beast-bitten things & thickens ye Alopeciae, it disperseth ye Strumas: with Lye, it wipes off ye furfures & ye Achores. But with Ladanum & with Oleum Myrtinum & Sufinum, or else Oesypum, & wine it staies ye falling hair; & ye decoction of it being rubbed on with Lye & wine doth the same. And it makes cocks and quailes ye more fighting when mixed with their meat. But it is planted for ye sheep about sheep-coats. It grows in shady and marshy places, and moist walls, & about fountains.

Trichomanes, some also call this Adiantum [some Pterion, some Opteron, ye Romans Capillaris, some Pinula, some Filicula] grows about ye same places, being like to Fearne, very small, having ye leaves slender, in order on either side, like to Lenticula, one over against ye other, upon thin little rods, and glittering, and of a bad taste, somewhat black. It is thought it can do ye same things, to ye afore spoken of.

Xanthium, which some call Phasganon, some Antithesion some Chascanon, some Choeradolethron, & some also call this Aparine [ye Romaons Lapa]. It grows in fertile places, & marshes that are dried up; it hath a stalk a cubit long, clean, cornery, and many wings upon it, but it hath leaves like to Atriplex, having incuts, near in the smell to Nasturtium, but a round fruit as a great Olive, prickly, as ye balls of the Plane tree taking hold of clothes after ye touch.
