And it is good for ye Synanchicall & for ye Columella that is fallen, and for ye pain of ye teeth, being rolled about them when it is warm.

Oxymel is made thus. Taking 5 Heminae of Acetum & of sea salt, 2 pound, of honey 20 pounds, of water 10 Heminas, having mixed all, seeth it until it boil ten times, & having cooled it, pour it into another vessel. It is thought being taken, to expel gross humors, to help ye Ischiaticall, & ye Arthriticall, & Epilepticall, & it is available also for such as are bitten of ye viper which is called Seps, & for those which have drank Meconium, or Ixia. And it is a profitable gargarisme for ye Synanchicall.

Acetum salsum being fomented on, is good for ye Nomae, rotten ulcers, dog-bitings, & the bitings of venemous beasts, & it stops the fluxes of blood, which are on such as are guelded, it being poured in warm in ye wound straight after ye surgeon hath done; & it helps ye seat that is fallen down. And it is given for a glister to ye dysentericall that have ye Nomae but afterwards, you must glisterize them with milk. Being supped up and gargarized, it kills the leeches, & it cleanseth ye furfures, & running ulcers of ye head.

Thymoxalme, which the Antients did use for such as had a weak stomach, mixing three or four Cyathi with warm water, and for ye Arthriticall, & ye puffed up with wind; it draws out also thick, and black humors, and it is made thus. Take of Thyme beaten small an Acetabulum, as much of salt, of Polenta, Rue, Pulegium, of each a little, casting them into a vessel, pour on them 6 Heminae of water, half an Hemina of Acetum, & wrapping it about with a linnen cloth set it in ye open air.

But ye Scillinum Acetum is made after this manner: having made clean a white Squill, and cut it in slices, & pierced them through with a thread, so that ye slices do not touch one another, having dried them in ye shade for 40 days, take one pound of it & put it into 12 Sextaries of good Acetum & leave it in ye Sun to be macerated 40 days, stopping the vessel carefully. Then after this having taken up ye Squill and pressed it out, cast it away, & straining ye Acetum, pour it into a vessel, & so set it up. But some do mix a pound to Sextaries of Acetum. And some, forthwith making it clean, without being dried, cast in ye like measure of Acetum & so let it steep for 6 months, & such as this is more cutting. And it is good by way of collution for loose, & swelling gums, binding & strengthening them, & for wagging teeth, effectually curing the rotten ulcers about ye mouth & stinking breaths. And being supped up, it both strengthenth ye jaws, & makes them hard, and it renders ye voice loud & clear. It is taken also for ye stomachicall, & ye hard of digestion, ye epilepticall, ye Vertiginall, ye Melancholicall, & such as are frantick, as also for womb stranglings, & swelling spleens, and Sciaticas, and it restoreth such as are extreme weak, and it makes the body sound, & well coloured, & it is also a sight-quickener & it is effectuall to be dropt in for hard-hearing, if it be poured in, & in general, it is good for all things besides exulcerations that are inward, head-aches, and griefs of ye nerves. But give to one fasting at ye beginning a little hereof to sup day by day, & a little after increasing (the dose) to a Cyathus, but some give two Cyathi, or more.

Ye wine of ye Squill is made thus: having cut asunder ye Squill, as I have said, dry it in ye Sun, afterward having cut one pound of it, and having sarced it with a thin sarce, wrap it in a thin linen cloth & put it into 20 Sextaries of good & new Must & let it be macerated 3 months, but after this having put out ye wine into another vessel, set it up having stopped it carefully. But one may also use the moist Squill, cutting it after ye fashion of a Navew and doubling the quantity; but you must sun it 40 days, & let it be very old. And furthermore ye aforesaid wine is made this way. Taking of ye Squill cut asunder, & made clean, three pounds put it into an Italian Metreta of good must, & having stopped it let it alone six months, then having strained it, & put it in another vessel, set it up. It is good for indigestions & corruptions of meat, & for such as vomit it up & for such as gross humors doe beset their belly, or stomach, for ye Splenicall, & such as have a Cachexis, & ye hydropicall, ye Ictericall, Dysureticall, ye Torminall, ye vexed with Inflations, ye Paralyticall, long continued Rigours, ye Vertiginous, & convulsions. And it expells ye menstrua, & doth not at all annoy ye Sinewes, but ye older is ye better. But you must refrain ye use of it, both in fevers & upon such as have an ulcer within.

But wines are made in divers ways with sea-water. For some after that ye grapes are gathered mix sea-water, others first sun them, and so tread them, mixing sea-water, others making Raisins of ye sun of ye grapes, steep them in hogsheads with sea-water; & such wine as this becomes sweet: but yet those, which are made of an harder rellish to the taste, are good against ye foresignes of coming agues if there be no better at hand & for ye bringing down of ye belly, & rotten spitters, & ye hard-bellied, and as many as are touched in ye head by ye Aminaean wines. And yet these too are bad for ye stomach, & breeders of wind.

But that ye history may be full, for such as love histories, we think it not amiss to describe ye making also of many other sorts of wine, not because the use of them is much, or necessary, but that we may seem to fail in nothing. And of them there are some, less curious to be made, yet falling into use, as that of Quinces, of Pears, & Siliquae & that which is made of Myrtle berries.

The Cydonites wine therefore, which some do call Melites, is made thus. Taking out the seed of the Quinces, & cutting them as a Nauew, put 12 pounds of them into a Metreta of must for 30 days, after having strained it, set it up. It is made also thus: we must after ye beating & pressing out of ye Quinces, mix with 12 Sextaries of ye juice of these, one Sextarie of Honey, & soe it must be set up. It is binding, good for ye stomach, fitting for Dysenteries, ye Hepaticall, & ye Nephriticall, & ye Dysureticall.

And Melomeli, which also is called Cydonomeli is made thus. The Quinces, having their seed taken out, are cast into good store of honey, so that they be covered. This becomes pleasant after an year, being like to Mulsum. It serves for ye same purposes as the confection before it.
Hydromelon is made thus: one Metreta of ye Melomeli of Quinces is mixed with two Metretas of sodden water, and sunned in ye days under ye Dog star, & ye virtue of this is ye same.

But Omphacomelitis is made after this fashion. Taking uripe grapes not yet changing colour, sun them for 3 days, & after that having pressed them, put to 3 parts of ye juice one part of ye best pruified measurable honey & sun it, having poured it into vessels. It hath a repressing, refrigerating power, whence it is good for ye stomachicall, Coeliacall, but the use of it is after an year.

Wine of Pears, is made in like sort, as that also that is made of quinces, but let ye pears not stand till they be over ripe. And that of ye Siliquae, and that of Medlars, & of Services, are made in like sort. But they are all binding, sourish, good for ye stomach, restraining ye fluxes within.
33. OINOS OINANTHINOS. Wine of Flowers of Wild Vine

But Vinum Oenanthinum is made thus, taking two pounds, of ye dry flower of ye wild vine new putting out, put it into a Metreta of must for 30 days, then having strained it set it up. It is good for ye weaknesses of ye stomach, want of appetite, ye Coeliacall, & dysentericall.

But wine of Pomegranates is made thus, taking ripe Apyrenian pomegranates, & having pressed out the juice of ye grains, set it up; or having sodden it two-thirds, so set it up. It is good for ye fluxes within, & for fevers accompanied with a flux of ye belly, & it is good for ye stomach, & binding of ye belly, & ureticall.

But Rodites is made thus, having bound in a linen cloth one pound of Roses, being beaten when they are dry, put it into 8 Sextaries of Must, but after three months having strained it, put it in other vessels, & set it up. It is good for such as have no fever, for ye digestion of ye stomach, & ye griefs of it, being drank after meat, and for moist bellies, & dysenteries. It is made also with ye juice of Roses & honey mixed with it, which is called Rhodomeli. It is good for the roughness in ye Artery.

But Myrteum is made thus. You must (having taken black overripe myrtle berries) beate them, and squeeze out ye juice with a Press, & put it in a vessel. But some also seeth it away two-thirds, & some again set ye berries first abroad in ye sun, & drying them mix three Heminas of water, & as much of old wine to a Choenix of them beaten, & so they strain it out, and set it up. But it is mightily binding, & good for ye stomach & profitable for a fluxing stomach, and belly, & for ye exulcerations within, and a flux, & it makes black the hair on ye head.

But Myrsinites is made thus. Men taking ye branches, & ye leaves of ye black myrtles beate them with ye Myrtle berries, & cast into three Congii of Must 10 pounds of ye Myrtle so beaten, & seeth them till 2 parts be left, or the half, & having strained it so set it up. And this is good both for ye running ulcers of ye head, & ye furfures, & exanthemata, & for ye gums, & ye Tonsillas, & for mattering ears, & it stops sweats.
And ye Lentiske wine is made after ye like manner as that of ye Myrtle.

And ye Terbinthinum is made alike, for the branches of these are taken when they have fruit, & they are of ye like force, being binding & good for ye stomach, & of fit use for fluxes of ye stomach, of ye entrails, of ye bladder, for bloody fluxes; & they cicatrize all running ulcers, being fomented on, & they represse the fluxes about ye womb, & ye seat being sate over.

Palmeum. Taking ripe Dates, such as are called common, cast them into a small hogs-head bored through in the bottom, and stopped with a pitched reed. But let ye hole be stopped with Linnen. And to ten Choinixes of dates put in 3 Congii of water. But if you would not have it too sweet, pour in five Congii, & so let it rest for 10 days. But on ye 11 taking away ye linnen cloth from ye reed, take away ye thick & sweet wine, & set it up. It is indeed sweet, yet naught for ye head, being good for fluxes, because of its binding. Whence it is fit for ye stomachicall & Coeliacall, and blood-spitters. But some mixing the same again with water, take it, and they do this ye third time, & ye fourth & ye fifth time, when that which is left grows sour.

And Catorchites which some call Suchiten is made in Cyprus like to ye Palmeum, but it differs because of some instead of water do put in the infusion of ye husks & stones of grapes new-pressed, ye like measure upon this. Dry figs are taken which are called Chelidonian, or Phoenician, but they are black, & are macerated as is aforesaid, but after 10 days ye liquor is taken out, & the same measure of ye infusion of ye husks & stones is poured on the second, & third time. In like sort by distances the 4th & 5th infusion growing sharp, is taken out: this they use for vinegar. The wine is of thinner parts & inflative, & bad for ye stomach, diverting ye appetite, yet it is good for ye belly, and ureticall, & it draws down ye menstrua, & makes milk abundant but it breeds bad blood & is a causer of ye Elephantiasis, like as Zythum is. Some also to 6 Amphoras of this liquor, cast in ten Sextaries of salt, and some one Amphora of brine, thinking it would be ye harder to be changed, & good for ye belly; & some lay Thyme and Fennill in ye bottom, then ye dry figs, & this they do by turns, until they shall have filled ye vessel.
There is made in like sort ye wine of ye Sycomores, but it turns to sharp vinegar, because ye strength of them is not able to keep ye sweetness of ye liquor that flows from them.

But ye Rosinie wine also is made in many nations but it abounds in Galatia, because the grapes remain unripe by reason of ye cold, and the wine grows sour if it be not mixed with Picea resina. But the Rosin is beaten with the bark, and half an Hemina is mixed to an Amphora; some strain it after it is sodden, taking away ye Rosin; others let it alone. These growing old become sweet. But all such as these cause head-aches, & are vertiginous yet they are digestive, & ureticall, and good for such as have distillations, & coughs, for ye Coeliacall, Dysentericall, Hydropicall, & women fluxing, & it is a glister for ye ulcerated in depth; but this blackish is more binding than ye white.

But Strobilites is made from Pine-apples being steeped in must, being new, and bruised. It performs ye same effects that Resinatum doth. But if any having steeped ye Pine-apples in must seeth them, it is good if drank copiously for ye Phthisicall.

But ye Cedar, or Juniper, or Cypress, or Bay, or Pine, or Fir wine, are made alike. We must divide ye new-cut woods when they give out fruit, lay them in ye sun, or in a bath, or near ye fire, that they may sweat & then mix one pound, to a Congius of wine; & having thus mixed them let them alone 2 months; then put it in another vessel, & having sunned it, set it up. But we must fill up ye vessels, of wines made so, for if not full they grow sour. Yet never ye less these medicinable wines are unfit for ye healthy, but they are all warming, ureticall, somewhat binding; but that of Bay, is ye most warming. There is also made a wine of ye fruit of ye greater Cedars. But we must mix half a pound of ye Cedar-berries bruised, to a Congius of Must, & sun it for 4 days, & after all this, strain it & pour it into another vessel.
There is made also (a wine) of ye fruit of Juniper berries or trees as there is of ye fruit of ye Cedar, performing ye same effects.

But Cedrites is made thus, washing ye Cedar-Rosin with sweet water, they dilute each Amphora with a Cyathus apiece, & so they fill it with must: & this also is warming & attenuating, being good for a cough so it be without a fever, & for ye griefs of ye Thorax, of ye sides, for ye Tormina, for ulcers which are in ye belly & ye entrailes, for purulent spitters, ye hydropicall, ye wombe-sick, & it is good for ye worms, & for shiverings, & it helps ye serpent-bitten, and kills serpents, & being dropped in it heals ye griefs of ye ears.

Vinum Picatum is made of moist pitch, and Must. But we must first wash ye pitch in sea-water or brine, till it grow white, & that the sea-water run clean, & then in sweet water, & to 8 Congii of Must, mix one or two ounces of pitch, & so let it stand, & after it hath been sodden, and is settled, put it in vessels. It is warming, digesting, cleansing, purging, fit to be used for ye griefs about ye Thorax, ye belly, ye Liver, ye Spleen, & ye griefs of ye womb, so that they be without a fever, & for exulcerations such as are in depth; & long continued fluxes. And it is good for coughs, slow digestions, inflations, Asthmas, & for Luxations, especially being laid on with unwashed wool.

But Absinthites is made divers ways, for some mixing one pound of Pontick Wormwood, to 40 and 8 sextaries of Italian Amphoras, seeth it till the 3rd part be left. Afterward pouring hereupon 6 Sextaries of must & half a pound of wormwood having mixed them carefully, they put it in a vessel, & strain it out when it is settled. But some put a pound of wormwood into an Amphora of must, beating it and binding it in a thin linen cloth, & so let it alone for 2 months. Others put 3, & some four ounces of wormwood & of Syrian Nard, & of Cinnamon, of Cassia, of ye flower Iuncus odoratus of ye Phoenicean Date, of each 2 ounces into a Metreta of must, & beating them in a mortar & stopping all close, they let it alone for 2 months or 3: then straining it, & putting it in other vessels, they set it up. But some put of Celtick Nard 14 ounces, & of Wormwood 40 ounces (binding it in a linen cloth) into a Metret of Must, & after 40 days put it up in other vessels. But some cast in one pound of wormwood into 20 Sextaries of Must, & 2 ounces of dry Rosin of ye Pine, & after 10 days having strained it they set it up. It is good for ye stomach, ureticall, good for ye slow of digestion, for ye liver-sick, & ye Nephriticall, and ye Ictericall, for such as want appetite, & ye agrieved at ye stomach & for ye long continued distention of ye Hypochondria and for inflations, & for ye round-wormed, for ye restrained menstrua. And it is good for ye drinking down of Ixium, being drank copiously & vomited up again.

But that Hyssop wine is the best which is made of ye Cilician Hyssop. It is ordered like to the Absinthites. We must put one pound of ye Hyssop leaves being bruised, wrapping them in a thin linen cloth, to an Amphora of Must & there are put in also small stones, that the bundle may subside at ye bottom, & after 40 days having strained it put it in another vessel. It is good for ye griefs in the Thorax & in ye side, & ye Lungs, & for old coughs, and ye Asthma. It is also Ureticall, and is good for ye Torminosi, & for ye Rigours that are in periods of fevers, it moves also ye menstrua.

And ye Chamaedryites is made in like sort to the Hyssop wine, being warming and discussing, being good for Convulsions, & ye Icteri, for ye womb inflations, slowness of digestions, for a beginning dropsy, but when it is old it is the better.

And Stoechadites is made in like manner. We must put one pound of Stoechados to six Congii. It dissolves gross humors, and inflations, & ye paines of ye side & of ye Nerves, & extreme colds. It is given also profitably to ye Epilepticall, with Pyrethrum & Sagapenum.
And there is made Acetum of Stoechas, for ye said purposes, ye herb being steeped in ye Acetum as is aforesaid, & it is effectuall for ye same things.

And a wine is made of that Betony, which they call Psychotrophon We must take the herb when it is full of ripe seed, together with ye branches, & cast one pound into 2 Congii of wine, & let it alone for 7 months, & then put it in another vessel. It is good for many of ye griefs within, as also the plant of it is. And generally all ye made wines doe receive the strength of ye mixtures, therefore to those who know ye natures of them, it is easy also to guess at the strength of ye wines. But yet ye use of wines is for ye unfeverish. And Acetum also is made of this Betony, being of good use for ye like griefs.

Tragoriganites. Let down bound in a linen cloth 4 dragms of Tragoriganum into 4 Sextaries of must, for 3 months, & then vessel it. It is good for ye Tormina, Convulsions, Ruptures, ye pains of ye side, ye running up & down of winds, hardness of digestions.

Wine of Bunium. Having beaten 2 dragms of Bunium, put it into four Heminas of Must, & doe ye other things accordingly. It is good for ye stomach-sick, for ye tired with fighting in armour, or by much riding.
Dictamnites. Steep likewise 4 dragms of Dittanie in 8 Heminas of Must. It is good for ye squeamish-stomached, & it expels ye after purgaments, & ye menstrua.

That of Marrubium. Having beaten ye leaves of full grown Marrubium 2 Choenices, put them into a Metreta of Must, & do ye other things in like sort. It is good for ye griefs about ye Thorax & for whatsoever Prasium is good for.

Thymites. Having bound an 100 ounces of Thyme beaten & sifted, in a linen cloth, put it into an Amphora of Must. It is good for hardness of digestion, want of appetite, dysenteries, griefs of ye nerves, of ye Hypochondria, for winter shiverings, & for poisons of venemous beasts that chill & putrify.
Thymbrites is made after ye same manner, & is good for whatsoever Thymites is.
But Origanites is made of Heracleoticall Origanum, after ye same fashion as Thymites, being good for ye same things.
Wine of Calaminth, Pennyroyall, Southernwood, is made like as that of Thyme is. They are good for ye stomach-sick & such as want appetite, and for the Icterus, for they are ureticall.
Wine of Conyza is made in ye like manner, but of all it is most effectuall against poisons.

But Vinum Aromatites is thus made. Having beaten small of ye Date, Aspalathus, Calamus, Celtick Nard, of each a Choenix, incorporate them with Passum & having made gobbets of a good bigness, cast them into 12 Sextaries of hard Must, and having stopped ye vessel, let it alone 40 days; then having strained it, set it up. It is made also otherwise. Take of Calamus 8 dragms, of Phu 7 dragms, of Costus 2 dragms, of ye Syriack Nard 6 dragms, of Cassia 8 dragms, of Saffron 4 dragms, of Amomum 5 dragms, of Asarum 4 dragms, having beaten small these together, and bound them in a linen cloth, put them into a Metreta of must, & after ye wine hath been sodden, vessel them anew. It is good for ye griefs of ye Thorax, of ye side, of ye Lungs, both for Dysuries, & Rigours, & for ye restrained menstrua, & being drank it is good for such as travel in extreme cold, & for such as breed gross humors. And it makes a good colour & it is both soporiferous, & an easer of pain, being of fit use for ye griefs about ye bladder, & ye kidnies.

Aromatic wine is made for distillations, coughs, crudities, inflations, & ye moisture of ye stomach, of Myrrh 2 dragms, of white Pepper 1 dragm, of Iris 6 dragms, of Dill 3 dragms, having bound these in a linen cloth (being first thoroughly beaten) put them into 6 Sextaries of wine, & after ye third day having strained it, set it up in a stone pot, & give to drink a Cyathus hereof after walking, giving it unmixed.

But Nectarites is made of Elycampane which some call Medica, some Symphytum, some Idaeum Verbascum, some Orestion, some Nectarion, having tied in a linen cloth 5 ounces of ye dry root of Elycampane, put it into 6 Congii of Must, and after 3 months, put it out. It is good for the stomach & ye thorax, & doth expel urine.

But that of ye Syriac & ye Celtick Nard, & of Malabathrum is made thus. Taking half a pound of each, put it into two Congii of Must & after 2 months strain it out. Give also of this 1 Cyathus, to three of water. It is good for ye Nephriticall, Hepaticall, dysureticall, Ictericall, ye uncoloured, & stomachicall. But some doe put 1 or 2 ounces of Acorus, 3 ounces of Celtick Nard into an Amphora of Must.
Asarites. Put 3 ounces of Asarum into 12 Heminas of Must, in like sort. It is diureticall, good for ye Hydropicall, and Ictericall, ye Hepaticall, & Ischiaticall.

But that of wild Nard. Of ye new root of wild Nard, beaten small & sifted, put likewise 8 ounces into a Congius of Must, & let it alone 2 months. It is profitable for ye Hepaticall, dysureticall, for ye inflated, & ye stomach-sick.

Daucites. Put likewise 6 dragms of ye root of Daucus, well beaten into an Amphora of Must, then pour it into another vessel. It is good for ye griefs of ye Thorax, of ye Hypochondria, of ye womb, it expels ye menstrua, moveth belchings, & ye urine. It is good for ye Cough, convulsions, & ruptures.

Wine of Sage is made in like sort. Put after ye same manner 8 ounces of Sage into an Amphora (which is a Ceramion) of Must. It is good for the griefs of ye kidnies, of ye bladder & of ye sides, & for ye spitting up of blood, for ye cough, for ruptures, convulsions, bruises, & ye stopped Menstrua.

Panacites. Put one ounce of Panax into a Congius of Must, then pour it into another vessel. It is good for Convulsions, ruptures, bruises, Orthopnaeas, & it is an abater of ye thickness of ye spleen and it is good for ye Tormina, Sciaticas, slowness of digestion, it expells ye Menstrua & it is good for ye Hydropicall, & such as are bitten of venemous beasts.

But wine of Acorus, and that of Lycoris are made after ye same manner. For we must, having steeped 80 ounces of each of them in 6 Congii (of wine) for 3 months, then put it up in another vessel. They make for the side, & ye thorax, moving also the urine.

Having bound up in a linen cloth 9 ounces of ye seed of Smallage ripe, new, & sifted, cast it likewise into an Amphora of Must. It causeth an appetite, and is good for ye stomach-sick, & dysureticall & it is also a maker of ye breath sweet.
And wine of Fenill, and of Dill, and of Parsley are made after ye same manner, being good for ye same things.

There is made also wine of ye flower of salt, more purging than that made of sea-water. But it doth trouble ye throat, & ye kidnies, ye bladder, & ye stomach. Wherefore such as this is useful neither for health nor for sickness.

There is also made a wine destructive of Embrya, for amongst ye vines planted, there is planted Veratrum, or wild Cucumber, or Scammonie, of which ye grape doth take the faculty, & the wine made of them becomes destructive. It is given mixed with water in quantity of 8 Cyathi to women fasting, having first vomited.

Thymelaeites. Cast 30 dragms of ye branches of Thymelaea together with ye fruit, into 3 Congii of Must. And order it, seething it gently, until that but 2 Congii be left, & having strained it, set it up. It purgeth watery matter & abateth ye Spleen.

Chamailaeites. After ye shrub doth flower, beating & sifting 12 dragms with ye leaves, cast them into a Congius of Must, & after 2 months pour it into another vessel. It is good for ye hydropicall, ye Hepaticall, ye wearied, & women hard to purge after child-birth.
Chamaepityinum is made after ye like manner, and is good for ye same things, being diureticall.

Mandragorites. Cutting in pieces ye bark of ye root pierce through half a pound with a thread & put them into a Metreta of Must for 3 months, afterward put it up in another vessel. An indifferent draught is half an Hemina, but it is drank, Passum beeing added thereto, in a double proportion.

But they say that an Hemina of it, being mixed with one Congius and drank brings one into an heavy & profound sleep. And that one Cyathus being drank with a sextary of wine, doth kill. But ye moderate use takes away ye sense of paine, is a thickener of fluxes, but being smelt to, or given by way of Glyster, it doth the same.

Elleborites. Cast into a Congius of Must, diluted with sea-water 12 dragms of black Ellebore, beaten small, tied in a clean linen cloth & when it hath sodden, pour it into another vessel. Or cast into a Congius of Must void of sea-water 15 or 14 ounces, having bruised them thoroughly, & having strained it, after some days use it. Give to drink hereof one Cyathus with water after bathing, for ye loosening of ye belly, to such as shall vomit after supper. Or, having bound in a linen cloth 20 dragms of Veratrum, 12 ounces of Iuncus, 13 ounces of Syriak Spica, sifted, put them into 14 Heminas of Coon wine for 40 days: after having strained it, give to drink 3 half Heminas: or else macerate for 40 days in 12 Sextaries of Sea-water sodden, 6 pounds of white Ellebore, & having strained it use it. Or macerate for 15 days in 12 Heminas of Must 12 dragms of Ellebore, 4 dragms of Aphronitrum, & having strained it use it after six months. And this also maketh infants abortive. Or else take a Metreta of Must of Raisins dried in ye Sun (now a Metreta is 20 Congii) & Cast Gypsum 20 dragms into ye wine, & let it alone 2 days: And put 30 ounces of black Ellebore tied in a knot, of Calamus 30 ounces, of Iuncus odoratus 30 ounces, of Juniper berries, half a Choenix & a 4th part, but of Myrrhe, & saffron, of each an ounce: having bound them in a linen cloth, hang them in ye wine 40 days, then strain it, & mixing it with water give 2 or 3 Cyathi. It doth purge women after child-births & abortments, and it draws out ye Embrya, & is available for womb-stranglings.

Scammonites. Of ye root of Scammonie digged in ye harvest, being beaten small, having bound it in a linen cloth, cast in 15 dragms into one Congius of Must, for 30 days. It doth purge ye belly, expelling choler and phlegme.

The best of ye Cadmia is ye Cyprian which is called Botryites, thick, heavy indifferently, but rather inclining to lightness, having an outside like Clusters, in colour like ashes, but being broken, ashie and rusty within. But ye next is of an azure colour without, but whiter within, having vains like to an Onyx Stone, for such as these are they which are digged out of old mines. And there is a sort called Placodes, having vains (or strokes) like guirdles, whence also they did call it Zonitis. And there is a sort called Ostracitis, slender, & as for ye most part black, endued with an earthy or testacean out-side, but ye white is naught. But that which is called Botryitis & Onychitis is of good use for eye-medicines and ye rest for plasters, and dry medicines, which are of force to cicatrize. And for these things ye Cyprian is of best use. For that which is brought out of Macedonia and Thracia and Spain is unprofitable. But it hath a binding faculty filling up ye hollowness of sores, & cleansing their foulness. And stops ye passage of ye pores, and drys, and draws to a scab, & represseth excrescencies of ye flesh, & cicatriseth ye malignancies of ulcers. But Cadmia also comes from brass red-hot in a furnace, the soot sticking to the sides, & to ye top of the furnaces. Now [rods] of iron, of a great bigness, called by ye metal-men Acestides are joined together at ye top to ye end that ye bodies that are carried up from the brass, may be held & settled there; which also sticking ye more, grow into a body, & sometime one kind of it, sometimes two, or all are made. It is made also of a burned stone called Purites, digged out of an hill that lies over Solis. And in ye same mount are found (as it were) some vaines of Chalcitis, Misy, Sory, Melanteria, Coeruleus, Chrysocolla, Calcanthus, Diphryges. And some also say that Cadmia is found in metals growing in stones, being deceived by ye stones having great resemblance, as in the case of a stone found at Cumae, showing no strength. They are known by their being lighter than Cadmia, & that being chewed, they are not mild in the taste, but do offend the teeth if ye stone were in ye chewing, but if it were Cadmia it would abide ye eating, it being of an yielding nature. And it is hereby discerned, that Cadmia being beaten small, & tempered with vinegar, and dried in the sun comes together, but that the stone doth not suffer this. Also that ye stone being broken & put into fire, doth leap, & that ye smoke that comes of it is like unto ye fire; but ye Cadmia both remains quiet and yieldeth a smoke of a yellowish & brass-like colour as a girdle with divers colours. And further ye stone, being burnt & cooled again, shall be altered in ye colour and shall be lighter, but the Cadmia alters in no respect, except one shall burn it for many days. It is made also out of ye furnaces for Silver, being whiter and lighter, but lesser, as concerning ye operation. But they burn ye aforesaid Cadmia covering it in coals, until it becomes transparent, & casts out flaming sparks, as plates of Iron do, then it must be quenched in Aminaean wine; but that which is for Psoricall medicines, in Acetum. But some beating small again this which was so burnt, mix it with wine & burn it again in a raw earthen vessel, until it be made to look like a Pumex. And again beating it small & mixing it with wine, they burn it ye third time, till it be resolved perfectly into ashes, having no roughness, & they use such as this instead of Spodium. It is washed by being beaten with water in a mortar, ye water being poured away until no filth be standing upon it; & then being made into balls, it is set up.
85. POMPHOLUX. Pompholyx: a deposit in smelting furnaces

Pompholyx doth differ from Spodium specifically, for it hath not a genericall difference, for ye Spodos is somewhat black & for ye most part heavier, being full of motes and hairs and earth, being as it were ye scraping & shaving of ye floors & hearths in the brass-finers’ shops. But Pompholix is fatt & white, & withall most light, so that it can fly into the air. Of this there are two kinds, one of ye colour of ye air, & somewhat fat, but the other very white, and having ye heighth of lightness. But ye white becomes Pompholix when in ye working and finishing of ye brass, ye brass-finers do sprinkle on ye bruised Cadmia the thicker, willing to have it ye better; for ye smoke that is carried up from this, being most white, is turn’d into Pompholyx. But Pompholyx is not made only from ye working and matter of brass, but also from Cadmia purposely blown with ye bellows for ye making of it. And it is made thus. In an house having a double roof a chimney is built, and by it towards ye loft, a suitable window, and open at ye parts above. But ye wall of ye house next to ye chimney, is beaten through with a small hole, into the very furnace for ye receiving of the bellows. It hath also a proportionable door made for ye going in, & coming out of the workman. There is joined unto this room another room, wherein ye bellows & ye bellows-blower work. Then the coals are put into ye furnace and are kindled, afterward ye workman standing by doth sprinkle on from the places over the head of ye furnace the Cadmia being beaten small. And ye servant that is under withall doth do ye same, & casteth on more coals, until all ye Cadmia that was laid on be consumed, so that by the burning, the thin & light part is carried into the upper room, & sticks to the walls & to ye roof thereof. But the body that is made of those things carried up, at ye beginning indeed is like to ye bubbles standing upon ye waters, but at last more increase coming, it is like to fleeces of wool. But that which is heavier goeth into ye places under foot & is dispersed about, some to ye furnace, & some to ye floor of ye house. This is thought to be worse than that of thin parts, because it is earthy & full of filth by ye gathering of it. And some think that ye aforesaid Spodos is made only thus. But it is thought that ye Cyprian is ye best which being wrought into a mass with Acetum, hath the smell of brass, but ye colour in a manner, pitchy, & further, being like dirt in ye taste. And being without deceit, if it be put on a burning coal it boils becoming of an aery colour. But we must look carefully to the signs afore spoken of, for it is counterfeited with bulls-glue, or with lambs lungs, or with those of ye sea, or with green figs burnt, & some other like things. But it is easy to be known, for none of ye aforesaid tokens in the trial are found upon these. But Pompholyx is commonly washed after this manner. Having bound it in a clean linen cloth of a moderate thinness, either dry or made into a mass with water, put it into a basin having rasin-water, & plunge it therein, carrying ye knott this way, and that way, so that the slimy matter & that which is good, will be run out, but all ye refuse stuff will remain in ye cloth. Then suffering it to be settled, strain out ye water with ye ashes, & again having poured on other water, roll it about & then pour it out & do these things, both straining it, and pouring it out until that no sandy matter do subside. Finally strain out the water, but having dried ye ashes, set it up. But some drying it as much as may be, squeeze it in their hands with water, & making it of an honey-like consistence, they strain it through a linen cloth spreading it over ye vessel that shall receive it; & eke binding it not too stiff, but that it may easily pass through, pouring in water in abundance on ye linen cloth, they trouble ye ashes, then taking up with a spoon from hence ye strained & ye frothy stuff of it swimming on ye top, they set it up in a new earthen vessel. But straining gently that which is settled, they pour it into another vessel, the sandy matter being left at the bottom. And again suffering ye stony substance to subside, they strain it into another clean vessel, & this they do often, until ye ashes become clean, and without sand. But others do wet it as it is whole in ye water by little, & little, thinking that ye aforesaid sand & ye stony matter would fall by its own weight to the bottom of ye vessel, but that ye hair & ye moates and such like would be lifted on high by their lightness; then severing ye ashes of them being in the middle, & casting them into a mortar, they wash them as Cadmia. It is washed also with Chian wine diluted with sea-water, according to ye aforesaid fashions, & it becomes more binding than that which is washed with water. But Pompholyx hath a binding, cooling, filling, purging & something of a drying faculty. But if need be that Spodium should be roasted, having carefully beaten it small & sprinkled it with water, make Trochiscks thereof, & put them in a new earthen vessell. But set this on a small & gentle coal fire, & turn ye little balls continually, until that they become red, and dry. It is to be known also that Spodium is made out of gold, and of silver, & moreover also of lead, and that of lead is ye best after that of Copper.
86. ANTISPODA. Ashes used instead of Spodium

Since that spodium is many times wanting and ye Antispodia are of very good use, it is needful to show both what they are, which are of equal force, & after what manner they should be taken. Taking therefore ye leaves of ye Myrtle with ye flowers, & ye Myrtle berries, being as yet unripe, cast them into a raw earthen vessel, & having luted about ye Cover pierced through with continual holes, put it into a potter’s furnace. When ye vessel is well baked, put it again into another raw vessel, & again this second vessell being throughly baked, taking it out, wash it, & use it. And ordering it in like sort take ye branch of ye Olive, but let it be of ye wild; but if not, of ye sative Olive with ye flowers, & if not this, Quinces cut in pieces, & ye bones taken out or galls, or linen rags, or unripe white mulberries dryed before in ye sun, or Lentisck, or Terebinth, or Oenanthe, or ye tender leaves of bramble, or ye hairs of Box, or that which is called false-Cypress together with ye flower. But some do prepare ye branches of ye fig tree, first dried in the sun, but others Bulls glue, some in like sort prepare wool unwashed, rough, moistening it with pitch, or honey. But ye use of all ye afore-spoken of is that they may serve instead of Spodium.

But that burnt brass is good which is red & in ye the bruising looking like Cinnabris, but ye black is burnt more than necessary. It is made of the nails of broken ships, being laid together in a raw earthen pot, brimstone being strewed under with ye like quantity of salt, & one being laid on ye other by turn. But the pot being stopped, and smeared with potter’s clay, is put into ye furnace until it be baked thoroughly. But some instead of brimstone and salt, do strew about Allom. And some without either brimstone, or salt, putting ye nails together into ye pot, do burn them for many days; and some do use brimstone alone, but (such nails as those) must have ye soot wiped from them. But others anointing ye nails with Alumen scissile, together with brimstone & acetum, burne it in a raw earthen pot. And some sprinkling them with Acetum, in a brass pot, so burn them; & after that they are burnt, they do the same thrice, & then they set it up. But that which is burnt in Memphis is ye best, then that in Cyprus. It is of force to bind, to dry, to extenuate, to repress, to attract, to cleanse, to cicatrize ulcers, to wear off things growing in ye eyes, to consume proud flesh, to stop ye Nomas. And also to move vomitings being drank with Hydromel, or licked in with honey, or smeared on. It is washed as the Cadmia, ye water being changed 4 times a day, till no froth stand upon it. And the dross of it, being washed in like sort hath ye same vertue, but somewhat weaker.

But ye flower of brass, which some of ye antients have called Psegma, ye best is that which is very brittle & very red in ye being small brayed, & like Milium in proportion, and small, and heavy, & indifferently glittering, & beside unpartaking of ye dust of brass wherewith it is counterfeited. But it is discovered by the powder spreading open when crushed by the teeth. It is made thus. When the brass being melted in metallicall furnaces runs through the colanders of ye appertaining pipes into ye Receivers, those who are over these (works) taking away the Scume, do pour in the purest water onto it, intending to cool it. By this therefore so sudden a thickening and concretion, the aforesaid flower of brass is as it were spit out, & flowers. And this also binds and represseth excrescencies, & wears off such things as darken ye sight of ye eyes, being mightily biting. And it is extractive also of gross humors ye quantity of 4 Oboli being given. It consumes also the excrescencies of flesh in ye nostrils, & with wine represseth pustles, of ye seats: & ye white is blown in through a pipe for long hardness of hearing. Being beaten small, & applied with honey, it represseth ye Tonsillas, & ye Uvula.

But Squama, called Helitis which is of ye Cyprian brass-wrought nails, is thick and good: but that of the white brass, being thin & weak, is wrought, which we refuse, preferring that which is thick and glistering & growing rusty when vinegar is sprinkled upon it. It hath a contracting, extenuating, Noma-repressing putrifying, cicatrizing faculty. But being drank with Melicrat it expells water. But some working it into a mass with meal give it in a Catapotium. It is mixed also with medicines for ye eyes, for it dries the eye-lids that be rough, doing away also the rheums. And it is washed thus: having made cleane half a pound of ye dry squama, cast it into a mortar with clear water, & stirring them up & down carefully with ye hand, till that the scum be sunk down, cast away the remainder. And having poured out ye water, pour in one cyathus of rain water, & with ye palm of ye hand rub it hard in the mortar, as if you were straining it, & when it shall begin to send out any viscousness, by little & little pour on water even to 6 Cyathi, beating it strongly; & taking ye Squama with ye hand against the side of the mortar, press it hard, & having pressed it take up that which is run out into a box of red brass, for this is as it were ye flower of ye Squama, and strong in force, & very effectual for eye-medicines, but the rest is of no strength. And yet washing in like sort that which is left, take it up till it show no glueyness. And then, having covered the rest with a linen cloth, you must let it stand still for 2 days; then pouring out ye water that stands on top, & drying (ye rest) put it in a box. And some washing it as Cadmia, set it up.
But ye faculty of ye squama of stomoma, is ye same with ye squama of brass, & ye washing, & ye laying of it up, are alike; but yet in purging ye belly, it comes short of that of brass.

But Aerugo rasilis is thus prepared. Pouring it into an hogshead, or some such like vessel, ye sharpest vinegar, turn upon it a brazen vessel: it is good if ye hollow look downward, if not, let it be plane. But let it be made clean & having no breathing place. Then after 10 days take off ye cover & scrape off ye Aerugo that is come on it; or having made a plate of ye brass itself, hang it in the vessel, so as not to touch ye vinegar, and after ye like number of days, scrape it off; or hiding one mass or plate or else more amongst the huskes of grapes, not pressed of late, but growing sour, invert it in like sort. It may also be made of ye filings of brass, or of ye plates, between which leaves of gold are held when beaten out, if one sprinkling them with Vinegar, turn them 3 or 4 times until that they be rusty all over. But they say that this rust is begotten in ye Cyprian mines in two ways, flourishing upon some stones having brass, and secondly dropping out of a certain den in ye scorching weather under ye Dog, & that the former is but little and very good, but that out of the den, though it flows out in abundance & bears a good colour, is naught, because it is mixed with stony matter. It is counterfeited also, by being mixed with many other things but especially with these. For some do mix it with ye Pumice stone, some with marble, but others with Calcanthum. But we shall find out the Pumice stone, & ye marble, by wetting the thumb of ye left hand, and rubbing some part of ye rust with ye other. For it happens that ye rust of it runs abroad, but ye parts of ye Pummice stone & ye marble remain undissolved, & at last it grows white with ye long rubbing and with ye mixture of ye moisture. And not so only, but by the crushing of ye teeth, for the unmixed falls down smooth, & not rough. But ye Calcanthum is discovered by the fire. For if any sprinkle ye rust thus counterfeited upon a plate, or earthen vessel, & shall put either of these in warm ashes or upon coals, that made of Calcanthum is changed & grows red, because it hath such a colour by nature when it is burnt.

But of ye rust called Scolecia there is a double kind, for ye one is a mineral, & the other is made thus: having poured half an Hemina of white & sharp vinegar into a mortar of Cyprian brass, having also a pestle made of ye same matter, beat it until it be viscous, then cast in one dragm of round Allom, & of transparent mineral salt, or of sea salt as white as may be, and strong, and if not, ye like quantity of Nitre; then beat them in ye Sun in ye extreme heat under ye Dog, till it become rusty in ye colour, but gluish in consistence, and so having made it into little wormes like to Rhodiaca, set it up. It is made effectual & well-coloured if there be taken one part of vinegar, & two parts of old urine, & ye rest as is aforesaid. But some mixing that which is brought to no good pass in ye Aerugo rasilis, frame it into a form with gum, & sell it, which is to be refused as naught; & there is also a rust made of ye gold-smiths with a mortar & pestle of Cyprian brass, & with a child’s urine, wherewith they solder gold. But ye aforesaid rusts commonly are suitable to burnt brass, but they are more strong as concerning ye operation. But it is to be known that ye fossilis Scolecia of them is ye chief, next to that is ye Rasilis, & then that which is made, but yet this is more biting and more binding, but that of ye Gold-smiths is answerable to ye Rasilis. But all rust is of force to binde, to warm, to wear off, and extenuate ye Cicatrices in ye eyes, to draw tears, to stay ye Nomas, to keep wounds from inflammations, to cicatrize ulcers with oil, and wax; & being sodden with honey they purge ye Callos, & ye foulness of ulcers; and being taken with Amoniacall in manner of Collyries, they do away Fistulas & their Callos. And they are good also for ye excrescencies & extuberancies of ye gums, & being anointed on with honey they do lessen greatly also ye eye-lids. But you must after ye anointing foment with a spung out of warm water. But being taken with Terebinthinall Rosin, with brass or Nitre they take away leprosies. But you must burn what rust you would, thus. Having broken it into very small pieces, put it in an earthen platter, & setting it over burning coals, stirr it about till it change, and look of somewhat an ashy colour, then having cooled it, set it up & use it. But some burn it in a raw earthen vessel, as is aforesaid, but being burnt it doth not change altogether into ye same colour.

But ye rust of iron doth bind, being put to doth stay ye womanish flux, & being drank it causeth inconception, but being anointed on with vinegar it heals Exanthemata & is of fit use for ye Paronychiae, & ye Pterygia, and scabrous eye-lids, & ye Condylomata, & it doth strengthen ye gums; & being anointed on doth help ye podagricall, & doth thicken ye Alopecia. But iron made burning hot, quenched in water, or wine, & drank, is good for ye Coeliacall dysentericall, splenicall, cholericall & for a dissolved stomach.
But ye Scoria of ye iron, is of force for as many things as the rust of ye Iron, but in a lower degree. But it helps Aconitum when drank with Oxymel.

And washen lead is prepared after this manner. Casting water into a leaden mortar, beat it with a leaden pestle until that ye water grow black & become muddy: then strain it through a linen cloth, pouring on more water, that all that which is dissolved may be strained; & do ye same again until it seem unto thee to have enough: then letting that which is washed settle, pour out that water and pour in other, as in the case of Cadmia wash until that any blackness no longer stand upon it. Having made trochiscks thereof, set it up. But some sprinkling water upon clean lead, beat it in a stony mortar with a stony pestle, or with ye hands pouring on water by little, & little under hand, when that which is grown black has been suffered to settle, they pour it out & form into trochiscks forthwith. For that which is rubbed longer, becomes like to Cerussa. But some cast in to the dust of ye lead a little Plumbago, saying that lead so washed is ye better. It is of force to cool, to bind, to stop ye pores, to fill up hollownesses, to stay the rhumes that fall into ye eyes, & ye flashy excrescencies of ulcers. And it is also a blood-stancher, & good for ye ulcers in the seat, for ye Condylomata and Haemorrhoids with Rosaceum; also for sores hard to be cicatrized, & in general it doth whatsoever Spodium doth, without raising a scab. But unmixed lead being rubbed on doth help ye stroke of ye sea Scorpion, & of ye Dragon.

But Lead is burnt thus. Taking plates of lead, as thin as may be, put them into a new pot, & having sprinkled brimstone upon, lay on other plates & sprinkle on brimstone & again other & do this until that you shall have filled ye pot: then put fire under. Then the lead being kindled, stir it with an iron rod till that it be perfectly turned to ashes, & have nothing leadlike in it; then take it out, having stopped ye nostrils, for ye vapour is hurtfull, and casting ye dust of lead with brimstone into a pot, so burn it. But some casting ye plates (as hath been said) into a raw earthen vessel, put it into a furnace, or over coals, luting the cover & giving it a little breathing place, burn it. Some again strew about Cerussa instead of brimstone, or barley. And some putting in the plates without any mixture, doe use a sharp fire, and stir it about lustily with an iron rod, until that it turn to ashes; but such burning as this is difficult, and being burned too much, so it takes ye colour of Lithargyrum. But the first burning pleaseth me. But we must was it as the Cadmia, and so set it up. It hath ye faculty that ye washed lead hath, but far stronger.

The best Scoria of Lead is that which looks like Cerussa, thick, & hard to break, having nothing of lead in it, but yellowish in colour, & glistering like glass. It is good for ye same things that burnt lead is, binding more. But it is washed in a mortar, water being poured on, & that which stands on top of a yellowish colour being poured out. And this is done often till that ye Scoria be consumed. And then, after suffering it to be settled, we pour out ye water, & so make it in trochiscks.
And the Leaden Stone hath ye like virtue to ye Scoria, & is washed after ye same manner.

But that is ye best Stibium which is ye brightest and is shining, crusty in the breaking, having no earthiness or foulness, and quickly broken: this some have called Stibi, some Platyophthalmon, some Larbason, [some Gynoecion, some Chalcedonium]. It hath a faculty of stopping ye pores, of binding, of cooling, of repressing flesh-excrescencies, of cicatrizing ulcers, & of cleansing ye filth & ulcers which are in ye eyes. It stops also ye fluxes of blood that come from ye Meninx. And generally the virtue of it is like to burnt lead. And in particular it doth not let burnings to grow to a scab, being anointed with new grease, and it doth cicatrize sores grown to scabs, some wax & a little Cerussa being mixed with it. But it is roasted being wrapt about with dough, and hid in coals till that the dough be turned to a coal, & being taken out, it is quenched with ye milk of an woman that bears a male child, or with old wine, & it is burnt being laid on coals, & blown till ye fiering, for if it be burnt more it melts like lead. But it is washed as ye Cadmia, & ye brass, but some washed it like to ye Scoria of Lead.

Plumbago, that is ye best which looks like Spuma Argenti, yellow, somewhat glittering & of a tawny yellow in being beaten small, & which being sodden with oil becomes liver-like in ye colour. But that of an aery, or leaden colour, is naught. It is made of Silver, and gold, & there is some found dug out of ye earth about Sebastia & Corycum, & of this that is the best that is neither like Scoria, neither is stony, but yellow and glittering. It hath a virtue like to Lithargyrum, and to ye Scoria of Lead, & it hath ye same manner of washing & burning. But this is mixed most fitly with gentle plasters called Lipara, & profitably with plasters that are not corrosive, being incarnative and cicatrizing, but it is not fitting for such as have conglutinating & cleansing faculties.
But ye Scoria of Silver is called Helcysma or Encauma. It hath the same faculty with Plumbago, whence it is mixed with blackish, & cicatrizing plasters, being extracting & binding.

Spuma Argenti, some of this is made of the sand called Molibditis, being blowed in ye furnance till perfect fiering: other is made of Silver, & some of Lead. But ye Atticall is the best, ye next to this is ye Spanish, after these that in Dicaearchia in Campania, & in Sicilia, for much is made in these & those places, ye Leaden plates being enflamed. For the yellow and glittering is called Chrysitis, which is the best, but that in Sicilia Argyritis, & that of silver Calabritis. But it hath a faculty of binding, of mollifying, of filling up hollownesses, of repressing excrescencies of flesh, and of cicatrizing, of cooling, of stopping ye pores. But you shall burn it thus. Having divided it into ye bigness of walnuts, & set them upon burning coals & having blowed them till thorough fiering, & having wiped away the filth that hangs about it, set it up. But some quenching it with vinegar, or wine thrice, burn it again, & having done these things, set it up. It is washed as ye Cadmia. But it is whited thus. Taking as much as a Choenix of Athens of that which is called Argyritis, & if not, then that of ye other, broken into ye bigness of beans, & casting it into a new earthen vessel, pour on water, casting in moreover a Choenix of white wheat, & by itself with an handful of barley bound in a thin, clean linen cloth, and hung from the ear of ye earthen vessel & seeth it until the barley be broken. Then having poured out all into a broad-mouthed new platter, having severed ye wheat, cast it away, & pouring on water wash the Lithargyrum, rubbing it strongly likewise with thy hands; then having taken it out, & dried it, beat it in a Thebaicall mortar, pouring on warm water until it be dissolved; & having strained out ye water, beaten it again for a whole day, & at ye evening pouring on hot water, let it alone; in ye morning, having strained out that, pour in more & thus strain it out 3 times a day. Doe this for seven days: then having mixed to a pound of Lithargyrum 5 dragms of Sal Fossile, and pouring on warm water, beat it 3 times a day, straining out ye old, & mixing new water. But whether it is become white, pouring on warm water, do ye same until it have a shew of no saltness; & having dried it in a most sharp sun, casting away first the moisture, set it up: & if not take one pound of Argyritis, beat it small carefully, & having beaten it, mix of mineral salt beaten small 3 times as much, and cast it into a new earthen vessel, & casting on water so that it may stand above, stirr it every day, morning & evening pouring in thereto more water, pouring out none of the former; and do this for 30 days, for being not stirred, it grows hard as a shell. But after these things, having poured out ye brine gently beat small ye Lithargyrum in a Thebaicall mortar & casting it into an earthen vessel & pouring on water stirr it diligently with thine hands, pouring out ye first, and pouring on ye other, until it have no appearance of saltness. Then having poured out ye white of ye Lithargyrum into another vessel, make Trochiscks thereof, & set them up in a leaden box. But some, breaking the Lythargyrum into ye bigness of beans & putting it into ye raw belly of a swine, seeth it in water until that the bowel be dissolved; then taking it out & beating it with as much salt, they washed it as is aforesaid. And some do pound in ye sun one pound of salt, & as much of Lithargyrum, with water, continually pouring it out, till it become white. Or thus also: Taking as much as you will, of Lithargyrum & having wrapt it in white wool, & putting it in a new earthen vessel, & putting water thereunto, & one handfull of clean & new beans, seeth them. But when the beans be broken, & ye wool grown black, take out ye Lithargyrum, & wrapping it in other wool and seeth it ye second time, purring thereto a Cyathus of water and the like quantity of beans, & doe ye same things like to ye aforesaid ye third time, & in brief until ye wool take no more tincture. And after this changing it into a mortar, to 80 Attick dragms of Lithargyrum, mix one pound of mineral salt, & beat it small. Then staying awhile, add, of ye very whitest Nitre washed with water 47 dragms, & beate it again until that ye Lithargyrum be sufficiently white. And so having poured it from on high into a broad-mouthed earthen vessel, and poured thereto good store of water, & letting it settle, strain it. And interchangeably doe after ye aforesaid directions until ye water that runs over become very clear & sweet, & unpartaking of saltness. And after all having changed it into a new earthen platter, all the moisture being gently strained out, set it in the sun 40 days under ye Dog, & having dried it, use it. But that which is washed doth appear to be good to be put in eye-medicines, & for foul scars & for faces wrinkled, and full of spots.

But Cerussa is made thus. Having poured in ye most sharp vinegar into a broad-mouthed vessel, or into an earthen Urn, make fast a leaden plate upon the mouth of ye earthen vessell, a little reeden mat being laid under before; & on ye top of it cast coverings to ye end that ye vinegar may not evaporate till it be dissolved & fall down distilling, and strain out ye pure liquor which is elevated, but ye viscous stuff is to be poured into a vessel, & to be dried in the sun. Then it must be ground in an hand-mill, or small beaten otherwise, and sarced, & after this ye rest of that which is hard to be made small, and sarced; & ye same things are to be done both three & 4 times by turns. But that which is sarced first is the best, which also is to be taken for eye-medicines, & that is next best which follows next, & so ye rest in order. But some put on a bullrushy matt, fastening it toward ye middle of ye vessel, so that it may (as it were) touch ye vinegar. Having stopped ye mouth of it and luted it about, they let it alone. And after some days taking off the cover they look in & when it is dissolved they do ye other things like the aforesaid. But if any will form it into Trochiscks, it must be kneaded with sharp vinegar & so formed & dried in ye sun. But these things aforespoken must be done in ye summer, for so it becomes white and effectual. It is made also in ye winter, ye earthen pots being set over furnaces or baths, or chimnies. For ye warmth being carried from above doth ye same that the sun doth. But that is reckoned ye best which is made in Rhodes, or in Corinth, or in Lacedaemonia. And ye next is that which comes from Puteoli. It is to be roasted after this manner: putting a new Ostracean vessell (& especially an Atticall) over light burning coals, sprinkle on Cerussa being beaten small, & stirr it continually, & when it is ash-like in ye colour, take it out, cool it, & use it. But if you would burn it, put it beaten small into an hollow platter &, setting it over live coals stirr it with a stick of Ferula, until it be like in colour to Sandaracha, & taking it out use it. And that which thus is made, by some is called Sandyx. But the Cerussa is washed in like sort to ye Cadmia. It hath a cooling, pore-stopping, mollifying, filling, attenuating, & moreover a gently repressing of excrescencies, & a cicatrizing faculty, being mixed with Cerats, & plasters called Lipara, & with Trochiscks, & it is of those, which taken inwardly kill.

Chrysocolla, that of Armenia is the best, very much resembling leeks in ye colour, but that of Macedonia is ye second, then the Cyprian, & of this the pure is to be chosen, but that which is full of earth, & stones is to be refused. The aforesaid is to be washed, thus: having beaten it, cast it into a mortar, & having poured on water rub it strongly with ye palm of thine hand against ye mortar, then having suffered it to settle, strain it; & pouring on other water, rub it again & do this by turns, till it be pure & sincere; after this having dried it in ye sun set it up, & use it. But if you would burn it, burn it after this manner: having beaten of it as much as will suffice, put it in a platter, & set it over light coals & do ye other things, as has been said about burnings. But Chrysocolla hath a faculty of wearing off scars, of repressing flesh-excrescencies, & of cleansing, & of binding & of warming & is gently corrosive with some little biting. And it is of ye number of those medicines that cause vomiting & are strong enough to kill.

That Armenium is to be chosen which is smooth & of an azure colour, & very even, & without stones, and very brittle. It doth ye same things that Chrysocoll doth, only it fails as concerning ye strength of it. It is also an increaser of ye hairs on ye eye-lids.

Cyanus grows in Cyprus of brasen mineralls. But ye most is made of the shorie sand, found by some hollow places of ye sea like dens, which also is the best. But that is to be chosen which is of a full colour. But it is to be burnt as Chalcitis & to be washed as Cadmia. It hath a faculty of repressing, & of a little corroding, & of scabbifying & of exulcerating.

But of that which is called Indicum, some comes of its own accord being, as it were, ye froth of the Indian reeds, but ye other comes of dyeing, being ye flower of purple elevated on the Dye-vatts which ye workmen taking off do dry. But that is reckoned to be ye best which is both azurie, & juicy, & smooth. But it is of those that bind gently, and break inflammations, & Oedemata, and doth purge and repress ulcers.

That Oaker is to be chosen which is lightest, & wholly yellowish, of a full colour, & unstony, & brittle, & of that of Athens by kind: but we must burn and wash this as the Cadmia. It hath a binding faculty of putrifying, of dissolving inflammations & little swellings, & it doth repress excrescencies of flesh & fills up sores that be hollow, with Cerat, & diminisheth callosities.

Some do think Cinnabaris to be ye same with that which is called Ammium, being deceived herein. For ye Ammium is made in Spain of a certain stone mixed with ye Arguritidicall sand, for otherwise it is not known. In ye furnace it changeth into a very lively and flaming colour, but it hath amongst metals a choaking smell, and therefore ye workmen there put bladders about their faces, that they may see, but not draw in the vapour. But the Painters use this for the Sumptuous adornings of walls. But ye Cinnabaris which we speak of, is brought from Africa, and is sold for much, & is so scarce that there is hardly enough for ye painters for the variety in the lines. It is also of an heavy, or deep colour, whence some thought it to be ye blood of ye dragon. But Cinnabaris hath the same virtue that Haematitis hath, being good for eye-medicines & that more effectually, for it is more binding & blood-stanching, & being taken with Cerat it heals burnings and ye breaking out of pustles.

But Hydrargyrum is made of that which is called Ammion, this also being abusively called Cinnabaris. Putting an iron Spoon having Cinnabaris in an earthen pot, they cover the Cup dawbing it about with clay, then they make a fire under with coals: and ye soot that sticks to ye pot, being scraped off & cooled, becomes Hydrargyrum. It is found also in ye place where Silver is melted standing together by drops on ye roofs. And some say that Hydrargyrum is found by itself in ye mines. But it is kept in glassen, or leaden, or tinnen, or silver vessels, for it eats through all other matter, & makes it run out. It hath a pernitious faculty being drank, eating through ye inward parts by its weight. But this is helped by much milk being drank, or wine with wormwood, or ye decoction of smallach, or ye seed of Horminum, or Origanum, or Hyssop with wine. [But ye dust of gold, that is, ye smallest scraping, is a miraculous help for this Hydrargyrum.]
111. MILTOS SINOPIKE. Red earth of Sinope

Rubrica Sinopica. Ye best is that which is thick and heavy, of a live colour, without stones, but of one colour, much spreading abroad in ye dissolving. It is gathered in Cappadocia in certain dens, but it is purified, and carried to ye city Sinope and sold, whence also it had the sirname. It hath a drying, emplasticall faculty, for which cause also it is mixed with vulnerarie plasters, and with drying and binding trochiscks. It stops also ye belly being taken in an egg, or by way of glister. It is given also to ye liver-sick.

But ye Tectonicall is inferior in every respect to ye Sinopicall. But ye best is ye Egyptian, and ye Carthaginian, without stones, brittle. It grows also in Spain towards ye West, the Ochre being burnt, & turning into Rubrica.

But that which is ye Lemnian earth is brought from the Island Lemnos, out of a certain hollow cavern having a marshy place. Thence it is gathered and is mixed with goats blood, and the men there make it into trochiscks, & sealing it with ye figure of a goat, call it ye seal of a goat. But it hath an eminent faculty of an Antidot against deadly poisons when drank with wine, & being taken before, it constrains to vomit up poisons. It is good also against ye strokes & it is good for ye bitings of venemous poison-outcasting beasts. It is mixed also with Antidotes. And some also use it for expiations. And it is good also for dysenteries.

Calcanthum, and this also is one in ye Genus, for it is moisture-concreated, but it hath 3 specificall differences. For this ye moisture being strained by dropping into certian concavities, is concreted, whence also it is called Stillatitium by such as work ye Cyprian metals. But Peteesius calls it Pinarium, and some Stalacticon, [concreted, sodden, thin, long like a spear]: & some running secretly in dens, & afterward being transfused into ditches taketh thickening, & this properly is called Pecton: but ye third sort is called Coctile & is made in Spain; & it hath this manner of making, being unuseful and the weakest: diluting it, they seeth in water, then pouring it out into ye receivers, they let it stand: this in some days is thickened, being divided into many forms, like Dice hanging to one another like grape-bunches. But ye best of it is reckoned to be ye azure-coloured, & heavy, & compact, & transparent, such as is the Stillatitium which by others is called Lanceatum, and ye next best is the Concretitium. But ye Coctile is thought to be ye fittest of any other for dyeing & making black colours, but experience showeth that it is ye weakest for medicinal use. The virtue of it is to bind, to warm, to incrustate, to kill ye broad worms, being swallowed ye weight of 2 dragms, or lickt in with honey; & it moves vomitings, & helpeth such as have taken mushrooms being drank with water, & it purgeth ye head, being diluted with water, & through wool dropped into ye nostrils. But it is burnt as we will show forthwith in Calcitis.

That Calcitis is to be preferred, which looks like brass & is brittle being without stones, & not old, & moreover having somewhat long and glittering vains. But it hath both a binding & a warming & an incrustating faculty, purging away of ye filth about ye eye-corners, and ye eyes; and it is of those things that do indifferently bind. And it is good also for ye Erysipelata, & the Herpetas, & fluxes of blood which come from ye womb, & from ye nostrils, with ye juice of a Leek. The powder of it is good for repressing ye gums’ excrescencies, & ye Nomas, & ye Tonsillas; but being burnt it is far more useful for eye-medicines being beaten small & mixed with honey, & it abates & cleanseth hard-grown and rough eye-lids, & it takes away fistulas, being put in like a Collyrium.

That which is called Psoricum is made of this Calcitis, two parts of Calcitis being mixed with one of Cadmia, & beaten small with vinegar. And it must be close shut up in an earthen vessel in dung for 40 days, in those under ye Dog, so it becomes sharper, being good for whatever Calcitis is. And some mixing them in equal proportions beat them in wine, & do ye same as before. But they burn it putting it in a new earthen vessel, and setting it over burning coals. But let this be ye measure of ye burning in those (metals) which are full of moisture, to become without bubbles, & to be perfectly dried, & in the rest, to change into a more flourishing colour. For when it is like blood or Rubrica deep within, then it is to be taken off, & you are to blow off the filth that lieth on it, & so to set it up. But it is roasted on coals that are blown, until it become of a pale yellow, or in an earthen pot over burning coals, being turned oft, till it be on fire and change colour.

Misy, but ye Cyprian is to be chosen, looking like gold, hard & in the breaking of a golden colour, and glistering like a starr. It hath ye same faculty & burning that Chalcitis hath, without ye making of Psoricum from it, differing both in ye excesse & ye defect. But that of Egypt in respect of others, is ye best, being ye most effectual; but for the eye-medicines it fails by much of ye aforesaid.

But of Melanteria some grows together in ye fashion of salt at ye mouthes of Mines out of which brass is digged; & some out of ye upper Superficies of ye aforesaid places which also is earthy: there is found some also that is digged out in Cilicia, & in certain other places. But that is ye best of it which is of brimstone colour, smooth, even, clear, & in touching ye water quickly growing black; but it hath a caustical quality ye same that Misy hath.

But some being deceived have supposed Sory to be Melanteria, for it is a proper kind, though not unlike; Sory is more poisonous, and a causer of nauseousness. It is found in Egypt and in other places as in Africa, and Spain, and Cyprus, but ye Egyptian is deemed ye best, & that which looks blackest in being broken, and hath many holes & is somewhat fat, and also binding, and to the swallowing or ye smelling poisonous, and overturning of ye stomach; but that which doth not glister in ye being broken, like as Misy, is to be thought to be both of another kind, and weak. But it hath the same virtue & burning to ye aforespoken of. It heals also tooth-aches being put into their concavities, & it strengthens the loose teeth, and it helps ye Sciaticall, being given for a glister with wine, & extinguisheth ye Varos, being smeared on with water; & it is mixed (with other medicines) for ye dying black of ye hair.

But in a common manner, as for these & almost all others, those which are not burnt are counted of more force than the burnt, except it be of salt, & wine-lees, and Nitre, and chalke, & of ye like, which being raw are weak, for being burnt they come to be of a more operative virtue.

But of Diphryges there are thought to be 3 kinds, for one is a mineral, & this grows only in Cyprus, for being dirty it is taken up out of a bottom of ye places there. Then being taken up, it is dried in the sun, & after this, small brushy sticks being laid round about it, it is burnt; from whence also it was called Diphryges, because it is burnt and dryed and, as it were, roasted by the Sun and the sticks. Ye other is as it were ye sediment and dross of wrought brass, for after the pouring about of ye cold water, as we said when discoursing of the flower of brass, after ye taking away of ye brass there is found such a kind as this in ye furnace sticking to ye bottom of it, having both ye binding quality, & ye taste of brass.

But ye 3rd is made thus. They which are over these works putting ye stone called Pyrites into a furnace, they burn it as chalk for many days. But when the colour becomes Rubrica-like they take it out and set it up. But some say that ye aforesaid is made of ye only matter that doth perfect brass stone, when being roasted in ye said ranges it is carried thence into the ditches, & is there burnt, for it takes up ye place round about ye dithces, & it is found nevertheless after ye taking away of ye stones That is ye best of it which is brassy to ye taste, looking rusty, & binding and drying mightily ye tongue, which quality ye burnt Ochre doth not possess, though some burning it, do sell it instead of Diphryges. But it hath ye faculty both of binding, & of cleansing thoroughly, & of wiping away, and of drying, and of repressing ye excrescencies of ye flesh & of cicatrizing of malignant & creeping sores. And it dissolveth Abscesses, being taken with Turpentine or Cerat.

Arsenicum grows in ye same mines that Sandaracha doth. That is reckoned ye best, which is crusty & gold-like in ye colour, and having fish-scale-like crusts, as it were, always lying one upon another & it is not mixed with any other matter. And such is that which grows in Mysia, which is in Hellespont. And there is of it two kinds: one, such as is aforesaid, but the other cloddy & like Sandaracha in ye colour brought from Pontus & Cappadocia, and such as this is ye second. And it is roasted thus: putting it in a new ostracean vessel, set it over burning coals, & stirr it continually, & when it is red hot, & is changed in colour, then cooling it, & beating it small set it up. It hath both a Septicall, and binding & incrustating with a burning, and strong biting faculty, & it is of those medicines that repress excrescencies & it makes ye hair fall.

But that Sandaracha is best esteemed that is fully red, brittle, easy to be beaten small, and pure, looking like Cinnabaris in the colour, & also having a brimstone-like smell. But it has the same virtue & manner of roasting, that Arsenicum hath: it healeth also ye Alopeciae being taken with Rosin, & with pitch it sends leprous nails going, & it is good for ye lowsy disease with oil, & with grease it dissolveth small swellings. And it is good also for the ulcers in ye nostrils & ye mouth, and for the other pustles with Rosaceum, and for ye Condylomata. It is given also with Mulsum to Spitters of rotten matter, & it is made a perfume with Rosin also for ye old cough, the smoke being drawn through a tunnel into ye mouth; & being licked in with honey it doth clear ye voice, and it is given with Rosin for a Catapotion to ye Asthmaticall.

Almost every kind of Allom is found in the same mines in Egypt, for there is ye Scissilis as it were ye flower of Bolitis, & also it grows in certain other places, in Melos, in Macedonia, in Sardinia, in Liparis, and Hierapolis of Phrygia, in Africa, in Armenia, and in many other places, like as Rubrica. But there are many kinds of it: but for medicinal use, both ye Scissilis, and the Round, and ye Moist is taken; but ye Scissilis is the best, & of this that which is new & exceeding white, and without stones, & of a strong smell, & very astringent & moreover not compact together like a turf or a slat, but gaping like unto gray hairs singled apart, such as is that which is called Trichitis growing in Egypt. And also there is found a stone very like to it, being discernable by ye judgement of ye taste not to be binding. The Round Allom which is made by hand, is not to be allowed to be taken; it is known by the figure: but that is to be taken which is naturally round, & is full of bladders, & is somewhat white and strongly binding, & withall having some paleness together with fatness, and withal both without stones & brittle, & by origin of Melia, or Egypt.

Of ye Moist that which is most transparent is to be chosen, & that which is milky, & both even & juicy throughout, & moreover without stones, & breathing out a smell of fire. But they have a faculty of warming, of binding & of purging away those things that darken the sight of ye eyes, & of consuming the flesh upon the eye-lids, & ye other fleshly excrescencies. But they do reckon ye Scissilis to be more effectuall than ye Round. But they are burnt, & roasted, as Chalcitis is. They restrain creeping ulcers, stop bloody fluxes, close moist gums, & with vinegar or honey they strengthen wagging teeth. They are good also for ye Apthae with honey, & for ye pustles, & rhumatick fluxes in ye ears with ye juice of Polygonum. And they are good for leprosies with ye leaves of Brassica, or sodden with honey, & for itches & for rotten nails, & for ye Pterygia & for ye Perniones being fomented on with water. And with ye lees of vinegar, being anointed on with ye like quantity of burnt galls they are good for ye Phagedaenae, and for ye Nomae with twice as much salt; & they wear off ye Furfures being smeared on with Ervum and moist pitch. And it is a remedy for knits, and lice, and burnings being anointed on with water. And they are smeared on for ye Oedemata & for ye rank smells of ye armpits & ye groins. Allom of Melos also co-operates to inconception, being laid before conjunction to ye mouth of ye matrix, and it expels ye Embrya. And they are expedient for ye gums’ excrescencies & for ye uvae, and ye Tonsillae, & for ye mouth; and they are smeared on with honey for ye ears & ye privities.

That is thought ye best Brimstone which has never felt fire, and is glistering in colour, & transparent, & without stones; but of that which hath felt ye fire (that is best) which is green, & very fat: it grows abundantly in Melos and Lipara. But ye aforesaid sulphur both dissolveth & ripeneth quickly, and being taken in an egg or else being suffumigated; it is good for coughs, & such as spit rotten matter, & ye Asthmaticall and moreover being suffumigated it draws out ye Embryo, & it takes off leprosies, & also ye Lichenes, & rotten nails, being mixed with Terebinthinall Rosin; and being smeared on with Vinegar it is good also for leprosies, & it takes away ye Vitiligines. It heals also ye strokes of Scorpions being mixed with Rosin, but with vinegar it heals ye stroke both of ye sea dragon & of Scorpions, & it assuageth ye itchings over all the body being rubbed on with Nitre. And it helps also ye Icterus, ye quantity of a spoonful being sprinkled on ye forehead, or taken with a rear egg and it is good for ye nose and the Catarrh, & being sprinkled on it keeps from sweating, & it is convenient for ye podagricall, being smeared on with nitre and water; & it cures ye hardness of hearing ye smoke being drawn up (in haste) through a tunnel; & being Suffumigated (it awakes) ye Lethargicall, & stops a flux of blood, & being smeared on with wine and honey, it heals ye bruises of ye ears.

That Pumistone is to be chosen which is most light, and very hollow, & cuttable, & unstony, & moreover both brittle and white. But it is to be burnt thus: taking of it as much as you will, hide it in burning coals, & when it is red-hot, taking it out, quench it with odoriferous wine, & burning it again, quench it. But taking it off ye third time, let it cool of itself, & having set it up use it.
