It hath a faculty both of binding, and cleansing ye gums, & of purging away such things as darken ye eye-sight, with warming; and of filling up ulcers, and of cicatrizing them, & further of repressing excrescencies & of cleaning ye teeth being beaten to powder; & of scabifying ye body, & it is a fit medicine for to make ye hair fall. But Theophrastus saith, that if one put a pumistone into a seething vessel of wine, that ye seething of ye wine forthwith ceaseth.

But of Salt ye most operative is the mineral, & of this commonly, that which is unstony, and white, and transparent, and thick, & equally compacted; but properly the Ammoniacall by country, being easily cut & having straight partitions. But of ye Sea Salt, that which is thick is to be taken, & that which is white and even: but ye best is in Cyprus & as Salamine of Cyprus, & at Megara, & in Sicily, & Africa; & also, that of ye Lakes in ye aforesaid places is deemed ye best, but ye strongest is the Phrygian, yet called Tattaean. But the aforesaid salts have a virtue in common of much use both of binding & of cleansing & of dissolving, as also of repressing, & of extenuating & of incrusting, differing in ye more or less (strength). They are also restringent of rotten ulcers, & are mixed with Smegmata Psorica, and they repress ye excrescencies in ye eyes and consume ye Pterygia, and take away the other flesh excrescencies, & they are fit to put in glisters & being smeared on with oil they are dissolvers of lassitude, & (are good) for ye Oedemata of ye Hydropicall, & a fomentation that is made of them in little bags is an easer of pains, & they assuage itchings, being anointed on together by ye fire with oil and vinegar till they sweat. In like sort also they assuage ye Lichenes, & ye Psoras, and leprosies & ye Synanchicall, being anointed on with honey and vinegar, & for the Tonsillae and ye uvae being roasted with honey; & for ye Phagedaenas and ye Aphthas, & ye moisture of ye gums they are laid on being burnt with Polenta, and for ye strokes of Scorpions with flax seed. But for ye bitings of vipers with Origanum and honey and hyssop. But for (ye bitings) of ye Cerastes with pitch, or Cedria or honey; & for ye bitings of ye Scolopendra, with honey & vinegar; & for ye strokes of wasps, & ye teredines, and for ye white pustles in ye head, & for ye thymos & tubercula, they take it with calves suet; but with uva passa or swines grease, or honey they dissolve ye Furunculos, & with Origanum & leaven, they ye sooner ripen ye oedemata of ye genitories; & help ye Crocodile-bitten, being beaten small & bound in a linen cloth dipped in vinegar, ye parts (affected) being bound with bonds. And they help ye venemous-beast-bitten, & ye black & blues of ye face, with honey, and for drinking of ye juice of poppy & for mushrooms, being drank with Oxymel, and for luxations with meal and honey, and being laid on with oil they do not suffer ambustions to blister, & they are applied in like sort to ye podagricall, & for ear-pains with Vinegar. And they stay ye Erysipelata and creeping ulcers being smeared on with vinegar, or laid on as a cataplasme with Hyssop. They burn them by casting them into an ostracean vessel, and carefully stopping them that they may not leap out, hiding them in live coals till their full burning. But some wrapping about the sales fossiles with dough setting it under hot coals let it alone until ye dough be burnt. And you may burn ye common salts after this manner, having washed them once in water, & suffered them to be dry, cast them into an earthen pot, & having stopped it, make a fire under, shaking it until ye salt leap no more.
Spuma Salis is a fragment of ye foaming sea, found upon ye little rocks, & it hath the same virtue that salt hath.

Muria hath the same operation as ye salts, of abstersion, & it is a glister for ye dysentericall which have ye Nomas, & ye long troubled with Sciaticas, and it is good for fomentations, for whom ye sea-water is profitable.

But ye flower of Salt flows down from the river Nilus & it stands upon certain lakes. That is to be taken which is like saffron in ye colour, of somewhat a bad scent, like as Garum, and sometimes smelling worse (than this) and more biting to ye taste, & somewhat fat. But that which is coloured with Rubrica, or hath clots, is reckoned naught. And further ye unmixed is dissolved only by oil, but ye adulterated, in some part, by water. But it is good for malignant & Phagedaenicall ulcers & for Nomas which are in ye privities, & for purulent ears, & for dulness of sight, & it takes off scars and pearls: it is mixed with plasters and ointments to colour them, as also with Rosaceum: it is also a mover of sweats, & a disturber of ye belly being taken with wine and water, & is bad for ye stomach; it is mixed also with Acopa, & with Smegmata for extenuating of ye hair, and in general it is sharp burning, as the salts are.

That Nitre is to be preferred which is smooth, & rose like, or white in colour, holie through, as it were some spungeous thing, & such as this is that, which is brought from Buni. It hath a faculty, of fetching humors from ye depth.

Spuma Nitri, that is esteemed to be the best which is ye lightest, & crusty, and brittle, and drawing to a purple or frothy, & moreover biting. Such as is that which is brought from Philadelphia in Lydia. Next to this is that of Egypt. And also it grows in Magnesia of Caria, and both this and the Nitre have ye strength & ye burning like to salt, and moreover, ye Nitre also assuageth ye tormina being beaten small with Cumin, and drank with Hydromel or with Sapa, or some (decoction) of things of force to dissolve wind, such as is that of Rue or of Dill. It is also a fit ointment for ye troubled with circulary fevers before ye suspected time of ye fits coming. And it is mixed with dissolving and with drawing plasters good for ye leprosy, & with such as extenuate. But being infused with warm water or wine, it heals ye inflations and noise of ye ears & their suppurations, and being dropped in with vinegar it takes away their filth, & it heals ye dog-bitten with asses’, or swines’ grease; and it opens also ye Furunculos, being taken with Terebinthina, but with figs it is a Cataplasme for ye Hydropicall; & being smeared on with honey, it is a sight-quickner & it is good against mushrooms being drank with Posca, & against ye Buprestis with water, & for bulls’ blood with Silphium, & it is a profitable cataplasme for those in an atrophy, & with Cerat for Opisthotonicall passions that are somewhat remiss, & for luxations, & it is mixed profitably in their bread for such as have ye palsy in ye tongue. And some burn ye aforesaid things setting them on burning coals (a new ostracean vessel being first set under) until it be fired.

But that Foex is to be chosen specially, which is of old Italian wine, & if not (of that) of some other like it. For that of vinegar doth exceed in strength. It is burnt as Alcyonium, being first dried carefully. But some putting it in new ostracean (vessels) burn it with a great fire, until it be fiered quite through. But others hiding ye Mass (of Foex) in burning coals, do the like. But ye signe that is reckoned of its due burning when it is white, or like ye colour of ayre; and this, that being put to ye tongue, it doth, as it were, burn it: & in like sort the Foex of Vinegar is burnt. But it hath a faculty of extreme burning, & of being exceedingly extersive & of cicatrizing, of binding, & of extreme eating, & of drying. But we must use Foex that is new, for it quickly evaporates, whence it is to be set up, neither uncovered, neither without a vessel. And the same is washed as Pompholyx. But that which is unburnt doth restrain Oedemata, both by itself and with Myrtle, and being applied it stop both ye belly and fluxing stomach, and assuageth ye womanish flux being applied to ye lower part of ye belly, & ye privities; & it dissolves ye Panos & lesser swellings, not yet exulcerated, & being anointed on with vinegar it slacks swollen breasts that run out with milk; that with rosin which is burnt takes off rotten nails; & with Lentiscine oil being smeared on for a whole night, it makes ye hair yellow, but being washed it is mixed with eye-medicines, like as Spodium. And such as this doth do away ye scars and darknesses which are in ye eyes.

Calx viva is made thus, taking ye shells of ye sea fishes called Buccinoe, cover them in ye fire, or putting them into a thoroughly hot oven let them stand there all night, and ye next day, if they be grown very white take them out, but if not (burn them) again, & until they be white; afterward having dipped them in cold water, cast them into a new pot, and having stopped them carefully with clothes let them alone there for one night, but in ye morning taking out (ye Calx) after it hath received ye full complement of the work, set it up. And it is made also of flints, or peble stones being burnt, and of the common marble, which also is preferred before ye other. But all Calx in common hath a fiery, biting, burning incrustating faculty, but being mixed with certain other things, as with grease or oil, it becomes digestive, mollifying dissipating, cicatrizing. But they reckon ye newest, & that which was never wet to be ye effectuallest of it.
Gypsum hath a binding, pore-stopping, restraining faculty, both of bleeding and of sweating; but being drank, it chokes after ye manner of strangling.

Cinis Sarmentitius hath a causticall faculty, but being smeared on with Axungia or oil, it is good for ye bruises of ye sinews, & ye luxations of ye joints, and ye knots of ye nerves. And with nitre, and vinegar it represseth ye flesh excrescencies of ye Scrotum, & being smeared on with vinegar it heals things bitten of serpents, or of dogs; & it is mixed with encrusting medicines: and Lye is made of it good for precipitations & mushrooms, with vinegar, salt and honey.

It is known that there are five kinds of Alcyonium, for one kind is thick and of a sour taste, & to look unto like a sponge, & moreover poisonous and heavy, & smelling of a fish; and much of this is found upon the shores. But ye next, as for ye shape (of it), is like to ye Pterygium of ye eyes, & is both light & hollow in many places, or like a sponge, & having a smell like a sea-weed. But the third (sort) is, for ye fashion, like to a little worm & more purple in ye colour, which some call Milesium. But the fourth is like to unwashed wool, hollow in many places, light. But the fifth is like for ye fashion to a mushroom, & is both without smell and rough, within somewhat like ye Pumistone, but without, smooth, sharp. Much of it grows in Propontis about ye island called Besbicum, which in that country they call ye foam of ye sea. Of these the first and the second are taken into ye Smegmata of women & for the Lentigines, & ye Lichenas, & leprosies, & ye vitiligines, & blacknesses, and such spots as are upon the face and the rest of ye body. But ye third is of fit use for ye Dysureticall, and such as gather gravelly stuff in ye bladder, and for the nephriticall, & for ye dropsy, & ye spleen; but being burnt, and smeared on with wine, it thickens the Alopeciae. But ye last (kind) is of force, to white ye teeth. And it is taken into other Smegmata, and Psilothra, being mixed with salt. But if you would burn some of these, cast it with salt into a raw earthen pot, and having luted about ye mouth of it with clay, put it into a furnace; & when ye earthen pot is baked enough, take it out, set it up and use it. But it is washed as Cadmia.
137. ADARKES. Calcium Chloride and other salts

But that which is called Adarces grows in Galatia, & it is, as it were a somewhat saltish concrete humor, coming out of moist and marshy places in a time of drought, and sticking about ye reeds and grass. But it is like in colour to ye flower of ye stone of Asia, but in ye whole form, to Alcyonium, which is soft, and hollow in many places, & is, as it were, Alcyonium palustre. It is of fit use for ye excoriation of leprosies & of ye Ephelis, & of ye Lichenae, & of ye Lentigines & of ye like. In brief, it is sharp, drawing humors from ye depth & it is good for ye Sciaticall.

Sponges. Some have called these, males when full of small holes, and thick, of which they have named the hardest, Tragi; & ye other (they called) females which are contrary affected to the aforesaid. But they have ye same burning that Alcyonium hath. The empty & without fat, is both good for wounds, & represseth Oedemata, and conglutinateth new wounds with water or Posca, but sodden with honey it conjoineth old concavities. But ye old is of no use. [New sponges] open contracted ulcers & callums, being bound with a thread & put in dry like tents; they dry up ye fluxing undermining ulcers, and old ulcers, being laid on dry, new and empty, & they restrain also a flux of blood. But being burnt, with vinegar they are good for dry lippitudes, and where there is need to cleanse, or bind anything. But they do better, when washed for eye-medicines; & being burnt with pitch they are good for a flux of Blood. But ye tenderest of them are whited in ye burning heat of summer when moistened with Spuma Salis standing upon the rocks, and sunned. But let him take heed that ye hollow side of them (stand) upward, & ye cut side under. But if it be a clear summer weather, they are set also under the moon, being moistened with spuma Salis, or sea-water. And such as these are ye whitest.

But Corall (which some have called Lithodendron) seems to be a sea plant, & to be hardened when it is drawn out of ye deep, being out of ye sea &, as it were, dipped into ye air flowing round about us. Great store of it is found it the Promontory which is called Pachynum, by Syracuse, but ye best is that which is red in colour, and like to Sandaracha in colour, or to Sandyx, of a deep dye, & in like sort easy to pound, & even through its whole concrescency, & withal having a mossy smell, & like to little seaweeds, and withal having many branches, & imitating Cinnamon in ye form of little shrubs. But that which is stony by concretion, and rough by colour, and hollow, and loose, is thought to be naught. But by its faculty, it binds and cools gently, & it represseth excrescencies, & it takes off ye Cicatrices that are in the eyes, & fills up concavities and chaps, and works effectually against spittings of blood, & it is good for ye dysureticall, & it abates ye spleen being drank with water.

But that which is called Antipathes, is to be thought to be Corall, having a specificall difference, but it is by colour black; and this also is like a tree, but more branchy, & it hath ye same faculty to ye aforesaid.

The Phrygian stone, which ye Dyers in Phrygia use (whence also it is named) groweth in Cappadocia. That is ye best which is paler & indifferently heavy, not firm by ye compacture of ye body, having between partitions of white, like as Cadmia. But ye stone is burnt thus: having moistened it with the best wine, cover it with live coals & blow it continually; and if it change the colour being of a more deep yellow, taking it out, quench it with ye same wine, & putting it again into ye coals do ye same things, then burn it ye third time, looking to it crumble not, & vanish into soot. But both ye raw & that which is burnt, hath an effectually binding faculty, & besides a cleansing and a somewhat incrustating one, & an healing one of ambustions with Cerate; & it is washed like as Cadmia is.

But that Asian stone is to be taken which is pumicestone-like in the colour, both fungous and light & also brittle, having yellowish partitions to ye bottom. The flower of it is the yellowish salt humor which stands on the outside of ye stones, which in consistence is thin, & in colour some is white & some is like ye Pumistone, enclining to a yellow, & being put to the tongue it bites a little. Either of them hath a faculty of binding, of corroding gently, & of dissolving small swellings being taken with Terebinthinall Rosin, or liquid pitch, but ye flower is accounted the strongest. And moreover this being dried doth heal the old and hard-to-be-cicatrized ulcers, & represseth ye flesh-excrescencies, & doth cleanse with honey those like to mushrooms, & wild ulcers. And it fills also ye concavities of ulcers, & cleanseth them with honey, and it stays ye feeding (ulcers) being mixed with Cerat. And (it helps) ye Podagricall in Cataplasms with bean meal, & ye splenicall with vinegar and unslacked lime. But ye flower being licked in with honey is good for ye phthisicall. And there are made also of ye stone bathing vessels, into which ye podagricall put in their feet & are benefited, & there are made of it, coffins that will eat ye flesh; & they extenuate very fleshy and gross bodies being smeared on instead of nitre in a bath: and if any would wash the ye before-written things, let him wash them as Cadmia.

Pyrites is a kind of stone of which brass is made; but that which looks like brass, & which readily sends out Sparks is to be taken. But it is burnt after this manner. Having moistened it with honey, put it into a soft coal fire & blow it continually, till it become yellowish in colour. But some put ye stone well moistened with honey into many & hot burning coals, & when it shall begin to change to a tawny yellow they take it off, and blowing off ye ashes they burn it again being moistened, until it become more brittle in all places alike. For often it is burnt only on ye outside. And burning it thus, and drying it they set it up. But if there be need of having it washed, it is to be washed as Cadmia. It hath either burnt or raw, warming, abstergent faculty, cleansing away of those things that darken the sight, and dissolving and ripening of hardnesses. But taken with Rosin, it represseth flesh excrescencies with a little warming and binding. But some doe call this thus burnt, Diphryges.

That is ye best Haematites lapis which is brittle & of a deep colour, or black, but in itself hard and even, not partaking of any filth, or girdling vains. But it hath a faculty of binding, of somewhat warming & extenuating; of wearing off ye scars & scabrousness that are in ye eyes, with honey; & with woman’s milk (it is good for) lippitudes & broken & bloodshotten eyes. And it is drank with wine for ye Dysurie, & for womens fluxes; & for spitting of blood with Pomegranat juice. And there is made of it Collyries, and touch-stones fitting for the passions in the eyes. But it is burnt like to the Phrygian stone, only ye wine outset. But let this be ye measure of ye burning, that it become indifferently light, and swollen up with some bubbles. Some counterfeit ye aforesaid thus. Taking a piece of ye stone Schistus, both thick and round (& such are they which are called the roots of it) they cover it in an earthen big-bellied-vessel, having hot ashes (in it): then leaving it a little while, they take it out, & rub it on a touch-stone, trying whether it have taken ye colour of ye Haematites, and if it have so, they set it up; & if not, they cover it again, continually looking to it and proving it, for if left too long in the ashes, it changeth in colour & then dissolves. But that which is adulterated is reproved, first by ye vains running between, for this is broken into vains going out straight, but Haematites hath them not so; (secondly) by ye colour, for this sends out a flourishing colour, but ye Haematites a deeper one, like to Cinnabaris. And it is found also in the Sinopicall Rubrica: and Haematites is made of the Loade stone burnt very much, but that which grows of itself, is digged out of mines in Egypt.

Ye stone Schistos grows in Spain toward ye West, & that seems to be the best, which looks like saffron in ye colour, and is brittle, and easy to cleanse as in itself, and is like to Sal Amoniacum in respect of ye compacture, & of ye mutual coherence of ye veins. And it hath the same force that Haematites hath, coming short of it only in ye strength. It also fills up concavities being diluted with woman’s milk, & it is very effectual for ruptures & ye falling down of ye eyes, & for ye thickness of ye eye-lids & ye staphylomata.

But of ye Gagates that is to be preferred which is kindled quickly, & savours like Bitumen in ye smell. But it is commonly black, & ill-favoured, and also crusty & exceeding light. And it hath a softening, and dissolving faculty. And being suffumigated it is a discoverer of ye epilepticall, and it fetcheth again women that have hysteria, & it is mixed with podagricall and acopicall medicines, and it drives away serpents with ye smoke. It grows in Cilicia at a certain fall of ye river flowing into ye sea, & it is near ye city which is called Plagiopolis. Ye place and the river at ye mouth of which these stones are found is called Gagas. [& they say also that it is a discerner of ye holy grief, for when it is smelt being born down to ye earth, they fall on a suddain, & that being perfumed it doth heal ye hidden griefs of women, they taking in ye vapour.]

But that which is called Thracius groweth in Scythia, in a river which is called Pontus. It can perform ye same cures that Gagates can, and it is said that it is set on fire with water, and quenched with oil, which also is donne upon Asphaltus.

But of ye Load-stone that which draws iron easily is ye best, & of an azure-like colour & thick, but not too heavy. It hath a faculty of drawing out gross humors being given with melicrate ye weight of 3 Oboli [& they say that this hath a discerning faculty of a woman that is chaste & of her that plays ye adulteress with another man, for if any do set it secretly upon the beds for ye chaste woman, who loves her husband, she being overborne into sleep, with a certain natural faculty of ye stone both opens her hands towards her husband, and cleaves close to him; but the other being troubled in dreams with foul labours, falls out of ye bed. Also when two men carry this, it freeth them from all strife, & it causeth concord, and being born on ye breast, it assuageth people].
But ye stone called Arabicus is like ye spot of ivory. This being beaten small, & smeared on, doth dry up ye Haemorrhoids, & being burnt is a dentifrice of ye teeth.

But this is called Galactites from its sending out milky stuff; else otherwise, it is like ashes in ye colour, & sweet to ye taste. It is good being anointed on for ye fluxes & ulcers of ye eyes. But it behoves them that beat it in water, to set it up in a leaden box for ye glueiness about it.
But Melitites is like to Galactites in all things, differing in that it sends out a sweeter juice: it is effectuall for what also Galactites is.

It is called also Galactites & Lethaeus, because men carrying it, and going to their own masters, find them well-affected, and taking a forgetfullness of ye same evils (often committed); & that ye milk of goats, and of sheep being extinguished, if any beat it small mixing it with brine it helps ye little flock: they say that it can do ye same to women for ye breeding of milk, being beaten and drank, and that being bound about ye neck in infants, it saves him free from envy & from diseases & keepeth the infant from treachery, & that both kings and judges do reverence him that bears this about him & that they seem gracious to all men.

Lapis Morochthus which some have called Galaxia or Leucographis, grows in Egypt, which also they who make linen use for whiting of the clothes, it being soft, & melting. It is thought also to stop ye pores, being good for blood-spitters, & ye Coeliacall; & the griefs of ye bladder being drank with water, & in like sort for fluxing women, and in a Pessum. And it is mixed with mollifying eye-medicines for it fills up concavities, & stays fluxes. But being taken with cerat, it cicatrizeth ye tenderness of ulcers.
Lapis Alabastrites, which is called Onyx, being taken when it is burnt with Rosin, or Pitch, dissolves hardnesses, & doth ease ye griefs of ye stomach with Cerate, and it bindeth ye gums.

The stone called Thyites growes in Aethiopia, & it is greenish, like jasper stone, & in being washed shewing of a milk colour, biting extremely, but it hath a faculty of cleansing away such things as darken ye apples of ye eyes.
155. IOUDAIKOS LITHOS. Fossil Spines of Sea Urchins

But ye Judaicall stone grows in Judea, in fashion like a Glans, white, of very handsome form, having also lines answering one another as if made by turning. Being dissolved, it yields no rellish in ye taste. But a Cicer-like bigness (thereof) being dissolved like a Collyrie on a whetstone with three Cyathi of warm water & drank, is of force to help Dysuries & to break ye stones in ye bladder.

Amiantus Lapis groweth in Cyprus, being like Alumen Scissile, which ye workmen make webbs of cloth of it, for a show, which being cast into ye fire take flame, but come out more bright, not burnt by ye fire.

The Sapphire stone is thought to be good for ye Scorpion-smitten being drank. And it is drank also for exulcerations that are inward and for the excrescencies in the eyes, and it represseth ye uvas, and Pustles, & it conjoins ye ruptures of ye Membranes.

Lapis Memphitis is found in Egypt by Memphis, having ye bigness of a pebble stone, fat, & of divers colours. It is said that this being beaten small, and smeared upon the places that shall be cut, or burnt, doth bring in them a stupid senselessness, without danger.

Lapis Selenites which some have called Aphroselenon because it is found in ye night-time, full in ye increase of ye moon. But it grows in Arabia, being white, transparent, light: filing it they give ye dust for a drink to ye epilepticall; but the women use it to hang it about them for an Amulet, & it is thought that being bound to trees, it makes them bear fruit.

Lapis Iaspis, some kind of it is like ye Emerald, & some like Christall resembling phlegm, some like ye air & some (is called) Capnia, as we should say, besmoked, and some also having white midling partitions, and glittering, called Assyrius. And some is called Terebinthizusa being in colour like to Calais. But all are said to be Amulets being hanged about one, & to speed deliverance, being tied to ye thigh.

Aetites lapis, which on being shaken sends out a sound as if it were great with another stone. It is an holder in of ye Embrya when ye wombs are slippery, being tied about ye left arm; but in the time of deliverance, taking it from ye arm tie it about ye thigh, & she shall bring forth without pain: & it is a discloser of a thief, if any put it into ye bread that he offers him, for he that stole cannot be able to swallow down ye things chewed; & they say also that Aetites, being sodden together with meat becomes a betrayer of a thief, for he who stole, shall not be able to swallow that which was sodden with it: but being beaten small, and taken in a Cerat made of Cyprinum or Gleucinum or of some other of those that warm, doth help greatly ye epilepticall.

Lapis Ophites, one kind of it is heavy and black; another of an ashy colour, & distinguished with pricks; & another having white lines. But each of them being tied about one is good for ye serpent-bitten & such as have ye headache; but that which hath ye lines is reported in particular to help ye Lethargy & headaches.
Stones which are found in the sponges, being drank with wine, break ye stone in ye bladder.
But Lithocolla, being a mixture of marble, or ye Parian stone, and bulls glue, is of force with a Probe made red-hot to turn back ye hairs (that hang) in ye eyes.

Lapis Ostracites, is like unto a shell, crusty & easy to cleave, which ye women use instead of ye Pumicestone for ye taking off hairs. And it stays ye menstrua being drank with wine ye quantity of a dragm. And if any drink ye weight of 2 dragms, after ye menstrua it causeth inconception. And being laid on with honey it assuageth enflamed duggs, & stays ye Nomas.
Smyris Lapis is that wherewith ye jewellers do polish their stones, being good for Septicall & causticall medicines, & for ye moisture of ye gums, and ye cleansing of ye teeth.

The sand which is burnt by the sunne upon the shores, doth dry up ye moisture of hydropicall bodies when covered all over except ye head. And it is roasted also for dry fomentations, instead of Milium, or salt.

That which comes off from ye Naxian whetstone when Iron is rubbed upon it, fills up with hair ye Alopeciae & forbids maidens breasts to grow big; but being drank with vinegar, it abates ye spleen, and is good for ye Epilepticall.
The stone Geodes doth bind, dry and take away things that darken the eyes. And being smeared on with water it assuageth ye inflammations of ye duggs & of ye stones.
All earth that falls (within ye compass) of medicinal use hath a supreme faculty of cooling & stopping the pores, but it differs in kind: one being good for other things with some preparations.

Of ye Eretrian earth some is exceedingly white, & some is of an ashy colour, but ye best is that which resembles ashes in ye colour and is very soft, and being drawn along brass-works yield out a violet-like lineament. But it is washed as Cerussa, or thus: having beaten small as much as you will of it by itself, & with water, let it be settled: then strain out the moisture gently, & having dried the earth in ye sun, beat it again a whole day putting water (to it) suffering it to settle all night; about ye break of day strain it, & having beaten it small in ye sun form it into trochiscks, as far as is possible. But if there be need of having it roasted, taking (pieces) of ye bigness of a Cicer of ye earth, put it into a vessel of earth full of holes, & having stopped ye mouth carefully, put it into lighted coals, & blow it continually, but when the ashes be turned to sparks, or rather become of an aerie colour, taking it out set it up. It hath a binding and a cooling faculty, gently mollifying, and filling up concavities, and conglutinating of bleeding wounds.

But of ye Samian earth that is preferred which is very white, & which is light, and in touching the tongue holds it fast like glue, & withal full of juice and soft, and brittle, such as is that which some do call Collyrium. There are 2 kinds of it, both ye aforesaid, & that which is called Aster being crusty, and thick, like ye whetstone: it hath ye virtue & the burning, & ye washing like to Eretrias. It stays ye spitting of blood, and is given to fluxing women with ye flower of wild pomegranat, & it assuages ye inflammations of ye stones & of ye duggs being smeared on with water, & it represseth sweatings, & it helps ye venemous-beast-bitten & such as have taken a deadly medicine, being drank with water.

There is found also a certain stone in Samia, which the goldsmiths use to polish & make ye gold glistering. But that is ye best which is white, & heavy. It hath a binding, cooling faculty, being good for ye stomach-sick in drink, dulling the senses. It is good for the fluxes and ulcers in the eyes with milk, & it is thought to be a quick speeder of delivery and a preserver of women that have conceived, being tied about them.

But of ye Chian, that which is white, & drawing to an ashy colour & that which is like to ye Samian is to be taken: but it is crusty, & white, but differing in ye forms of ye making up. But it hath ye same virtue that ye Samian hath. And it makes ye visage, and more ye whole body to be without wrinkles and clear, & in a bath it scours instead of Nitre.
The same things also doth ye Selinusian perform, but ye best is that which glisters extremely, and is white, and brittle, and very speedily dissolved if it take wet.

But of ye Cimolian earth some is white and some enclining to a purple, possessed of a certain fatness bred in it, and to the touch somewhat cold, which they count ye best. But either being diluted with vinegar do dissolve ye Parotidas, & ye other lesser tumors. And they are good for ambustions being anointed on out of hand, so that it keeps the affected parts from blistering. And they do suppress ye hardness of ye stones, and ye inflammations about the whole body, & moreover they withstand ye Erysipelata, & in brief, the genuine are of much use, if ye bastard ones be not taken.

But ye earth called Pnigitis in colour resembles in a manner ye Eretrian earth, but it is thick crusted, cooling when touched by ye hands, & it very much cleaves to ye tongue, so that it hangs on it. And it hath ye same virtue that Cimolia hath, failing something of ye strength. Some sell this for Eretrian.

But ye tiles of Furnaces that are much burnt, are encrustative whence being anointed on with vinegar they heal itchings, & ye breaking out of pustles, and they are good for ye podagricall, & being taken with Cerat they dissolve ye strumas.
And ye red earth of the Furnaces that is well burnt hath the same quality that ye shells have.

But Melia as to its colour is also like to that of Eretrian earth which is of an ash colour, but is rough, & when rubbed with ye fingers (is noted) to send out a creaking noise like Pumicestone when it is grated; but it is like Allom in quality, but somewhat more remissely, which also appears by the taste. It drieth also ye tongue gently. Also it is of force to make ye body clean and well-coloured, & also it extenuates ye hair, and it wears off ye Alphos, & ye Lepras. And it is of good use also for painters for ye longer continuance of their colours & it co-operates in green plasters. Both of this, & commonly of all earth, that is to be chosen, which is without stones and new, and soft, and brittle & easily dissolved when it toucheth moisture.

But of ye earth Amphelitis which some call Pharmacitis growing in Seleucia which is by Syria, that which is black is to be chosen. It is like to small coals of ye Pitch tree, cleaving like a lath, and glistering equally; & moreover not melted slowly when a little oil is poured on it, when it is beaten small. But ye white, & ashy, & unmeltable is reckoned naught. It hath a dissolving and cooling faculty. And it is taken also for to make ye eye-lids fair, & for ye dyeing of ye hair, and for ye anointing of ye vines at the time of their putting out, for it kills ye worms that breed in them.
Fuligo pictoria, which ye painters use, is taken of ye glass-makers for that is the best. But it hath a putrifying, sharp faculty, and with Ceratum Rosaceum, it cicatrizeth fractures.

The ink wherewith we write, is prepared from ye soot gathered of torches, and there are mixed to one ounce of Gum, three ounces of soot. It is made also of the soot of Rosin & of ye aforesaid Fuligo pictoria. But you must take of ye Fuligo pictoria one pound, & of gum half a pound, of bulls-blue half an ounce, of Chalcanthum half an ounce. And it is good to put in to septicall medicines, & for ambustions being anointed on thick with water, & let alone till ye cicatrizing, for it falls off of its own accord, when ye ulcers are healed.
And so, O Most Loving Areius, to have stored up well near as much as we thought fitting, & to be of a large composure withall, & of store of Matter Medicinall, & helps, let this suffice.
An end of ye fifth, and last

The following identifications of the plants of Dioscorides are those which were suggested by Professor Charles Daubeny in 1857, and published as an Appendix to his Lectures on Roman Husbandry wherein he gave the following explanation:

“Those introduced have been classified according to the Natural System; in which undertaking I have availed myself of the kind assistance of Mr. Maxwell Masters, Lecturer on Botany to St. George’s Hospital, who till lately filled the post of Sub-Curator to the Fielding Herbarium, now attached to the Botanic Garden at Oxford.

It has been thought useful to point out in what degree, and in what cases, the conjecture formed as to the plant intended derives confirmation from the drawings accompanying the most ancient known MS. of Dioscorides, which has been done, by noticing briefly the character of the figure therein given. When the term fictitious is attached, the meaning is, that the artist, in ignorance of the plant named, has given a representation of some other, totally unconnected with the real one, if indeed he has not in this instance drawn from his own fancy alone. In other cases, the figure given, however bad, rude, or inaccurate, is conceived to have been taken, either from the plant itself, or from some drawing of it to which the draughtsman had had access”
Out of 345 plants he regarded 93 as good, 36 as fictitious, 17 as bad, 16 with some resemblance, 3 with no resemblance, 127 as pretty good, 9 as tolerably like, and 44 as indifferent.

The Greek χοη was a libation, here used as a fluid measure, a congius=5.76 pints. Liquid Measure. 1 choa or congius = 6 sextarii = 12 kotulai or heminae = 72 kuathoi = 5.76 pints. A cyathus = about 1/12 pint.
A species of Amyris known as kataf is like Sorbus domestica.
Two 3-obol pieces weighed 1 drachma or about 66 ½ grains. 100 drachmas = 1 mina (or ‘pound’ of 15.2 oz.).
